"I have lived in Dresden since 2001. I moved to Dresden with my family in the eighties, but then I lived elsewhere for years, in Freiberg, Munich and Eilenburg. After training in agriculture and serving in the military, I got my high school degree and studied political science, history, law, and culture management. Since 2001, I have lived here in the Neustadt.

I am active in a number of associations that deal with Jewish history and culture, including HATiKVA, the Jewish Music and Theatre Week, the Friends of the Synagogue, and Stolpersteine for Dresden. I have also been working in the synagogue for over eighteen years, and I do guided tours there. That job is incredibly fun. Itâs different from what I do every day.

I travelled to Israel several times in the early nineties, and at some point, I discovered the HATiKVA association and became a member of it. I was already a tour guide in the city when the synagogue was inaugurated. But I also worked for five years at the memorial at the former prison for political prisoners in Bautzen. It was a great thing to be able to do that. In the beginning at the synagogue, there was a lot of interest in history and architecture, but in the course of time people became more and more interested in religion, what was behind it, and what the Jewish community is today. I love the city, its diversity, the Altstadt with its world-famous baroque splendor, but I also love the Neustadt, the neighborhood, the cool people who live there. "I live in Chemnitz on the KaÃberg, a neighborhood known for its beautiful architecture, which has many small pubs and bars and shops. On my street, for example, there is a bookstore and a wine bar. That is actually enough. Every year, there are small markets here, where the residents of the surrounding streets come out and participate however they can. Nobody can really say how this year will be, but I already notice when I am going to work or coming home that not many people are on the street anymore, all bars and shops are hanging up notes. It makes me a bit sad, and I ask myself whether the infrastructure will still be there after the crisis.

Because I work for an ESF-funded project, which is based at an educational provider in the private sector, I am still goingfd to the office. I work at the Coordination Office for Literacy in the Free State of Saxony (koalpha) and through my daily efforts I try to help end the taboo around the topic of functional illiteracy - now known as "low literacy among adults." In Germany, 12.1 percent of the people have difficulties with reading and writing and another 20 percent read and write very poorly. This is a large number, and yet we speak about it far too rarely. But in order to sensitize the public, I have to go out and talk to people, of course. For example, we attend the Book Fair every year or events organized by job centers and employment agencies, none of which are taking place at the moment. Ich weiÃ, dass es im Moment fÃ¼r alle eine sehr schwere Zeit ist. Ich habe versucht, meinen arabischen MitbÃ¼rgern zu helfen zu verstehen, welche Nachrichten Ã¼ber die Krise Fakenews sind. I am proud of Germany â how people are helping each other."

I found the events of 2018 frightening. I would never have thought the rightwing could mobilize so much so quickly. If you take them seriously, you can get them excited about responsibility and participation at a very early age. In this way, I can make a small contribution as a mother and by training teachers. In the short term, we must also focus on bringing people together. Prejudices can be overcome through experience. My mother is a DaZ teacher. When my grandparents visited her, she invited her whole DaZ class. My grandparents met people from different backgrounds who did not fit their prejudices about "foreigners" and therefore they had to recognize their prejudices as such and discard them. We need a lot more encounters like that.

My children have two parents who show interest and commitment to their learning. But not everyone is doing so well - some children will suffer severe educational disadvantages due to being out of school for so long, people will lose their jobs and no longer have a salary because they work freelance. Here in Germany we have responsible politicians who provide financial aid and a well-functioning health system. In other countries, the situation is much worse. At the moment, I am watching all this with concern and trying to provide a good atmosphere and education for my children at home. In the afternoon and in between I do my work - it's a bit exhausting, but absolutely fine and not worth complaining about, considering how bad the situation is for many others. I only hope that the appeal to everyone's sense of responsibility will have an even greater effect. I am skeptical about that.

Im Dezember 2004 starb mein Vater, weshalb ich zurÃ¼ck nach Deutschland kam. Ich wollte gern nach Dresden oder in die Umgebung und so bin ich im Mai 2005 in Pirna gelandet. 2010 kamen dann zwei grÃ¶Ãere VerÃ¤nderungen mit dem Umzug nach Dresden im FrÃ¼hjahr und der Aufnahme des Psychologiestudiums im Oktober.

Ich war seitdem schon mehrfach im Finnlandurlaub und frage mich immer wieder mal, ob ich nicht hÃ¤tte bleiben sollen. Aber dann hÃ¤tte ich jetzt nicht das Leben mit meinem Mann und den drei Kindern hier und das mÃ¶chte ich natÃ¼rlich auch nicht mehr hergeben! An Finnland mag ich vor allem die Ruhe und Natur. Man fÃ¼hlt sich irgendwie immer nah an der Natur, ist schnell am Fluss oder im Wald, und ich fand, dass mich das immer sehr entspannt und selber zur Ruhe gebracht hat. Das ganze Leben ist ziemlich am Rhythmus der Natur ausgerichtet. Es ist eben auch alles intensiver - die dunklen Winter, die hellen Sommer, die Temperaturunterschiede. Die Finnen sind auch sehr naturverbunden, gehen skifahren, angeln, jagen, wandern. Sobald der Fluss tief genug zugefroren ist, werden die Loipen gezogen, und man kann selbst mit Wohnung im Stadtzentrum direkt nach der Arbeit noch eine Runde skifahren gehen. Insgesamt kam mir der Alltag etwas langsamer und entspannter vor. Und die Menschen sind im Schnitt zurÃ¼ckhaltender, was anfangs durchaus gewÃ¶hnungsbedÃ¼rftig ist, weil Kontakte und GesprÃ¤che auch mal mÃ¼hsamer ins Laufen kommen, aber dann ist es eben auch ehrlich und authentisch und das fand ich angenehm.

Wir waren jetzt eine Woche mit den Kindern (14 Monate, 4 Jahre, 5 Jahre) zu Hause. Da wir aber gerade in einer 50-qm-Ferienwohnung leben, weil seit Oktober die Sanierung unserer Mietwohnung nicht fertig wird, haben wir uns nach einigem AbwÃ¤gen entschieden, dass ich mit den Kindern nach Brandenburg zu den Schwiegereltern âflÃ¼chteâ. Die haben ein Haus mit Garten und da sind natÃ¼rlich die AusgangsbeschrÃ¤nkungen deutlich besser auszuhalten.    

Mein Mann muss wegen der Arbeit in Dresden bleiben, was fÃ¼r uns als Familie zwar auch nicht schÃ¶n ist, aber in der kleinen Wohnung festzusitzen hÃ¤tte uns allen sicher auch nicht gut getan. Also auch fÃ¼r uns ist das eine groÃe Ausnahmesituation, aber eigentlich kommen wir dabei noch recht entspannt weg, und das wissen wir sehr zu schÃ¤tzen!"

"I was born and grew up in Greiz, and I lived there until after my training as an occupational therapist. I moved to Griesheim in South Hessen for my first three years of work, before I moved to northern Finland for a year of volunteering. I spent a total of 16 months there. It's been 15 years now, but I still get quite wistful thinking back. It was really a wonderful experience! My father died in December of 2004, so I came back to Germany. I wanted to move to Dresden or the surrounding area, and so I landed in Pirna in May 2005. There were two major changes in my life in 2010: I moved to Dresden in spring and I started my studies in psychology in October.

Since then, I have been on holiday in Finland several times, and I always wonder if I should have stayed. But then I wouldn't have my life with my husband and our three children here, and of course I wouldn't want to give that up! What I like most about Finland is the quiet and nature. You somehow always feel close to nature, you can always reach a river or the woods quickly, and I found that this made me very relaxed and calm. Life in Finland is pretty much oriented to the rhythm of nature. Everything is more intense - the dark winters, the bright summers, the temperature differences. The Finns are also very close to nature; they go skiing, fishing, hunting, hiking. As soon as the river has frozen enough, the cross-country ski trails are drawn, and you can go skiing right after work, even if you have an apartment in the city centre. All in all, everyday life seemed a bit slower and more relaxed to me. And the people are more reserved on average, which takes getting used to at first, because making contact and having conversations can sometimes be a bit more tedious, but then it is also honest and authentic, and I found that pleasant.

We have now been at home with the children (14 months, 4 years, 5 years) for a week. We are currently living in a 50 square meter short-term rental, because the renovation of our apartment has been going on since October. After considering it for a while, we decided that I should "flee" with the children to Brandenburg to my parents-in-law. They have a house with a garden and of course the restrictions on going out are much easier to bear.

My husband has to stay in Dresden because of work, which is not great for us as a family, but being stuck in the small flat would not have been good for us either. We had already collected ideas and bought some material and games to pass the time, but in the long run, it would have been a burden. Our youngest had just started daycare in March, so I haven't started working again yet. That's why we don't have the childcare problem that many other families have. It's is also a very special situation for us, but actually we are still quite relaxed and we know we should appreciate that."

"Vor Ã¼ber zwei Jahren auf dem NeustÃ¤dter Gelichter Markt vor der Scheune trafen wir uns ja schon einmal. Wir sprachen damals Ã¼ber das Kriegsenkelprojekt, welches ich in Dresden gegrÃ¼ndet hatte. Es gab eine ganze Weile einen GesprÃ¤chskreis und fÃ¼r ein Jahr auch eine kleine FÃ¶rderung der Stadt. Es sollte ein Projekt mit Worten und Poesie werden, welches in einer Art Lesung mÃ¼nden sollte, und eine Veranstaltungsreihe mit Filmen und Lesungen war geplant. Die ganze Organisation fast ohne finanzielle UnterstÃ¼tzung und fehlende Mitstreiter und Mitstreiterinnen hat leider extrem viel Kraft gekostet. Und mein Ziel, auch bei den Februarveranstaltungen der Stadt dabei zu sein oder Menschen das Thema nahezubringen, eben durch Veranstaltungen, war wohl einfach zu groÃ, leider. Als letzte Veranstaltung gab es eine FilmvorfÃ¼hrung von "TÃ¶chter ohne VÃ¤ter" - zumindest eine Veranstaltung, die stattfand neben dem GesprÃ¤chskreis. Gern hÃ¤tte ich auch noch "SÃ¶hne ohne VÃ¤ter" gezeigt, der auch schon auf 3Sat lief. Zwei Filme Ã¼ber die Generation unserer GroÃeltern und Eltern, ein guter Einstieg ins Thema. Denn die Familie in der wir aufwachsen sind prÃ¤gt uns zutiefst, mit all ihren alten Mustern und PÃ¤ckchen.

Die letzten Jahre habe ich auch das Filmprojekt "Der Krieg in mir" verfolgt. Sebastian Heinzel, der mir aus dem Kriegsenkel e.V. bekannt ist, hat dieses Projekt als Filmemacher auf die Beine gestellt. Er verfolgt als Kriegsenkel im Film die Spuren seiner GroÃeltern. Er reist nach WeiÃrussland, dort wo sein GroÃvater als Soldat im Einsatz war. Er macht auf dieser Reise viele Entdeckungen und wir dÃ¼rfen ihn im Film dabei begleiten. Auch wenn das Kriegsenkelprojekt jetzt ruht, mÃ¶chte ich und auch einige andere Menschen versuchen, diesen Film nach Dresden zu bringen. Und gleichzeitig wollen wir eine Lesung veranstalten, denn Sebastian hat auch ein Buch zum Film geschrieben, welches gerade erschienen ist.

Ich widme mich auch dem Schreiben und der Biografiearbeit und unterstÃ¼tze auch andere Menschen dabei, sich dem eigenen Leben zuzuwenden, Dinge zu klÃ¤ren und dann leichter und mutiger in die Zukunft zu gehen. Die letzten Jahre habe ich mich sehr viel mit Trauma, vor allem den frÃ¼hen Bindungstraumata, befasst. Etwas, das sehr viele Menschen betrifft. Wir leben in einer traumatisierten Gesellschaft, und so lange wir da nicht hinschauen und das klÃ¤ren, geben wir dieses Trauma an unsere Kinder weiter. FÃ¼r mich ist das ein gesellschaftlich enorm relevantes Thema. Gerade im Osten, wo viele Kinder zu DDR-Zeiten viel zu frÃ¼h in die Krippe gegeben wurden, betrifft das viele Menschen sehr versteckt - denn das, was in dieser frÃ¼hen Kindheit erlebt wurde, konnte das Kind damals ja nicht fassen oder verstehen, und spÃ¤ter geht es den Erwachsenen schlecht. Sie fÃ¼hlen vielleicht eine innere Leere oder haben Probleme mit Beziehungen, verfolgen oft autoritÃ¤re Ansichten, lenken sich zu viel ab, bekommen Depressionen, Ãngste oder ein ErschÃ¶pfungssyndrom, und viele leiden auch unter einer posttraumatischen BelastungsstÃ¶rung. Leider wird das oft nicht erkannt, weil die Verbindungen nicht richtig gesehen werden, und so wird zu oberflÃ¤chlich geschaut und dann eben auch zu oberflÃ¤chlich damit umgegangen, leider. Dabei prÃ¤gt uns die frÃ¼he Kindheit am tiefsten und die Themen sind eigentlich bekannt in der Medizin.

Kinder kennen nur das was sie erleben, das ist fÃ¼r sie die NormalitÃ¤t, daraus werden Strategien des Ãberlebens entwickelt, die spÃ¤ter einfach nicht mehr funktionieren, und der Mensch dreht sich dann im Kreis. Meistens braucht es erst eine heftige Krise, bis die Menschen sich selbst die Aufmerksamkeit schenken, die es braucht. Keiner schaut sich das natÃ¼rlich gern an, weil es einfach sehr schmerzhaft ist, diese Thematik bei sich selbst zu realisieren und zu sehen, wie die Kinderseele gebrochen wurde und wie sehr dies das ganze Leben und die eigene Familie beeinflusst. Vieles in unserer Gesellschaft basiert aber leider auf dieser Basis. Noch immer steht ja das Funktionieren des Menschen im Vordergrund. Es geht in unserer Welt um alles MÃ¶gliche, aber kaum um die wesentlichen Dinge wie (An)Bindung und BedÃ¼rfnissorientierung. Eigentlich ist die momentane Zeit diesbezÃ¼glich echt spannend. Denn sie wirft uns sehr auf uns selbst zurÃ¼ck."

"More than two years ago, we met at the NeustÃ¤dter Gelichter Markt in front of the Scheune. Back then, we talked about the Kriegsenkel (War-Grandchild) project, which I had founded in Dresden. We had a discussion group for a while, and a small grant from the city for one year. The intention was to create a project with words and poetry, which was going to culminate in a kind of reading, and we planned a series of events with films and readings. All of the organization, with almost no financial support and a lack of colleagues, unfortunately took a lot of energy. And my goal, to be participate in the city events in February and to introduce people to the topic through events, was simply too big, unfortunately. The last event was a film screening of "Daughters without Fathers" - at least one event that took place in addition to the discussion group. I would also have liked to screen "Sons without Fathers", which was also shown on 3Sat. Both films are about our grandparentsâ and parentsâ generations and are a good introduction to the topic. The family in which we grow up has a deep impact on us, with all its old patterns and baggage.

The last few years I have also been following the film project "The War Within Me." The filmmaker Sebastian Heinzel, whom I know from the Kriegsenkel e.V., got this project off the ground. As a war grandchild, he follows the traces of his grandparents in the film. He travels to Belarus, where his grandfather was a soldier. He makes many discoveries on this journey, and we are allowed to accompany him in the film. Even though the war grandchild project is now on hiatus, I and some other people would like to try to bring this film to Dresden. And we would also like to organize a reading; Sebastian has also written a book about the film, which has just been published.

I am also dedicating myself to writing and biography work, and I also support other people in thinking about their own lives, clarifying things and then going into the future more lightly and courageously. In the last few years, I have dealt a lot with trauma, especially the early attachment traumas, something that affects very many people. We live in a traumatized society, and as long as we don't look at it and sort it out, we pass this trauma on to our children. For me, this is an enormously relevant social issue. Especially in the East, where many children were put into daycare far too early during the GDR period. This affects many people in a very subtle way - because children cannot grasp or understand what they experience in early childhood, and then later, they feel bad as adults. They may feel an inner emptiness or have problems with relationships; they often have authoritarian views, become too distracted, get depressed, anxious or burn out, and many also suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Unfortunately, this is often not recognized because the connections are not seen properly, and so people view it too superficially and then deal with it too superficially, unfortunately. Early childhood has the deepest impact on us, a topic that has been well researched in the medical discourse.

Children only know what they experience; what they experience is the normality for them, from which they develop survival strategies, and later, these simply don't work anymore, and the person then goes round in circles. Usually, it takes a severe crisis before people give themselves the attention they need. Nobody likes to face this, of course, because it is just really painful to confront this subject in oneself and to see how your child's soul has been broken and how much this affects your whole life and your own family. Unfortunately, there is a lot in our society is based on this. The functioning human being is still in the foreground. Our world is about all sorts of things but not really the essential things like attachment and needs. Actually, the current time is really exciting in this respect because it makes us confront ourselves."

Und gleichzeitig wollen wir eine Lesung veranstalten, denn Sebastian hat auch ein Buch zum Film geschrieben, welches gerade erschienen ist.

Die letzten Jahre habe ich mich sehr viel mit Trauma, vor allem den frÃ¼hen Bindungstraumata, befasst. Etwas, das sehr viele Menschen betrifft. Wir leben in einer traumatisierten Gesellschaft, und so lange wir da nicht hinschauen und das klÃ¤ren, geben wir dieses Trauma an unsere Kinder weiter. Sie fÃ¼hlen vielleicht eine innere Leere oder haben Probleme mit Beziehungen, verfolgen oft autoritÃ¤re Ansichten, lenken sich zu viel ab, bekommen Depressionen, Ãngste oder ein ErschÃ¶pfungssyndrom, und viele leiden auch unter einer posttraumatischen BelastungsstÃ¶rung. Leider wird das oft nicht erkannt, weil die Verbindungen nicht richtig gesehen werden, und so wird zu oberflÃ¤chlich geschaut und dann eben auch zu oberflÃ¤chlich damit umgegangen, leider. Dabei prÃ¤gt uns die frÃ¼he Kindheit am tiefsten und die Themen sind eigentlich bekannt in der Medizin.

Kinder kennen nur das was sie erleben, das ist fÃ¼r sie die NormalitÃ¤t, daraus werden Strategien des Ãberlebens entwickelt, die spÃ¤ter einfach nicht mehr funktionieren, und der Mensch dreht sich dann im Kreis. Meistens braucht es erst eine heftige Krise, bis die Menschen sich selbst die Aufmerksamkeit schenken, die es braucht. Keiner schaut sich das natÃ¼rlich gern an, weil es einfach sehr schmerzhaft ist, diese Thematik bei sich selbst zu realisieren und zu sehen, wie die Kinderseele gebrochen wurde und wie sehr dies das ganze Leben und die eigene Familie beeinflusst. Vieles in unserer Gesellschaft basiert aber leider auf dieser Basis. Noch immer steht ja das Funktionieren des Menschen im Vordergrund. Es geht in unserer Welt um alles MÃ¶gliche, aber kaum um die wesentlichen Dinge wie (An)Bindung und BedÃ¼rfnissorientierung. Eigentlich ist die momentane Zeit diesbezÃ¼glich echt spannend. "More than two years ago, we met at the NeustÃ¤dter Gelichter Markt in front of the Scheune. Back then, we talked about the Kriegsenkel (War-Grandchild) project, which I had founded in Dresden. We had a discussion group for a while, and a small grant from the city for one year. The intention was to create a project with words and poetry, which was going to culminate in a kind of reading, and we planned a series of events with films and readings. All of the organization, with almost no financial support and a lack of colleagues, unfortunately took a lot of energy. And my goal, to be participate in the city events in February and to introduce people to the topic through events, was simply too big, unfortunately. The last event was a film screening of "Daughters without Fathers" - at least one event that took place in addition to the discussion group. I would also have liked to screen "Sons without Fathers", which was also shown on 3Sat. Both films are about our grandparentsâ and parentsâ generations and are a good introduction to the topic. The family in which we grow up has a deep impact on us, with all its old patterns and baggage.

The last few years I have also been following the film project "The War Within Me." The filmmaker Sebastian Heinzel, whom I know from the Kriegsenkel e.V., got this project off the ground. As a war grandchild, he follows the traces of his grandparents in the film. He travels to Belarus, where his grandfather was a soldier. He makes many discoveries on this journey, and we are allowed to accompany him in the film. Even though the war grandchild project is now on hiatus, I and some other people would like to try to bring this film to Dresden. And we would also like to organize a reading; Sebastian has also written a book about the film, which has just been published.

I am also dedicating myself to writing and biography work, and I also support other people in thinking about their own lives, clarifying things and then going into the future more lightly and courageously. In the last few years, I have dealt a lot with trauma, especially the early attachment traumas, something that affects very many people. We live in a traumatized society, and as long as we don't look at it and sort it out, we pass this trauma on to our children. For me, this is an enormously relevant social issue. Especially in the East, where many children were put into daycare far too early during the GDR period. This affects many people in a very subtle way - because children cannot grasp or understand what they experience in early childhood, and then later, they feel bad as adults. They may feel an inner emptiness or have problems with relationships; they often have authoritarian views, become too distracted, get depressed, anxious or burn out, and many also suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Unfortunately, this is often not recognized because the connections are not seen properly, and so people view it too superficially and then deal with it too superficially, unfortunately. Early childhood has the deepest impact on us, a topic that has been well researched in the medical discourse.

Children only know what they experience; what they experience is the normality for them, from which they develop survival strategies, and later, these simply don't work anymore, and the person then goes round in circles. Usually, it takes a severe crisis before people give themselves the attention they need. Nobody likes to face this, of course, because it is just really painful to confront this subject in oneself and to see how your child's soul has been broken and how much this affects your whole life and your own family. Unfortunately, there is a lot in our society is based on this. The functioning human being is still in the foreground. Our world is about all sorts of things but not really the essential things like attachment and needs. Actually, the current time is really exciting in this respect because it makes us confront ourselves."

"I moved to Dresden in August 2017. Originally I wanted to go to Leipzig, but for professional reasons, it ended up being Dresden - and I have to say that I find Dresden a whole lot nicer now. The advantages of a big city combined with the charm and tranquility of a small town is just perfect. At the moment, I am still a trainee myself as well as a representative for trainees and teenagers. Besides my traineeship, I am a wedding and event musician (www.zwischen-spiel.de). Every year we play at about forty weddings and other events. Unfortunately there are a lot of cancellations for the wedding season at the moment, which makes us a bit worried.

Playing at weddings is really wonderful. Since we usually stay at a wedding all day long, we get to know the guests and hosts well. Sometimes it gets really emotional for us as well. Being able to be with people on their most important day is the greatest gift for me. To see happy people everywhere makes you happy too.

Luckily we are not completely self-employed with the music - otherwise we would have quite a problem with the many cancellations. It is difficult because we lack the income to invest in instruments and technology due to the crisis. But I'm more worried about all the other service providers and colleagues who do it full-time and depend on the income. I hope that the government's help for the self-employed will arrive and work. If not, our cultural landscape will be different after the crisis - which would be fatal. I hope that the crisis will make the government realize how important the promotion of culture and cultural venues is. Because without culture our world is a different one.

And I hope that we can all learn something from the crisis, namely in areas of charity, solidarity, and the willingness to help."

Ich hoffe, diese Krise endet bald und alles wird wieder normal. Ich wÃ¼rde gerne heiraten. Ich liebe das Leben und ich mÃ¶chte Kinder haben. Die Religion ist mir egal, aber ich mÃ¶chte, dass meine Frau meine Sitten und GebrÃ¤uche kennen lernt.

"I am from Iraq, and I have been living in Dresden for 5 years. I wanted to be fashion designer, but unfortunately, I did not complete my studies because of the conditions in my country. I have been working in distribution for two years, and now I am at an Amazon warehouse. Itâs usually fun when everyone is working together and helping each other out, but sometimes I find it difficult, when I am tired or there is too much work or there arenât enough people working. Right now, a lot of people have taken leave until the Corona crisis ends. We have a different number of orders every day; these days, it's between 29 thousand and 46 thousand requests. That is a little above normal, but like I said, there are people on leaveâ¦

I hope this crisis ends soon, and everything gets back to normal. I would like to get married. I love life, and I want to have children. I donât care about religion, but I would like my wife to learn about my customs and traditions.

Meine Familie besteht aus vier Personen, ich, meine Frau Summer, mein Sohn Deea und meine Tochter Sana, die in Damaskus alleine lebt. Deaa ist 25 Jahre alt und Sana 22 Jahre.

Mein Sohn lebt in Dresden. Deaa ist 2015 mit mir nach Deutschland gekommen. Meine Frau ist erst seit einem Jahr hier. Deaa hat an der UniversitÃ¤t von Homs Musik studiert und meine Tochter an einem privaten Schauspielinstitut. Sie ist sehr talentiert und hat an einer Reihe von TheaterstÃ¼cken mitgewirkt.

Ich mache mir groÃe Sorgen wegen meiner Tochter, die neben Lupus hat auch unter einer Depression leidet. Ich schlafe schlecht. Wir als Familie befinden uns in einem Teufelskreis. Ich kann aus vielen GrÃ¼nden nicht zurÃ¼ckkehren und meine kranke Tochter kann nicht nach Deutschland kommen. Als ich eine Aufenthaltserlaubnis beantragt habe, war sie noch unter 18, aber als ich die Aufenthaltserlaubnis bekam und die FamilienzusammenfÃ¼hrung beantragen konnte, war sie schon 18 Jahre und 20 Tage alt. Ich habe Kontakt zu einer AnwÃ¤ltin, aber das Ergebnis ist bisher negativ. Wir warten auf die endgÃ¼ltige Entscheidung des Berliner Gerichts. Sana lebt allein in Damaskus ohne Familie.

Ich habe in meiner Wohnung ein Projekt gemacht. Es heiÃt Dialog-Salon. Wir haben uns mit Freunden verschiedener NationalitÃ¤ten getroffen und Ã¼ber Themen wie Integration, BeschÃ¤ftigungsmÃ¶glichkeiten, Rassismus und die Probleme der Radikalisierung von AuslÃ¤ndern und Deutschen gesprochen. Aber nachdem ich einen Arbeitsplatz gefunden hatte, hatten wir keine mehr Zeit mehr fÃ¼r die Treffen.

Ich leide unter einigen Problemen mit meinen Arbeitskollegen. Vielleicht aufgrund des kulturellen Unterschieds. Obwohl ich ein liberaler und marxistischer Intellektueller bin, bestehen einige leider auf der negativen Sicht auf mich als Orientale oder Muslim. Ich habe groÃe Anstrengungen unternommen, um die beiden Kulturen hier und auch bei mir zu Hause kennenzulernen. Leider habe ich aufgrund der NegativitÃ¤t, mit der ich konfrontiert war, einen toten Punkt erreicht."

"I am Mahmoud Hasan from Syria. I am 60 years old. I have been living in Germany for four years. I am a painter by profession. I work as a kitchen assistant. My family consists of four people, me, my wife Summer, my son Deea and my daughter Sana, who lives alone in Damascus. Deaa is 25 years old and Sana is 22.

My son lives in Dresden. Deaa came with me to Germany in 2015. My wife has only been here for one year. Deaa studied music at the University of Homs, and my daughter studied at a private acting institute. She is very talented and has participated in a number of plays.

I am very worried about my daughter, who suffers from lupus as well as depression. I sleep badly. We as a family are in a vicious circle. I cannot return for many reasons, and my sick daughter cannot come to Germany. When I applied for a residence permit, she was still under 18, but when I got the residence permit and could apply for family reunion, she was already 18 years and 20 days old. I am in contact with a lawyer, but the result is negative so far. We are waiting for the final decision of the Berlin court. Sana lives alone in Damascus without family.

I used to do a project in my apartment. It was called Dialogue Salon. We met with friends of different nationalities and talked about topics like integration, employment opportunities, racism and the problem of foreigners and Germans becoming radicalized. But after I found a job, we didn't have time for the meetings anymore.

I have some problems with my colleagues at work, maybe because of the cultural difference. Although I am liberal, Marxist intellectual, some of them insist on the negative view of me as an Oriental or Muslim unfortunately. I have made great efforts to get to know both cultures here and at home. Unfortunately, I have reached a dead end because of the negativity I have been confronted with."

"I am Mahmoud Hasan from Syria. I am 60 years old. I have been living in Germany for four years. I am a painter by profession. I work as a kitchen assistant. My family consists of four people, me, my wife Summer, my son Deea and my daughter Sana, who lives alone in Damascus. Deaa is 25 years old and Sana is 22.

My son lives in Dresden. Deaa came with me to Germany in 2015. My wife has only been here for one year. Deaa studied music at the University of Homs, and my daughter studied at a private acting institute. She is very talented and has participated in a number of plays.

I am very worried about my daughter, who suffers from lupus as well as depression. I sleep badly. We as a family are in a vicious circle. I cannot return for many reasons, and my sick daughter cannot come to Germany. When I applied for a residence permit, she was still under 18, but when I got the residence permit and could apply for family reunion, she was already 18 years and 20 days old. I am in contact with a lawyer, but the result is negative so far. We are waiting for the final decision of the Berlin court. Sana lives alone in Damascus without family.

I used to do a project in my apartment. It was called Dialogue Salon. We met with friends of different nationalities and talked about topics like integration, employment opportunities, racism and the problem of foreigners and Germans becoming radicalized. But after I found a job, we didn't have time for the meetings anymore.

I have some problems with my colleagues at work, maybe because of the cultural difference. Although I am liberal, Marxist intellectual, some of them insist on the negative view of me as an Oriental or Muslim unfortunately. I have made great efforts to get to know both cultures here and at home. Unfortunately, I have reached a dead end because of the negativity I have been confronted with."

"In 2015, I took up the idea of a friend of mine and looked into the possibility of working as a freelance funeral orator; I prefer the term "funeral speaker." He had proposed the idea to me about 2013, without me taking it seriously at that time. But it stuck. I researched what this activity involved and asked myself if I could trust myself to do it. At some point, the first request came, and apparently, I did not disappoint the family. My memorial speeches draw on the anecdotes and experiences people tell me. When the bereaved see them again in their minds, they usually smile - despite their grief. To see this and to be allowed to experience it together with them touches me deeply; it is meaningful for me personally.

What I definitely do differently than my colleagues is that I never have more than one appointment a day. I stay at the cemetery until I have the impression that I am no longer needed. Even the preliminary talks have no time limit. The longest interview lasted about three hours: The widow had nursed her husband for a long time and now didn't know what she should do all day. We then explored together what brought her joy in the past and what she could still do today. In retrospect, the long conversation with that lady probably also led to the decision to get involved in the crisis intervention/emergency pastoral care team.

Ultimately, however, I do not treat psychological disorders or illnesses, but offer my help to people in exceptional situations. In this respect I can be called a "pastor." As a humanist, I donât believe the "soul" is supernatural. It is rather an open term for the totality of a person, his personality in a given situation. Most people "in the east" derive their values from the virtues that were already cultivated by the ancient Greeks without the Bible: Righteousness, helpfulness, enjoyment - i.e. love for your neighbor and yourself. We act morally and do not need to be obliged to do so by means of a "Holy Book," the threat of hell or the prospect of reward in the form of a promise of paradise. And we have just as much a right to professional care when we need and want it.

As President of the Humanist Association of Dresden, I am committed, among other things, to ensuring that there are also humanist pastors* in hospitals and prisons. Also we want to make sure there is a subject like "Humanistic Life Science" based on our world view available. We want to show how rules and values can and have changed, and that it is people who negotiate these norms with each other - ideally for the benefit of all. In this subject, it would not be a government agency that determines the content, but us. The mechanisms of evolution, for example, would also be included in primary school. And getting to know ourselves would take up a lot of space in our lessons. The head of a primary school in FÃ¼rth outlines how this could look like here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTp5eJl9w8I

The danger of infection at the moment should not be taken lightly. And nobody should try to profit from the current situation - neither politically nor commercially. What can help now? In our crowded coexistence, humour helps, but weighing every word does not. As long as you don't endanger yourself and others, soak up the sun; otherwise, follow the advice of the Robert Koch Institute!

Unfortunately, personal strategies for crises are not learned in such a crisis but often afterwards - through self-reflection: What is good for me, what do I need, what can I achieve, what overtaxes me, how can I recognize when I am overwhelmed? Do I need rest, do I need conversations, do I need a warm sofa with a blanket or do I prefer sports? In this way, there is also a connection to the people who have lost someone. Knowing oneself is a basic requirement for a successful life and for a successful togetherness - socially as well as professionally and in partnership. In addition, you must be extremely reticent about drawing conclusions about others. I, for example, wouldnât know how to begin with sports, but I don't deny that other people can find happiness and fun in them. I need a lot of time in seclusion; it would drive others crazy to be alone with their thoughts too often. People are different - it sounds so flat and banal that you want to roll your eyes. And yet, when you think it through, it means a lot.

And in terms of the future... Strange as it may sound, but of all things a satirical show, the heute-show, managed a very accurate "short analysis": Among other things, it has now become clear that it does not make sense to cut down on nursing staff (hospitals, outpatient services, nursing homes) for reasons of cost or profit, and we can see how important well-functioning channelsinformation are (internet access, modern conditions for teaching and learning). All that "left-wing talk"! None of it is new, but politically speaking, it is not "sexy" yet."

"When I was sixteen, I trained to be a cake maker in Dresden. Since the age of nineteen I have been baking in our hundred-year-old family business. Since three out of four people in the bakery were cake and pastry makers at that time, I turned to the bread making trade and found my passion in it. At the age of twenty-six, I took over the bakery from my father and have been running the business ever since.

It was also during this time that I made the big decision to ban all pre-made mixes and miracle powders from the bakery. This "small" project kept me busy for the next eight years. In order to successfully keep a small bakery going, it was necessary to produce eye-catching baked goods. So black baguettes and colorful breads are part of our everyday life. Chile and garlic in large quantities are a welcome change that helps us to bake bread that tastes especially good. Olive breads with almost thirty percent Kalamata olives and without baking yeast correspond to my standard of everyday luxury.

I have been coming to Dresden regularly for a long time. It started with the annual bread market, continued with trade fairs and the collaboration with Dresden caterers. Since August of last year, I have been a weekly visitor to the market in the Neustadt with bread and rolls.

Last year we won the Saxon environmental protection prize for our commitment to ancient grain. Even as a small bakery, we like to contribute our share to environmental protection. And if that also succeeds regionally, then it is doubly nice.

Three years ago I started to take an interest in ancient grain because I was looking for a path between organic and conventional farming. The old grains do not need irrigation and hardly need any fertilizer. My focus is not on the very old varieties like emmer and einkorn, but on "normal" varieties. 
Dickkopfweizen and Champagnerroggen are the traditional grains of the Lausitz. They tolerate our sandy dry soils wonderfully. Unfortunately, they were replaced at the beginning of the 19th century by over-bred hybrid cereals, as these give a higher yield and produce less waste (straw). The latter reason, however, is outdated. Straw is biomass and can be converted into energy today, without having to farm the whole area just for biodiesel.
You won't find any of my breads that hasn't been rise for at least twenty-four hours. Forty-eight hours, is increasingly becoming the norm. The advantage is that these breads and baguettes are more digestible for humans. Many people who suffer from irritable bowel or flatulence can tolerate my breads. Sometimes you should just let nature do its work and make time the most important ingredient.

I don't think that you can run a bakery successfully today with just the classic German bread culture -- just the fact that in German bakeries one usually only thinks of rye when you speak of sourdough. In Italy, it is called "Lievito Madre" which literally translates as mother yeast. The influences of "foreign" baking cultures have enriched our variety of products and thus the spectrum of enjoyment. My madre, her name is Vanessa by the way, has greatly changed my baking and, above all, slowed it down. The breads with Vanessa are different, unusual, aromatic, light with a dark crust... And yet I would never say that the southern way of baking is better. It is different. Likewise, I also love a really strong rye bread. The most important thing remains that bread does not come from a baking mixture but is made with love and skill."

"I was born in Lutherstadt Wittenberg in the last millennium. I trained for a normal job in the chemical industry and studied culture and art at the Humboldt University. Of course, I properly completed my studies. In 1984, I moved to Dresden because of love. And stayed. After the reunification, I started working as an editor at a private radio (today Hitradio RTL) and then at the private SACHSEN TV in front and behind the camera, then freelance as a lecturer and writer for newspapers and books.

I write (of course from home). Sometimes for the Neustadt GeflÃ¼ster, sometimes on a book. Itâs a Dresden theme from the era of 100 years ago. "Showcase Dresden â between Foot Sweat and Shaved Heads,â of course with illustrations. It will be published by Alwis-Verlag Dresden in the next few days, and then I'll be talking (remotely), at literature readings in the Neustadt.

I experienced the reunification period in Dresden as many did: I was uncertain what would happen; what will become of my job? Politically, I was torn back and forth. I was not a rebel or in the resistance. Even during the GDR era, I briefly switched to the restaurant business. My first working day was January 2, 1990 as a qualified dishwasher and then I was waiter until September 1990. I don't feel like a âreunification victim." On the contrary. The years following were adventurous for me. I encountered a lot of new things and fell on my face. Ups and downs pervaded my life from then on. âBroken biographyâ is a common saying. Looking back I can say, I had many experiences, a rich life, sometimes angry, mostly good.

I had the urge to write even at school. It started with funny, quick poems, which I (not always to the delight of the teachers) sent around the class during the lessons. There were long "dry spells" that challenged me professionally. I shifted to journalistic texts and moderation for newspapers, radio and television. I wrote my first novel "Visitor" over six years with interruptions. I self-published it in 2017, and since 2011, I have published short stories in various anthologies with different publishers. In between, I have produced new texts of different genres for readings at "TresenLesen" in CafÃ© 100, in the Sankt-Pauli-Salon, in the atmosphere of Hole of Fame and at the "Kaffeeklatsch" in Valentino. And now the first volume of "Showcase Dresden" at Alwis-Verlag. A volume will follow every year. And then the online magazine NEUSTADT-GEFLÃSTER publishes a weekly story by me. I really have a lot to do. I like to write with a touch of satire, irony and humour, so not "deadly serious."

My book is about the time before the First World War. Dresden prospered and became one of the most important cultural cities in the world. It was a great place to live. And no one suspected that it wouldn't go on forever. The starting point for the stories was a historical series "Dresden 100 years ago," which I wrote between 2008 and 2012 for the DRESDNER NEUESTEN NACHRICHTEN. I was in search of the "soul of the people of Dresden;" I wanted to find out why they are the way they are. I have been searching for that ever since. As far as the soul is concerned, I don't mean the theological one. Per definition, one cannot grasp it precisely (like the theological one as well). But in my discoveries and my digging in history and in everyday life, I have gotten a little bit on the track of it. I think this is very important if you want to understand the mentality of the people here. I see a problem with the failure of the application for the European Capital of Culture 2025 precisely in this. In the application, I didnât see the "soul of Dresden." And this soul is also needed in shaping the future of the cityscape, in architecture, in cultural life.

Somehow, I had a vague hunch that the decades of the 21st century would also mark an end, like the decades of the 20th century. I just did not know what was coming. And now we have the caesura. The caesura at the beginning of 20th century, in the years after 1910, was the First World War. Today, we have a different caesura. A mixture of problems of globalization, climate change, the search for ways out of social crises has piled up. This could not go on forever. And nature has created the break - with a virus. 100 years ago, there was something similar - the Spanish flu. The First World War pushed it into the background. It caused 40 million deaths worldwide. And this is a watershed that will bring about huge changes. I don't mean this esoterically, and I'm not a psychic. It's just a hunch. It's fuelling a lot of uncertainty and anxiety. I feel the increasing fear around me. I feel the insecurities, the farewell to the old and the familiar. I see some things being destroyed. Here and there, seeds of something new are sprouting. I wonder if they can flourish. I don't know where the journey will lead, but I am curious. It will be exciting. I think that many people who experienced the reunification here in the East with all its upheavals will have a dÃ©jÃ  vu experience. It will again be about existential issues, about job losses, about adjusting to a lot of new things. I hope that people in this country will come to terms with it better."

"I was born in Lutherstadt Wittenberg in the last millennium. I trained for a normal job in the chemical industry and studied culture and art at the Humboldt University. Of course, I properly completed my studies. In 1984, I moved to Dresden because of love. And stayed. After the reunification, I started working as an editor at a private radio (today Hitradio RTL) and then at the private SACHSEN TV in front and behind the camera, then freelance as a lecturer and writer for newspapers and books.

I write (of course from home). Sometimes for the Neustadt GeflÃ¼ster, sometimes on a book. Itâs a Dresden theme from the era of 100 years ago. "Showcase Dresden â between Foot Sweat and Shaved Heads,â of course with illustrations. It will be published by Alwis-Verlag Dresden in the next few days, and then I'll be talking (remotely), at literature readings in the Neustadt.

I experienced the reunification period in Dresden as many did: I was uncertain what would happen; what will become of my job? Politically, I was torn back and forth. I was not a rebel or in the resistance. Even during the GDR era, I briefly switched to the restaurant business. My first working day was January 2, 1990 as a qualified dishwasher and then I was waiter until September 1990. I don't feel like a âreunification victim." On the contrary. The years following were adventurous for me. I encountered a lot of new things and fell on my face. Ups and downs pervaded my life from then on. âBroken biographyâ is a common saying. Looking back I can say, I had many experiences, a rich life, sometimes angry, mostly good.

I had the urge to write even at school. It started with funny, quick poems, which I (not always to the delight of the teachers) sent around the class during the lessons. There were long "dry spells" that challenged me professionally. I shifted to journalistic texts and moderation for newspapers, radio and television. I wrote my first novel "Visitor" over six years with interruptions. I self-published it in 2017, and since 2011, I have published short stories in various anthologies with different publishers. In between, I have produced new texts of different genres for readings at "TresenLesen" in CafÃ© 100, in the Sankt-Pauli-Salon, in the atmosphere of Hole of Fame and at the "Kaffeeklatsch" in Valentino. And now the first volume of "Showcase Dresden" at Alwis-Verlag. A volume will follow every year. And then the online magazine NEUSTADT-GEFLÃSTER publishes a weekly story by me. I really have a lot to do. I like to write with a touch of satire, irony and humour, so not "deadly serious."

My book is about the time before the First World War. Dresden prospered and became one of the most important cultural cities in the world. It was a great place to live. And no one suspected that it wouldn't go on forever. The starting point for the stories was a historical series "Dresden 100 years ago," which I wrote between 2008 and 2012 for the DRESDNER NEUESTEN NACHRICHTEN. I was in search of the "soul of the people of Dresden;" I wanted to find out why they are the way they are. I have been searching for that ever since. As far as the soul is concerned, I don't mean the theological one. Per definition, one cannot grasp it precisely (like the theological one as well). But in my discoveries and my digging in history and in everyday life, I have gotten a little bit on the track of it. I think this is very important if you want to understand the mentality of the people here. I see a problem with the failure of the application for the European Capital of Culture 2025 precisely in this. In the application, I didnât see the "soul of Dresden." And this soul is also needed in shaping the future of the cityscape, in architecture, in cultural life.

Somehow, I had a vague hunch that the decades of the 21st century would also mark an end, like the decades of the 20th century. I just did not know what was coming. And now we have the caesura. The caesura at the beginning of 20th century, in the years after 1910, was the First World War. Today, we have a different caesura. A mixture of problems of globalization, climate change, the search for ways out of social crises has piled up. This could not go on forever. And nature has created the break - with a virus. 100 years ago, there was something similar - the Spanish flu. The First World War pushed it into the background. It caused 40 million deaths worldwide. And this is a watershed that will bring about huge changes. I don't mean this esoterically, and I'm not a psychic. It's just a hunch. It's fuelling a lot of uncertainty and anxiety. I feel the increasing fear around me. I feel the insecurities, the farewell to the old and the familiar. I see some things being destroyed. Here and there, seeds of something new are sprouting. I wonder if they can flourish. I don't know where the journey will lead, but I am curious. It will be exciting. I think that many people who experienced the reunification here in the East with all its upheavals will have a dÃ©jÃ  vu experience. It will again be about existential issues, about job losses, about adjusting to a lot of new things. I hope that people in this country will come to terms with it better."

"Apart from all the negative and restrictive things that are going on right now, I also see a lot of opportunities for the individual and families and society as a whole. And from this we should draw conclusions and finally introduce a basic income, for example. Or the subject of school and assignments and compulsory schooling â viewing it in a way that that you don't take the guidelines more seriously than what is going on right now, namely dealing with the situation, accepting yourself with your feelings, looking deeper.

I think it is important to name things, to show yourself, to talk about things, because not everybody everywhere has insight. I have health problems myself ,and the internet is very important for me. Even if strength and financial means are not enough for the "normal" world, I can maintain contacts, find information and have a space for my interests in the internet. I can write here and show things and reach some people. For that reason, not much has changed in my everyday life. At the moment I have a lot to do with bureaucratic matters, which is always very stressful, and even more so in such times. And now my few important appointments outside my house are cancelled.

I very much hope that this time will be used as an opportunity. In any case, I will not get bored. Rather, I hope that I can rest a little. I hope that everyone looks after him or herself and his/her environment and that we all make the best of what is happening now. Overcoming trauma means finding new ways and new strategies in problematic and triggering events. And thatâs how you can have new experiences, realize that you have self-efficacy and can change things and learn."

"I lived in Dresden from 1981 until the end of 2019. I trained as a waitress here. My two children, who were born here, are now grown up. Until my accident in 2018, I enjoyed classical ballet very much and was involved with "BÃ¼hne Frei." Dresden has always been my dream city. As a little girl, I wanted to live here, and I got my wish.

It was not until I was 42 that I fulfilled my dream of doing ballet. I actually only wanted to buy some toe shoes as decoration. The owner of the ballet shop asked me if I wanted to do to try dance as a hobby and recommended a ballet studio. She herself was a dancer at the Semper Opera House, and we have been friends ever since. I took a trial lesson and stuck with it. It was difficult, but it was a childhood dream, and so it was great fun from the beginning, despite the sore muscles. But I am also very flexible, so that was an advantage.

In 2018, I slipped in the hallway at home, flew against a door frame and broke my upper arm twice. It is now wired, screwed and has a long nail in it. That was the end of my hobby.

I left Dresden because of love. Because of the accident and my ex-husband, the decision to move was relatively easy for me, even if my children had to look for their own apartments, and we are now 450 km apart. I miss my children and friends and the historical Dresden. I didn't like the expansion so much; the Prager StraÃe, in particular, is totally built up and you can't breathe, as opposed to how it was the past.

I came to "BÃ¼hne Frei" through my daughter Vivian. Since I like baking, she asked me if I would like to do something for the group, which I thought was great because I wanted to volunteer somewhere. I also used to work as a waitress. So it turned out that I made food for the group with homemade muffins, cookies and cheese sticks - depending on the season and mood. I did it enthusiastically for four years. I think volunteering is very important, and I would do it again anytime, no matter what. Without volunteers many things would not work, especially associations.

I am now taking care of my boyfriend's children, who are seventeen and eight years old. I am doing a lot of schoolwork with the little one, while the older one is learning independently through an online portal. The older one is overburdened with tasks. Itâs going great with the little one, but I also have strong nerves. I come from a big family - that shaped me. In terms of the future, I want to be happy with my new husband in my new home for the rest of my life."

Until my accident in 2018, I enjoyed classical ballet very much and was involved with "BÃ¼hne Frei." Dresden has always been my dream city. As a little girl, I wanted to live here, and I got my wish.

It was not until I was 42 that I fulfilled my dream of doing ballet. I actually only wanted to buy some toe shoes as decoration. The owner of the ballet shop asked me if I wanted to do to try dance as a hobby and recommended a ballet studio. She herself was a dancer at the Semper Opera House, and we have been friends ever since. I took a trial lesson and stuck with it. It was difficult, but it was a childhood dream, and so it was great fun from the beginning, despite the sore muscles. But I am also very flexible, so that was an advantage.

In 2018, I slipped in the hallway at home, flew against a door frame and broke my upper arm twice. It is now wired, screwed and has a long nail in it. That was the end of my hobby.

I left Dresden because of love. Because of the accident and my ex-husband, the decision to move was relatively easy for me, even if my children had to look for their own apartments, and we are now 450 km apart. I miss my children and friends and the historical Dresden. I didn't like the expansion so much; the Prager StraÃe, in particular, is totally built up and you can't breathe, as opposed to how it was the past.

I came to "BÃ¼hne Frei" through my daughter Vivian. Since I like baking, she asked me if I would like to do something for the group, which I thought was great because I wanted to volunteer somewhere. I also used to work as a waitress. So it turned out that I made food for the group with homemade muffins, cookies and cheese sticks - depending on the season and mood. I did it enthusiastically for four years. I think volunteering is very important, and I would do it again anytime, no matter what. Without volunteers many things would not work, especially associations.

I am now taking care of my boyfriend's children, who are seventeen and eight years old. I am doing a lot of schoolwork with the little one, while the older one is learning independently through an online portal. The older one is overburdened with tasks. Itâs going great with the little one, but I also have strong nerves. I come from a big family - that shaped me. In terms of the future, I want to be happy with my new husband in my new home for the rest of my life."

"I moved from Austria to Dresden in 2017. I studied classical singing and teaching at the UniversitÃ¤t Mozarteum in Salzburg, and now I am continuing my studies at the Hochschule fÃ¼r Musik Dresden. We moved because life in Austria has simply become too expensive. Here it is easier to live as a student with a family. My son quickly made friends here and feels very comfortable.

Financially, it is much easier here. Artistically, I was very surprised how quickly you get to know people. After a few weeks at the university, I was immediately connected to Ballroom Studios, which opened up a few opportunities for me. There are also a lot of possibilities interact other musicians at open stages and sessions.

Salzburg is a very "classical" city. Pop music is virtually non-existent. The music scene here is much more diverse; I can sing classical music as well as put together my own band project. My band is called Sinnpathie. We play Austrian and German pop songs. The songs I write are somewhat deep. I try to process my life in them.

In Salzburg I was a "classical idiot" with blinkers on, but I always felt restricted in classical singing. For me, there is no "right" or "wrong" in music, but in classical music it has to be one way or another so that it is "beautiful" or "good." In pop music, I can decide for myself what I consider beautiful. Everything is allowed. I was never the greatest fan of the piano either, but learning about pop music has opened doors for me. All of a sudden, I was able to accompany myself, and that's how I came to songwriting.

I have been struggling with my psyche since childhood. I have a serious mental disorder that has affected my life quite a bit. To put everything that goes on in my head into songs helps me a lot. It is often about being free and flying, running away, but also about things that people say to me and that occupy me. For example, I have written one or two songs about the stories that my refugee friends told me.

I believe that music helps us build empathy. I think it works best when the audience is involved. Making music together helps to strengthen cohesion enormously. I notice that especially at school, where I work as a substitute teacher. A common musical project and fun making music can work wonders.
At the moment, I am trying to make it as nice as possible for myself and my family at home. We are lucky to be able to work from home. As terrible as it is at the moment, we try to make the best of it. For us, that means a lot of time together, finally time for things for which there is very little time otherwise - jogging, making music together casually, reading books.

I am also writing my final thesis at the HfM about the cultural self-concept of refugees in multicultural music projects. I am still pretty much at the beginning. In Salzburg, I conducted a choir for refugees, migrants and Austrians with some colleagues. Sprich fÃ¼r jeden, der mÃ¶chte (Speak for everyone who wants to). It was an unbelievable experience, I met an incredible number of interesting people. I took the opportunity to make a study about the choir. I am now expanding on that and interviewing members of five choirs and music groups to explore how effective making music is in terms of integration, cultural self-perception, and language acquisition. "Cultural self-image" basically means that each person is not the product of a single culture. In the course of one's life, one automatically comes into contact with different cultures. This approach describes that these encounters with other cultures lead to a broadening of cultural understanding, i.e. theoretically that the more contact a person has with other cultures, the more he or she absorbs "foreign" ways of thinking and thus the more his or her cultural horizon is broadened."

"I am from Zwickau, but I have been living in Dresden for ten years in a wonderful flat share. Actually my plan was to study here and then move on to see other places in the world. But Dresden didn't let me go. I like the contrasts. If you walk through the Neustadt with one tourist, walk through the Altstadt with another and have them talk to each other in the evening, they wouldn't believe they'd been in the same city. I would like to visit the other places with a camper someday -- the dream of the mobile office that so many people dream of. Actually, everything is working out. I have my own one-man company, I'm unattached, and I have a project, which would allow me to achieve my dream.

People today think that whereas the bad things, which happen in the world are bad, they are not going to happen in Europe. Now they are. I always thought that I was well informed and objective and that I could correctly assess the general situation in the world. The silly summer topics come up just as reliably as the disease warnings in the spring. Attention! Swine flu, bird flu, normal flu, H1N1, coronavirus. Pure scare tactics. Or so I thought. Now I realize how naive that was.

When I read the news on Thursday before last, I began to understand that there will soon be a lockdown in Germany too. My first thought was: I still have to buy new reeds for my saxophone. I always do that in the Neustadt at a small music shop. Friday I had no time for it. I couldn't get there. Then I'll have to buy online at the big A. Stupid. If it goes on for 1-2 months, the shop will probably go bankrupt. Very stupid. The question of who else will go broke turned into the question of who will survive this time. I felt in that moment that we are all being called upon now to keep our way of life going.

One often forgets the "I" in a "we". I did not want to do that this time. So I called STRIKE.DESIGN on Friday and presented my idea: With the lockdown in place, a lot of stores will be closing. But picking up stuff at the store and online shopping in general is still possible. So what's missing is a platform that allows shops to set up an online shop quickly and easily and offers the customer the comfort they are used to. Matthias, the head of STRIKE.DESIGN, liked the idea. I created a plan on Friday and on Saturday we agreed to turn the idea into reality. http://www.xn--dresdner-lden-kfb.de/ was born.

Agile management is a much hated topic among business consultants. Nobody knows what it means, but one aspect is definitely a "learning" from every project or problem. So here is my very personal learning: There are an incredible number of great, nice, helpful, selfless, smart and committed people in Dresden and the surrounding area! I only told a few people about http://www.xn--dresdner-lden-kfb.de/ and now I have a team of about 25 people working on it. Free of charge. Because "we think it's good", "I can solve this" and "invite me for a beer when this is over". You guys are awesome!"

"I am from Zwickau, but I have been living in Dresden for ten years in a wonderful flat share. Actually my plan was to study here and then move on to see other places in the world. But Dresden didn't let me go. I like the contrasts. If you walk through the Neustadt with one tourist, walk through the Altstadt with another and have them talk to each other in the evening, they wouldn't believe they'd been in the same city. I would like to visit the other places with a camper someday -- the dream of the mobile office that so many people dream of. Actually, everything is working out. I have my own one-man company, I'm unattached, and I have a project, which would allow me to achieve my dream.

People today think that whereas the bad things, which happen in the world are bad, they are not going to happen in Europe. Now they are. I always thought that I was well informed and objective and that I could correctly assess the general situation in the world. The silly summer topics come up just as reliably as the disease warnings in the spring. Attention! Swine flu, bird flu, normal flu, H1N1, coronavirus. Pure scare tactics. Or so I thought. Now I realize how naive that was.

When I read the news on Thursday before last, I began to understand that there will soon be a lockdown in Germany too. My first thought was: I still have to buy new reeds for my saxophone. I always do that in the Neustadt at a small music shop. Friday I had no time for it. I couldn't get there. Then I'll have to buy online at the big A. Stupid. If it goes on for 1-2 months, the shop will probably go bankrupt. Very stupid. The question of who else will go broke turned into the question of who will survive this time. I felt in that moment that we are all being called upon now to keep our way of life going.

"I am eighteen years old and at the moment I am finishing high school. Besides school, I am also active in various groups, and I am a passionate recorder player. I play in a small band with which I play street music. Apart from that I am also Larper (live role playing), but unfortunately all these events were cancelled until summer. You can imagine Larp as a computer game, in which you slip into a character and really embody it; it's often a mixture of improv theatre and any other genre. On the one hand, it fulfills this dream of being the hero or immersing oneself in a fantasy world. On the other hand, it's a way to try it out and slip into different roles without having to be in the theater. But the experience of the stories is also wonderful. It's like reading a book and being in the middle of it.

After graduating from high school, I plan to do a volunteer year and then an apprenticeship, preferably in an artistic field. Also I want my volunteer year to be preferably in an artistic field. I have applied for various positions in the fields of technology and theater pedagogy. I am especially interested in technology in the theater and on stage in general, i.e. lighting, sound and special effects. I was very impressed by the stage when I acted in Tschick at the LandesbÃ¼hnen Sachsen. The stage set was painted with fluorescent paint and lit up under black light. It's actually quite simple but still impressive. I hope to get a more detailed insight into the work as an event technician.

It is very difficult at the moment, especially for artistic professions. Dresden's theaters are holding up well at the moment, and I think the media presence is great. Unfortunately, I don't know how things will continue. But I hope that the consequences of Corona will not be too great. But I am very sure that theatre will continue to exist, because we just love to see stories, and theater has a magic that you can't even find in film."

"Refugees often come from countries whose culture differs from that of Europe. Often these foreign cultures are also disparaged as inferior and less progressive, especially Islamic cultures, but this generalization is wrong; it is just a different culture and religion, which is simply different but nevertheless no less valuable.

A very important factor is the particular personal background of a person. The refugees who arrive in Germany often had to flee their homeland because they were persecuted and threatened there politically, religiously, ethnically and so on, and their livelihoods were destroyed. I think that this experience has an inconceivably formative influence on a person's personality and is therefore very important when dealing with refugees. However, it doesn't get enough attention that these people do not leave for Europe voluntarily, but because they were forced to. What they experienced before or during fleeing is difficult for us to imagine.

Despite this, there is a great deal of rejection of refugees in this country and in many other European states, and the reporting is therefore mostly very one-sided and negative. When people talk about waves of refugees, they are immediately associated with the threatening and impersonal, when we are actually talking about an incredible number of people with their own stories and identities. Unfortunately, they are all too often lumped together.
In order to change this, and to give young people the opportunity to get to know refugees and to learn more about them, " Witnesses of Flight," on whose Dresden board I have served since November, was founded as an anti-racist education campaign. We fulfill this mission by visiting interested schools and addressing the students directly. I myself first became aware of the topic at the age of about sixteen, when several refugees from Somalia who were my age started playing in my football club. Since then I have been concerned with such things and with "Witnesses of the Flight" in Dresden, I found a project whose aims I appreciate and one hundred percent support.

I would say that the exchange with refugees differs from the exchange with people from France, for example, in that although French people are also regarded by Germans as foreign in a way, the similarities are more pronounced and there is more of a feeling of being part of a common big whole. Refugees, on the other hand, are seen as very different and foreign, and this is unfortunately all too often equated with bad and inferior. You simply have far fewer points of reference to refugees, because - our lives are very differently, especially because of the flight and its causes. Often such people are also traumatized and do not want to talk about their experiences. Sometimes I have to be careful not to reduce refugees to their flight but to remember that although it is an important part of their story and their character, it is also only one facet, and that there is much more to every person.

All of our storytellers - that is what we call the refugees who talk about themselves during school visits and answer students' questions - naturally volunteer to participate and only tell what they want to tell. There is no compulsion at all, but many of them say afterwards that it does them good to talk openly about such things.

The refugees, who have been with us for some time, often bring friends and acquaintances with them who are also interested, so that our group has grown steadily. However, it is our goal to incorporate over more refugee women in order to give the stories another level and because schoolgirls might be able to identify with them even better. At the moment, however, all this is difficult because we cannot meet as a large group and cannot visit schools. But if you could imagine to join us, just contact us at dresden@zeugenderflucht.de. "

When people talk about waves of refugees, they are immediately associated with the threatening and impersonal, when we are actually talking about an incredible number of people with their own stories and identities. Unfortunately, they are all too often lumped together.
In order to change this, and to give young people the opportunity to get to know refugees and to learn more about them, " Witnesses of Flight," on whose Dresden board I have served since November, was founded as an anti-racist education campaign. We fulfill this mission by visiting interested schools and addressing the students directly. I myself first became aware of the topic at the age of about sixteen, when several refugees from Somalia who were my age started playing in my football club. Since then I have been concerned with such things and with "Witnesses of the Flight" in Dresden, I found a project whose aims I appreciate and one hundred percent support.

I would say that the exchange with refugees differs from the exchange with people from France, for example, in that although French people are also regarded by Germans as foreign in a way, the similarities are more pronounced and there is more of a feeling of being part of a common big whole. Refugees, on the other hand, are seen as very different and foreign, and this is unfortunately all too often equated with bad and inferior. You simply have far fewer points of reference to refugees, because - our lives are very differently, especially because of the flight and its causes. Often such people are also traumatized and do not want to talk about their experiences. Sometimes I have to be careful not to reduce refugees to their flight but to remember that although it is an important part of their story and their character, it is also only one facet, and that there is much more to every person.

All of our storytellers - that is what we call the refugees who talk about themselves during school visits and answer students' questions - naturally volunteer to participate and only tell what they want to tell. There is no compulsion at all, but many of them say afterwards that it does them good to talk openly about such things.

The refugees, who have been with us for some time, often bring friends and acquaintances with them who are also interested, so that our group has grown steadily. However, it is our goal to incorporate over more refugee women in order to give the stories another level and because schoolgirls might be able to identify with them even better. At the moment, however, all this is difficult because we cannot meet as a large group and cannot visit schools. But if you could imagine to join us, just contact us at dresden@zeugenderflucht.de. "

Together with my team of doctors, psychologists and physiotherapists, we want to alleviate the pain of our patients and improve their quality of life. It simply bored me to know that after school comes work, salary, strike, a little more salary - and sometime retirement. It's so predetermined. I just wanted to take the risk and think: Someone just has to really like you once and you've done it, then you'll have everything that others dream of. Then, and only then, can I be really free. I can even create and not just function. It was crippling and dissatisfying. I think I also find it difficult to simply carry out tasks that I am "ordered" to do without thinking about optimization. I want to optimize and implement, I can only do that if I make decisions for myself and don't let others decide.

In the last year and a half, I have sensed a certain resentment and insecurity, now even more insecurity due to Corona. I understand that, a lot has changed and a lot will change in the time to come. But fear is always a bad advisor and paralyzes creative ideas and good actions. I know Dresden as cosmopolitan, creative and just "moving". I wish that we all had less fear and reacted less out of fear and instead that we acted and decided more for ourselves and implemented and lived out our creative ideas and thoughts. Talking to each other, approaching each other, not being afraid that someone takes something away from you, but recognizing possibilities, going down new paths. Building and creating something. Have courage in these difficult times, now more than ever. Go out into the world and have fun and enjoy life."
