"I am 31. I was born in Dresden, but I grew up near Bautzen, and have lived in Dresden again since 2007. I work as a nurse with a specialization in palliative care on a palliative ward in a hospital. This is an acute ward for palliative care patients with heavy symptom load, which can only be treated as inpatient. The aim is always to discharge them, but due to severe oncological diseases, about fifty percent die in our hospital. Nevertheless, we are not a terminal ward. This is often also a misunderstanding in society.

I am currently studying practice development in nursing care with nursing science and ethical aspects, vocationally The academic recognition of my profession is very important to me, as is the ethical and reflective approach to my work. That is why I feel very comfortable working with palliative patients and think it's essential to direct society's attention to this area of life. I am a volunteer with the crisis intervention team, but due to my studies my involvement has unfortunately been somewhat delayed.

It is very important to me to rethink how people deal with transitoriness and grief in many phases of life. I think that the health care system is increasingly turning to an economic idea instead of a moral one. We are losing touch with ethically justifiable decisions. There are, for example, patients who are operated on because of an oncological disease, who in total spend perhaps a year in hospital and are thus "hospitalized", i.e. traumatized in a way. As a result, they are often no longer able to decide for themselves what is right or wrong with regard to therapies and so on. So I wonder which surgery would really benefit the patient. In short, I very often have the impression that medicine can start treatment well, but it doesn't know how to stop, and in my eyes, it ignores ethical boundaries because dying is not desirable. I am grateful that we have such modern intensive therapies, no question. But an integration of the palliative concept into the intensive care unit would ideal in accompanying a patient, even with a poor prognosis, in such a way that he is allowed to die and is not just kept alive.

The idea that a treatment will not be successful is often not considered. Knowledge about palliative medicine, for example, has been part of the curriculum since 2014, and it is hoped that the "new" generation of doctors will bring about a change, just like the trainees and students in nursing. I try to encourage the new generation to always question "Why do I want to do a particular intervention on patients? Am I doing it for me, so that I have a better feeling or for the patient?" That is essential! And that's how I see it with treatment approaches, and I also believe that my medical colleagues are often unable to let their patients die or that relatives want maximum therapy. This is completely understandable; nobody wants to let anybody go. That is our job in the health care system to deal with mortality in an enlightened and patient manner.

I have had some thoughts about Covid. First and foremost, I thought about palliative patients in the home, and how care is provided by the outpatient palliative teams there. I just hope that my colleagues will be able to work under those circumstances. But I also see the chance that the emergency services, general practitioners and may now be able to think carefully about which patients they need to refer to hospital, thus avoiding unnecessary hospital stays, which can often be very stressful mentally for the older patients I also hope, however, that despite Covid patients being ventilated, we will be able to maintain a reflective view of the purpose of intensive care measures. There is much talk about survival, of course. But people are also dying, it will continue to be unavoidable, and this should also be discussed. And age per se does not play a role here, I think.I would like to see honesty towards people instead of a universal "We must save everyone!"

My work is often about deceleration, enduring the things you can't change, and observing and supporting. And I would hope for that not only in palliative care but in general. And maybe there's some benefit in the Corona crisis as well. I am aware of that a lot of individuals, especially self-employed people, suffer in the crisis, and I do not want to neglect this. What I mean is a rethinking/questioning of what we really still need in society. There is nothing we can do about Corona, but we can decide how to deal with it. There is a little freedom in that."

Mir ist bewusst, dass der Krisenanteil vieler Einzelner, besonders selbststÃ¤ndiger Menschen sehr hoch ist, und ich mÃ¶chte das auch nicht negieren. Was ich meine ist ein Umdenken/Hinterfragen, was wir wirklich in der Gesellschaft noch brauchen. An Corona kÃ¶nnen wir nichts Ã¤ndern, aber wir kÃ¶nnen uns entscheiden, wie wir damit umgehen. Darin liegt auch ein bisschen Freiheit."

"I am 31. I was born in Dresden, but I grew up near Bautzen, and have lived in Dresden again since 2007. I work as a nurse with a specialization in palliative care on a palliative ward in a hospital. This is an acute ward for palliative care patients with heavy symptom load, which can only be treated as inpatient. The aim is always to discharge them, but due to severe oncological diseases, about fifty percent die in our hospital. Nevertheless, we are not a terminal ward. This is often also a misunderstanding in society.

I am currently studying practice development in nursing care with nursing science and ethical aspects, vocationally The academic recognition of my profession is very important to me, as is the ethical and reflective approach to my work. That is why I feel very comfortable working with palliative patients and think it's essential to direct society's attention to this area of life. I am a volunteer with the crisis intervention team, but due to my studies my involvement has unfortunately been somewhat delayed.

It is very important to me to rethink how people deal with transitoriness and grief in many phases of life. I think that the health care system is increasingly turning to an economic idea instead of a moral one. We are losing touch with ethically justifiable decisions. There are, for example, patients who are operated on because of an oncological disease, who in total spend perhaps a year in hospital and are thus "hospitalized", i.e. traumatized in a way. As a result, they are often no longer able to decide for themselves what is right or wrong with regard to therapies and so on. So I wonder which surgery would really benefit the patient. In short, I very often have the impression that medicine can start treatment well, but it doesn't know how to stop, and in my eyes, it ignores ethical boundaries because dying is not desirable. I am grateful that we have such modern intensive therapies, no question. But an integration of the palliative concept into the intensive care unit would ideal in accompanying a patient, even with a poor prognosis, in such a way that he is allowed to die and is not just kept alive.

The idea that a treatment will not be successful is often not considered. Knowledge about palliative medicine, for example, has been part of the curriculum since 2014, and it is hoped that the "new" generation of doctors will bring about a change, just like the trainees and students in nursing. I try to encourage the new generation to always question "Why do I want to do a particular intervention on patients? Am I doing it for me, so that I have a better feeling or for the patient?" That is essential! And that's how I see it with treatment approaches, and I also believe that my medical colleagues are often unable to let their patients die or that relatives want maximum therapy. This is completely understandable; nobody wants to let anybody go. That is our job in the health care system to deal with mortality in an enlightened and patient manner.

I have had some thoughts about Covid. First and foremost, I thought about palliative patients in the home, and how care is provided by the outpatient palliative teams there. I just hope that my colleagues will be able to work under those circumstances. But I also see the chance that the emergency services, general practitioners and may now be able to think carefully about which patients they need to refer to hospital, thus avoiding unnecessary hospital stays, which can often be very stressful mentally for the older patients I also hope, however, that despite Covid patients being ventilated, we will be able to maintain a reflective view of the purpose of intensive care measures. There is much talk about survival, of course. But people are also dying, it will continue to be unavoidable, and this should also be discussed. And age per se does not play a role here, I think.I would like to see honesty towards people instead of a universal "We must save everyone!"

My work is often about deceleration, enduring the things you can't change, and observing and supporting. And I would hope for that not only in palliative care but in general. And maybe there's some benefit in the Corona crisis as well. I am aware of that a lot of individuals, especially self-employed people, suffer in the crisis, and I do not want to neglect this. What I mean is a rethinking/questioning of what we really still need in society. There is nothing we can do about Corona, but we can decide how to deal with it. There is a little freedom in that."

Weil es schÃ¶n und lebenswert ist und vor allem weil ich viele nette Menschen kennengelernt habe, von denen ich mit einigen bis heute befreundet bin.

Der Geruch von Ofenheizungen, der in der Luft lag, half auch wenig. Ich hab fast geweint. SpÃ¤ter bin ich zur WG-Besichtigung in die Neustadt gefahren und das war die Offenbarung. Ich wusste, dass ich hier wÃ¼rde leben und glÃ¼cklich sein kÃ¶nnen. In Dresden passierte stÃ¤ndig was: LÃ¤den Ã¶ffneten und schlossen; man fuhr in den Semesterferien in die alte Heimat und wenn man nach vier bis sechs Wochen zurÃ¼ck kam, sah alles ganz anders aus. Meine Mutter ist eine Alt-68erin; eine sozialdemokratische Lehrerin, die unter einem CDU-Kultusminister arbeiten musste - der erste Politiker, dessen Name ich kannte, war Gerhard Meyer-Vorfelder, glaube ich. Und Herbert Wehner, weil wir ein Buch mit den besten Beschimpfungen aus Bundestagsreden hatten. Gemeinschaftskunde war immer mein Lieblingsfach in der Schule und ich habe dann ja auch Politikwissenschaft studiert. Zum ersten mal wÃ¤hlen konnte ich erst sehr spÃ¤t â zur Bundestagswahl 1998 mit zwanzig Jahren; und das war dann gleich eine historische Wahl. Die Parteien, die ich gewÃ¤hlt habe, konnten die erste rot-grÃ¼ne Bundesregierung bilden.

Politisch engagiert habe ich mich die meiste Zeit allerdings nicht parteipolitisch. Ich war in der SchÃ¼lermitverwaltung aktiv, spÃ¤ter in der studentischen Mitverwaltung, war GrÃ¼ndungsmitglied der Dresden Debating Union, habe die meines Wissens nicht mehr aktive Absolventeninitiative des Institituts fÃ¼r Politikwissenschaft mitgegrÃ¼ndet und war bei BÃ¼rger.Courage aktiv. Einer Partei beigetreten bin ich allerdings erst kurz vor meinem 40. Geburtstag. Nach der Bundestagswahl 2017 bin ich BÃ¼ndnis 90/Die GrÃ¼nen beigetreten und seitdem glÃ¼ckliche GrÃ¼ne. Eingetreten bin ich, weil mich das AfD-Ergebnis so schockiert hat. Ich bin ein groÃer Fan des Grundgesetzes und finde es absurd, dass Menschen sich Patrioten nennen, die die beste politische und rechtliche Ordnung, die Deutschland je hatte, ablehnen und lÃ¤cherlich machen. Ich denke, das ist tatsÃ¤chlich mein politischer Hauptantrieb, in meinem kleinen Sprengel meinen kleinen Beitrag fÃ¼r ein demokratisches, weltoffenes, freundliches, friedliches, lebens- und liebenswertes Miteinander leisten zu wollen.

Zur Kommunalwahl 2019 bin ich in Loschwitz bei der Wahl fÃ¼r den Stadtbezirksbeirat angetreten und knapp reingewÃ¤hlt worden. Es ist ganz schÃ¶n viel Arbeit â neben Vollzeitjob, zwei Kindern, Mann â macht aber auch viel SpaÃ. Wobei ich merke, dass ich da auch noch reinwachsen muss und noch viel Ã¼ber die MÃ¶glichkeiten lernen muss, die wir als RÃ¤t*innen haben oder eben nicht haben."

"I have been working from home for three weeks now with my husband and two children, a four-year-old and a seven-year-old. This is a challenge, but we realize that we are in a very luxurious, privileged situation. We both have jobs that can be done at least temporarily from home; we both don't have to fear losing our jobs or earning less as a result of the Corona pandemic; we have a large apartment and a garden by the house. Nevertheless, I notice that I, as a relatively sociable person, find it increasingly difficult to stay in the limited social space of the nuclear family. And of course video chats cannot solve this problem either.

In 1998, after my Abitur and FSJ, I moved from Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg to Dresden to study (political science, communication science and a few semesters of philosophy). Despite this, it played a role - actually, people in I kne went to Berlin or Freiburg to study. And then I got stuck here. Because it's beautiful and worth living here and above all because I met many nice people, some of whom I'm still friends with today.

The difference between the tidy little towns of Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg and Dresden was stark. I arrived on the first day - to enroll and look for an apartment share - having taken the night train to the main station and then I walked up the totally bumpy BergstraÃe. The smell of coal stove heaters in the air didn't help much either. I almost cried. Later I went to the Neustadt for a tour of an apartment share and that was the revelation. I knew that I would live here and be happy. The first apartment - on the ForstereistraÃe - was the same, even though my two boy roommates and I could not have been more different. In the second semester, I moved to the Bischofsweg with two friends. Another big difference from Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg was that Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg was so much more static - at least in my perception. In Dresden, things happened all the time --shops opened and closed; you went to home during the semester break and when you came back after four to six weeks, everything looked completely different. And everything was colorful, not only white or at most light yellow houses, but houses in all colors - and I love old brick buildings.

In the beginning, I also had my problems with the different mentalities, found people quite grumpy, especially in shops, and also had the odd experience of people saying: "Oh, I didn't think you were from the West! You are much too nice..." But from the very beginning, I met great people from all parts of Germany and found our different biographies - I was twelve at the time of reunification - exciting, especially because we had all ended up at the same point. How Chernobyl and especially the reunification period were perceived are good examples of the very different realities we had experienced.

I grew up in a politically interested household. My mother is an old-68er, a social democratic teacher who had to work under a CDU minister of culture - the first politician whose name I knew was Gerhard Meyer-Vorfelder, I think. And Herbert Wehner, because we had a book with the best insults from Bundestag speeches. Civics was always my favorite subject at school and then I studied political science. I was able to vote for the first time very late - when I was twenty in the 1998 Bundestag elections, and that was a historic election. The parties I elected were able to form the first red-green federal government.

Most of the time, however, I was not politically involved in party politics. I was active in the student co-administration, later in the student co-administration, was a founding member of the Dresden Debating Union, co-founded the graduate initiative of the Institute of Political Science, which to my knowledge is no longer active, and was active in BÃ¼rger.Courage. However, I only joined a party shortly before my 40th birthday. After the federal elections in 2017 I joined BÃ¼ndnis 90/Die GrÃ¼nen and since then I have been a happy Green. I joined because I was so shocked by the AfD results. I am a big fan of the German Constitution, and I find it absurd that there are people call themselves patriots who reject and ridicule the best political and legal order Germany has ever had. I think that this is really my main political motivation, to want to make my small contribution to a democratic, cosmopolitan, friendly, peaceful, liveable and lovable coexistence in my small district.

For the local elections in 2019 I competed in Loschwitz for the city council and was narrowly re-elected. It's a lot of work - besides full-time job, two children, husband - but it's also a lot of fun. But I realize that I have to grow into it and learn a lot about the opportunities that we as councillors do and don't have."

Wir suchen immer noch Leute, die gerne online (oder persÃ¶nlich mit 1,50 Meter Abstand) interviewt werden mÃ¶chten, aber in der Zwischenzeit mÃ¶chten wir euch ein paar Interviews mit Kleinunternehmern in Dresden vorstellen, die wir im Laufe der Jahre durchgefÃ¼hrt haben. Bitte unterstÃ¼tzt sie, indem ihr Geschenkgutscheine online kauft oder ihre GeschÃ¤fte besucht, sobald diese wieder geÃ¶ffnet sind.
--

We are still looking for people who would like to be interviewed online (or in person at distance of 1,5 meters), but in the meantime we would like to present some interviews with small business owners in Dresden that we have done over the years. Please support them by buying gift certificates online or actually going to their shops if they are open.

"Als wir das letzte Mal miteinander gesprochen haben, wollte ich einen KÃ¤sehandel erÃ¶ffnen. Ich wollte meinen eigenen KÃ¤se aus Biomilch produzieren. Aber das ist hygienerechtlich sehr kompliziert. Jetzt kaufe ich KÃ¤se im GroÃhandel und verkaufe hier Sandwiches. Ich habe hier auch etwas Neues fÃ¼r Dresden. Es heiÃt Sucok. Das ist Rindfleisch gewÃ¼rzt mit Knoblauch und ein bisschen Kartoffel. Viele sagen mir, dass das sehr lecker ist. Es gibt auch sÃ¼Ãe Sachen - Obstsalat mit arabischer Sahne, Honig und Pistazien und Obstcocktail. Bald mÃ¶chte ich auch Falafel herstellen.

Ich habe ein Jahr lang ein LadengeschÃ¤ft gesucht. Das ist schwierig in Deutschland, aber schlieÃlich hat es geklappt. FÃ¼r den ersten Monat lÃ¤uft es sehr gut. Ich baue das StÃ¼ck fÃ¼r StÃ¼ck auf. Es ist viel Arbeit mit den Formularen, aber ich habe es geschafft."
--
"When we spoke last time, I wanted to open a cheese store. I wanted to make my own cheese with organic milk. But it is very complicated in terms of hygiene law. Now, I buy cheese from a wholesaler and sell sandwiches here. I have something new for Dresden here. It's called Sucok. It is beef seasoned with garlic and a little potato. A lot of people tell me that it is very delicious. There are also sweet things -- fruit salad with Arab cream, honey, and pistachios and fruit cocktail. Soon, I want to start making falafel.

I looked for a store front business for a year. It is difficult in German, but finally, it worked out. For the first month, it's gone well. I am building it piece by piece. It is a lot of work with forms, but I have done it."

"I have lived here in Dresden for ten years. I have two children. Originally, I come from RÃ¼gen and grew up at the sea. It was a terrible childhood. I had to go the beach every day; I really suffered.

Because it was the reunification-upheaval period, I went directly into a training program in Nordfriesland after finishing school, and I trained to be a totally normal waiter. After that, I came into contact with wine pretty quickly and then moved around a lot â fifteen times in thirteen years. I tried to explore the world and get to know various businesses. Among other places, I lived in California for two years and then got my first relatively long employment; I lived for five years in Bergisch-Gladbach, near Cologne. There I tried to build my own wine statement, more or less, and fund myself. After the job there, I managed a wine wholesale business, and I noticed that I wasnât so fulfilled by commerce and that I would rather like to celebrate wine. Then we said that we would move one more time in order to give the family a home, and we chose Dresden as the most interesting and exciting city with the most potential for development at that point. I wanted to live out my dream of a wine bar here â my dream of a place where people like to come to drink wine. Thatâs why we came here in 2007, and weâve lived here since then.

Whereas with eating, you eat the meal and then there is little development within a short period of time, with wine, you can promote the development really strongly; you can develop yourself strongly. Thatâs whatâs exciting about it.

Itâs only hard for new customers to get in because there are these advance reservations for one, two, and three years in advance. I havenât not yet thought about moving into something bigger since the basic philosophy wasnât too make as much money as possibly, but to have as much contact with people as possible and guide them in their life in wine. The greatest piece of wine wisdom is that you have enjoy and that there are no rules. Instead you build the rules yourself at some point. You shouldnât fight for it in any case. Wine is something beautiful, and you should keep this beauty for yourself. You should first follow your own sensitivities before you subject yourself to some rules."

"Itâs hard, challenging, and wonderful to have a bookstore in the Neustadt. We have ambitious customers, and the market is difficult. With 15 years experience behind me, I am now very confident about what the next fifteen years will involve. BÃ¼chers Best has succeeded in the market. That, at least, is my experience. We have succeeded in making breaking down the border between buying and friendship and have created a kind of extended community. I feel sometimes like I am in a big family, anyway â only that I also get money.

There is a cat in this family. We are a team. Alone, I couldnât do it. The most formative and least hard-working part of this team is Miyamoto Musashi, who is named after a samurai but is more at home in an Oscar Wilde novel. We have him here for a lot of reasons, but mainly because we want to make the world a nicer place overall, and a cat is necessary for that. Everywhere where a cat settles is a harmonic place to work.

I come from Magdeburg, but I always wanted to live in Dresden. I live on the Elbe, and the other option was Hamburg, but I ended up in Dresden. I think the Elbe has its own spirit as a blue band. I have been here a long time. With multiple breaks, I have been here since 1987. At the time of the reunification, I moved to a rural commune with my long hair for five years, but then I came back here.

I didnât train to be a book seller. I trained to be a mechanical engineer. Then I studied cyber technology at the TU until the reunification â thatâs automation technology, section 9. Then I studied philosophy, political science, and the scholarship of editions in Leipzig.

The study of editions does have something to do with publishing books. I came to book selling like the virgin to children. I actually thought I would land in a publishing house. But in 1995 when I was finished, the German publishing landscape was flat, and there was nothing left to do other than start something yourself.

I did everything. I was a mover and a dry-waller; I even worked in the forest service. Then I was a gallerist for a long time; that was a really unlucrative profession. I founded a gallery in 1999, the Galerie Treibhaus. That existed for ten years â which was a big success for an independent gallery. And one of my artists worked in a book shop, which was in this space. It was a small bookshop that existed for two years. He said, âThe bookshop isnât doing well at all and is looking for a successor. Do you want to become a bookseller?â And that revealed to me for the first time that that would actually be the ideal place for me. It wasnât clear to me yet that a community would form then. The first three years were crazy. I was constantly thinking that I would have to close. Find your bill, I am just pretending to be a bookseller.

It all looked like a bookstore on the stage, but actually it didnât exist. I didnât study to be a bookseller, and I had to learn everything myself. They screwed with me a lot and I had to pay a lot of money to learn my lessons. In part, the publishers sent me all possible kinds of crap that then lay around in the back courtyard and was never sold. I had a case of pin-up calendars. I have no idea how I got them!

Just like in the textbooks, I landed on my feet after 1000 days. The 1000-day rule: If you do something for 1000 days, then suddenly a hobby becomes a business. You need naivety, engagement, and endurance. You arenât allowed to know everything required at the start. Itâs like a marathon; one step after the other. If I had known everything that was going to happen to me, I wouldnât have dared to do it, I have to say. Luckily, I was very ignorant. And then you just canât stop running, like in a marathon. Just keep going. After three years, I had so many phases in which I thought, âShit, tomorrow, I have to quit and shut the doors,â but then came the next day, and I knew that something would happen, and it would go on. It always goes on. I am very optimistic. "

"Itâs hard, challenging, and wonderful to have a bookstore in the Neustadt. We have ambitious customers, and the market is difficult. With 15 years experience behind me, I am now very confident about what the next fifteen years will involve. BÃ¼chers Best has succeeded in the market. That, at least, is my experience. We have succeeded in making breaking down the border between buying and friendship and have created a kind of extended community. I feel sometimes like I am in a big family, anyway â only that I also get money.

There is a cat in this family. We are a team. Alone, I couldnât do it. The most formative and least hard-working part of this team is Miyamoto Musashi, who is named after a samurai but is more at home in an Oscar Wilde novel. We have him here for a lot of reasons, but mainly because we want to make the world a nicer place overall, and a cat is necessary for that. Everywhere where a cat settles is a harmonic place to work.

I come from Magdeburg, but I always wanted to live in Dresden. I live on the Elbe, and the other option was Hamburg, but I ended up in Dresden. I think the Elbe has its own spirit as a blue band. I have been here a long time. With multiple breaks, I have been here since 1987. At the time of the reunification, I moved to a rural commune with my long hair for five years, but then I came back here.

I didnât train to be a book seller. I trained to be a mechanical engineer. Then I studied cyber technology at the TU until the reunification â thatâs automation technology, section 9. Then I studied philosophy, political science, and the scholarship of editions in Leipzig.

The study of editions does have something to do with publishing books. I came to book selling like the virgin to children. I actually thought I would land in a publishing house. But in 1995 when I was finished, the German publishing landscape was flat, and there was nothing left to do other than start something yourself.

I did everything. I was a mover and a dry-waller; I even worked in the forest service. Then I was a gallerist for a long time; that was a really unlucrative profession. I founded a gallery in 1999, the Galerie Treibhaus. That existed for ten years â which was a big success for an independent gallery. And one of my artists worked in a book shop, which was in this space. It was a small bookshop that existed for two years. He said, âThe bookshop isnât doing well at all and is looking for a successor. Do you want to become a bookseller?â And that revealed to me for the first time that that would actually be the ideal place for me. It wasnât clear to me yet that a community would form then. The first three years were crazy. I was constantly thinking that I would have to close. Find your bill, I am just pretending to be a bookseller.

It all looked like a bookstore on the stage, but actually it didnât exist. I didnât study to be a bookseller, and I had to learn everything myself. They screwed with me a lot and I had to pay a lot of money to learn my lessons. In part, the publishers sent me all possible kinds of crap that then lay around in the back courtyard and was never sold. I had a case of pin-up calendars. I have no idea how I got them!

Just like in the textbooks, I landed on my feet after 1000 days. The 1000-day rule: If you do something for 1000 days, then suddenly a hobby becomes a business. You need naivety, engagement, and endurance. You arenât allowed to know everything required at the start. Itâs like a marathon; one step after the other. If I had known everything that was going to happen to me, I wouldnât have dared to do it, I have to say. Luckily, I was very ignorant. And then you just canât stop running, like in a marathon. Just keep going. After three years, I had so many phases in which I thought, âShit, tomorrow, I have to quit and shut the doors,â but then came the next day, and I knew that something would happen, and it would go on. It always goes on. I am very optimistic. "

UrsprÃ¼nglich gepostet am 8. Dezember 2017

"Ich lebe seit achtzehn Jahren in Dresden. Am Anfang gefiel es mir hier nicht besonders, aber seitdem ich selbst Sachen mache, finde ich es toll. Ich habe mir mein eigenes Umfeld geschaffen.

Ich habe das mexikanische Essen vermisst, jetzt habe ich ein mexikanisches Restaurant. Es hat mir auch gefehlt, meine Muttersprache zu sprechen. Es gab nicht so viele Leute, die Spanisch gesprochen haben, aber das hat sich in den letzten Jahren sehr verÃ¤ndert.

Ich hatte gemeinsam mit ein paar Freunden die Idee, ein Projekt zu starten, mit dem wir unsere Kultur fÃ¶rdern kÃ¶nnen, Partys und unsere Art zu leben. Es heiÃt Atelier Schwartz. Meine Freunde kommen aus verschiedenen Ecken in Lateinamerika, und es ging hauptsÃ¤chlich darum, einen Platz fÃ¼r kulturellen Austausch zu schaffen.

Das Projekt begann in einem Studio in der LouisenstraÃe. Wir haben dort unsere Kultur ausgestellt und die besten Partys veranstaltet, die diese Stadt je gesehen hat. Wir haben nicht einfach nur Salsa gespielt, was jeder kennt, sondern auch alternative Musik. Niemand wusste, dass es auch solche Musik in Lateinamerika gibt. Unser DJ war LeÃ³n Daza aus Kolumbien, und wenn er nicht konnte, habe ich es gemacht.

Unsere Partys sind exponentiell gewachsen, wir hatten bis zu 300 GÃ¤sten. Die Leute standen Schlange bis zur Ecke Kamenzer. Ich fand das so toll. Leider war die Familie unseres Vermieters nicht so begeistert. Die wollten, dass wir mit unseren Partys aufhÃ¶ren, sie wollten uns drauÃen haben. Wir waren drei Jahre vor Gericht, bis wie diesen Ort auf der FÃ¶rstereistraÃe gefunden haben. Nachdem ich drei Jahre lang selbst aufgelegt hatte, habe ich ein paar DJs gefunden, und wir haben eine komplett neue Art von Partys. Sie sind total multikulturell, es ist kein âLatinâ-Projekt. Wenn man hier reinkommt, hÃ¶rt man mindestens sieben Sprachen. Es ist ein Ort zum Teilen. Wir fangen um sechs an und es endet, wenn wir gehen. Manchmal fÃ¼hlt es sich an, als ob wir nie gehen.

Das kann anstrengend sein, aber wenn man mag was man tut, legt man seine Seele hinein. FÃ¼r mich ist mein Job kein Job. Es ist ein VergnÃ¼gen. Auch wenn es Probleme macht. Das ganze rechtliche Zeug ist manchmal kompliziert und so einen Schmelztiegel zu betreiben bringt immer Herausforderungen mit sich. Zwischenmenschliches kann schwierig sein. Zum GlÃ¼ck konnten wir immer alles zum Guten wenden."
--
Originally posted on December 8, 2017

"I have been living in Dresden for 18 years. In the beginning, I didnât like it so much, but since I have been producing things, I think itâs great. I have created an environment for myself.

I missed Mexican food, and now I have a Mexican restaurant. I also missed speaking my mother language. There weren't so many people who spoke Spanish, but that changed a lot in the last years.

Some friends and I had the idea of creating a project to promote our culture, parties, and the lifestyle that we like. Itâs called Atelier Schwartz. My friends are all from different regions in Latin America, and the main idea was to create a space for cultural exchange.

The project started in a studio in LouisenstraÃe. We started doing expositions of our art there, and we were throwing the best parties this city has ever seen. We didnât just play salsa, which everyone knows, but alternative music too. Nobody knew that kind of music also comes from Latin America. Our DJ was LeÃ³n Daza from Colombia and when he couldn't do it, I did.

Our parties grew exponentially, and we had up to 300 people. The line to get in would go to the corner of Kamenzer. I thought it was so great. Unfortunately, the family of our landlord didn't feel the same way. They didn't want us to continue with our parties; they wanted us out. We ended up in court for three years, until I found this place on FÃ¶rstereistraÃe.
After playing the music myself for three years, some DJs decided to join me, and we created a new way of partying. Our parties are completely multicultural; it isnât a âLatin' project. When you enter this place, you hear at least seven languages. It's a place to share. We start at 6 pm, and it ends when we leave. Sometimes, it feels like we never leave.

It can be tiring, but when you like what you do, you put your soul into it. For me, my job is not a job. It's a joy. Even when itâs problematic.

All the legal stuff can be hard to deal with and having a place that is such a melting pot can also present some challenges, since human interactions can be difficult. Fortunately, we have always been able to solve it positively."

"Heute bin ich ganz genau zwei Jahre in Dresden. Vor zwei Jahren habe ich nicht geglaubt, dass ich zwei Jahre spÃ¤ter noch in Deutschland sein werde, aber ich habe hier eine Menge tolle Leute kennengelernt und alles hat gepasst. Ich bin nach Dresden gekommen, um ein Pop-up-Weinbar-Projekt zu machen. Ein Freund von mir, den ich vor zwanzig Jahren in den USA getroffen habe, Silvio Nitzsche, hat das betrieben und er rief mich an, um zu fragen, ob ich fÃ¼r drei Monate herkommen mÃ¶chte. Ich habe meine Freundin Anne Ã¼berredet, mitzukommen.

Nach drei Wochen haben Anne und ich entschieden, dass wir lÃ¤nger hier bleiben wollen. Es lag an der Gemeinschaft; aber auch die Geschwindigkeit des Lebens hat eine groÃe Rolle gespielt. Wir waren beide an einem Punkt unseres Lebens angelangt, an dem wir eine VerÃ¤nderung brauchten. Als wir nach Deutschland gekommen sind, hatte Anne seit 22 Tagen keinen einzigen Tag frei, und sie hat jeden Tag 13 bis 17 Stunden gearbeitet. Es ist sehr stressig, in einer teuren Stadt wie San Francisco in der Gastronomie zu arbeiten. Hier ist das VerhÃ¤ltnis von Arbeit zu Freizeit viel besser. Und in der Neustadt fÃ¼hlt es sich an wie in unseren Lieblingsgegenden von San Francisco. Dann ist Donald Trump gewÃ¤hlt worden, und ich hatte keine Eile, nach Hause zu gehen.

Ich habe die meiste Zeit meines Lebens in der Gastronomie gearbeitet. Ich habe auf einer Kochschule gelernt und war zehn Jahre lang Leiterin eines Restaurants in San Francisco, bevor ich hierhergekommen bin. Ich habe gekocht, gebacken, gekellnert und an der Bar gearbeitet; ich habe so ziemlich alles gemacht. Und jetzt werde ich CafÃ©besitzerin sein.

Es ist nicht einfach, ein GeschÃ¤ft zu erÃ¶ffnen, wenn man die Sprache nicht spricht. Zum GlÃ¼ck hatte ich viel Hilfe. Anne hat mich viel unterstÃ¼tzt. Silvio, der mich hierhergebracht hat, hat mir so viel geholfen. Er hat mich mit groÃartigen Leuten bekannt gemacht. Heute habe ich darÃ¼ber nachgedacht, dass ich zum ersten Mal Erfahrungen mit Immigration mache. Ich bin US-Amerikanerin der ersten Generation - meine Eltern sind beide in die USA ausgewandert. Wenn ich daran denke, dass sie das alles auch durchmachen musstenâ¦es kann manchmal sehr frustrierend sein, aber das meiste funktioniert.

Das CafÃ© wird im kalifornischen Stil sein, das heiÃt locker und entspannt. Wenn man aus Kalifornien kommt, wÃ¤chst man mit allen mÃ¶glichen Sorten von Essen auf. Weil Kalifornien von Anfang an Einwanderer aus vielen verschiedenen LÃ¤ndern angezogen hat, ist die KÃ¼che von vielen verschiedenen Aromen geprÃ¤gt - Asien, Mittlerer Osten, Mittelmeer und natÃ¼rlich Mexiko. Wir werden frische Produkte der Saison verwenden. Ich will das Angebot der Saison entsprechend anpassen und Specials mit coolen Produkten der Region machen. Und wir werden viel backen. Meine Koch- und Backpartnerin hier ist Dani, die aus Deutschland kommt. Sie ist jung und enthusiastisch, und sie ist eine groÃartige BÃ¤ckerin. Wir werden amerikanische Sachen backen.

Leider haben wir hier nicht das breite Angebot, das es in Kalifornien gibt, aber man kann hier sehr gutes Obst und GemÃ¼se bekommen. Davon wird es eine Menge geben, und nicht so viel Fleisch und Kartoffeln. Ich liebe Fleisch, aber ich glaube, es muss nicht Ã¼berall dabei sein. Ich habe versucht, ein paar meiner Lieblingssachen vegan und glutenfrei zu machen, als Herausforderung fÃ¼r mich und weil ich glaube, dass es nicht fair ist, Veganern immer nur Salat mit einem Spritzer Zitrone zu geben. Es soll kein vegetarisches CafÃ© werden, aber Essen ist fÃ¼r mich eine soziale Angelegenheit und ich mÃ¶chte, dass fÃ¼r jeden etwas dabei ist."

"Today is my two-year anniversary of being in Dresden. Two years ago, I didnât think I would be in Germany in two years, but I met a lot of really great people here, and things fell into place. I came to Dresden to do a wine bar pop-up project. A friend of mine, who I met 20 years ago in the US, Silvio Nitzsche, was running it, and he called me and asked me to come for three months. And then I convinced my other friend Anne to come with me.

After three weeks, Anne and I decided to stay longer because of the community; the pace of life was also a big factor. We were both at a point in our lives where we needed a change. When we got to Germany, Anne hadnât had a day off in 22 days, and she was working 13 to 17 hours every single day. Working in the restaurant industry in an expensive city like San Francisco is very stressful. The balance here between life and work is much better. And the Neustadt has the same feeling as the neighborhoods in San Francisco that we liked. Then Donald Trump got elected, and I wasnât in a hurry to get home.

I have worked in gastronomy for most of my life. I went to culinary school, and I was general manager of a restaurant in San Francisco for ten years before coming here. I went from cooking to baking to being a waiter to be a bar tender; I have pretty much done everything. And now I am going to be a cafÃ© owner.

Itâs not been easy setting up a business in a place where you donât speak the language. Luckily, I have had a lot of help. Anne was a lot of help. Silvio, who brought me here, has helped so much. Heâs connected me with great people. Today, I was thinking about the fact that this is the first time I have had the immigrant experience. I am a first generation American â my parents were both immigrants to the US. To think that they had to do all of this as wellâ¦ it can be very frustrating at times, but things are working out for the most part.

The cafÃ© will be California-style cafÃ©, meaning relaxed and laid-back. Being from California, you grow up eating everything. Because it has attracted so many different immigrants from the beginning, California cuisine is a mix of flavors â Asian, Middle Eastern, Mediterranean, and of course Mexican. We will have produce that is fresh and in season. I will change the menu seasonally and have specials that will use cool regional products. Also, there will be baked goods. My baking and kitchen partner in this venture is Dani who is German. She is young and enthusiastic and a great baker, and we are going to be baking American style.

Unfortunately, we donât have the kind of bounty in produce that California does, but you can get very good fruits and vegetables around here. We will have a lot of that and not so much meat and potatoes. I love meat, but I donât think it needs to be in everything. I have tried to make some of my favorite things vegan and gluten-free, to challenge myself and because I donât think itâs fair to always just give vegans a plain salad with a squeeze of lemon. It wonât be a vegetarian cafÃ©, but for me, dining is a social experience; I want there to be something for everyone."

We will have produce that is fresh and in season. I will change the menu seasonally and have specials that will use cool regional products. Also, there will be baked goods. My baking and kitchen partner in this venture is Dani who is German. She is young and enthusiastic and a great baker, and we are going to be baking American style.

Unfortunately, we donât have the kind of bounty in produce that California does, but you can get very good fruits and vegetables around here. We will have a lot of that and not so much meat and potatoes. I love meat, but I donât think it needs to be in everything. I have tried to make some of my favorite things vegan and gluten-free, to challenge myself and because I donât think itâs fair to always just give vegans a plain salad with a squeeze of lemon. It wonât be a vegetarian cafÃ©, but for me, dining is a social experience; I want there to be something for everyone."

Ich bin in die USA zurÃ¼ckgekehrt und habe diesen Mann getroffen, der Deutscher war, und bin seinetwegen hierher gezogen. Er kam aus Westdeutschland und hat eine Stelle in Dresden bekommen. Ich wÃ¼rde definitiv niemandem empfehlen, wegen einer Beziehung in ein anderes Land zu ziehen. Wenn es nicht hÃ¤lt, sind die Konsequenzen viel schwerwiegender.

Ich musste in Deutschland bleiben, weil meine Kinder hier aufgewachsen sind. Das war ihr Fundament, das war ihre Basis, das war alles, was sie kannten. Ich war Ã¼berzeugt, dass es das beste fÃ¼r sie wÃ¤re, wenn sie in dieser Umgebung bleiben. Es war auÃerdem sehr schwer, wÃ¤hrend einer Scheidung ins Ausland zu ziehen. Eine Scheidung ist ganz anders als in den Staaten. Es ist â leider - sehr technisch, was bedeutet, dass deine ganze Situation keine Rolle spielt. Ich glaube, den Leuten muss klar sein, dass man bei einer Ehe in einem anderen Land nicht die gleichen MÃ¶glichkeiten der UnterstÃ¼tzung hat, man weiÃ nicht, wie das System funktioniert. Es hat den Anschein, als wÃ¼rde alles gegen einen arbeiten, wenn man ein Problem hat, und es gibt niemanden, an den man sich wenden kann, weil die Familie deines Ex-Partners auf seiner Seite ist.

Als ich meine Scheidung hatte, hatte ich nicht viele Freunde. Ich war im Grunde genommen ein Jahr lang allein. Meine Scheidung hat fÃ¼nf Jahre gedauert. Nach alledem wollte ich etwas eigenes haben, also habe ich meinen Burrito-Imbiss aufgemacht. Ich habe das getan, weil ich von den anderen Burritos in Dresden total enttÃ¤uscht war. Ich war erstaunt, dass man dort Dinge wie Gurken und Pilze oder Dillsauce in die Burritos macht. Ich habe mal ein kurzes Praktikum in einem richtig guten Restaurant in Ohio gemacht, als ich jÃ¼nger war. Ich habe schon immer sehr gern gekocht.
Ich bin glÃ¼cklich mit dem Laden. Ich freue mich Ã¼ber die Leute, die ich treffe, und wenn ich ihre verschiedenen Seiten kennenlerne. Ich mag meine Kunden, ich mag es, mit ihnen zu interagieren. "I was born in Columbus, Ohio, and I moved to Atlanta, Georgia when I was 14. I went to university in England; I would go on to study at three different universities after that. I wanted to go to England because I was always very perplexed by the social structures in America. I always felt out of place there. In a way, it got worse when I moved to Atlanta, but it opened my eyes even more to what was going on. I feel like racism in Ohio is more hidden; itâs more structural. Because the black population is bigger in Georgia, there is more confrontation between whites and blacks, but that actually makes things kind of work because people talk; they get into dialogue, and they sort it out.

I went back to the US, and I met this guy who was German, and I moved here because of him. He was from western Germany, and he ended up working in Dresden. I definitely would not recommend moving internationally for a relationship. When it doesnât last, the consequences are more severe.

I had to stay in Germany, because my kids grew up here. This was their foundation, this was their base, this was everything they knew. I felt it would be best for them to stay in this environment. It was also really difficult to move abroad when you are going through a divorce. Getting a divorce in Germany is very different than in the US. Itâs very technical, unfortunately, because it means your whole situation doesnât get factored in. I think what is important for people to know is that when you get married in a foreign country, you donât have the same support system you would have had in your own country, you donât know how the system functions. It seems like everything is working against you if there is a problem, and there is no one for you to turn to, because your ex-partnerâs family is on their side.

When I went through my divorce, I didnât have many friends. I was basically alone for a year. My divorce took five years, and at the end of that, I just wanted to have something for myself, so I opened my burrito place. I opened it because I was really disappointed by other burrito places in Dresden. I was amazed that they put things like cucumbers and mushrooms and zucchini and dill sauce in their burritos. I had done short apprenticeship in a really good restaurant in Ohio when I was younger, so I had always had a love of cooking.

I am happy with the shop. I am happy about the people that I meet, with sides of peopleâs personalities that I get to know. I like my customers, I like the interaction with them. I love Dresden. I think itâs possibly one of the most beautiful places to live in the world. I love riding my bicycle along the Elbe. I think people in Dresden are misunderstood sometimes, and I wish they would be a little bit more open to new things and new people."

"Meine Wurzeln liegen in Brandenburg, einem Bundesland, das durch Rainald Grebe berÃ¼hmt geworden ist. Die dort besungenen Alleen fÃ¼hrten auch in mein Heimatdorf: von daher, gut recherchiert, Herr Grebe! UrsprÃ¼nglich wollte ich mal Theaterwissenschaften studieren und als Dramaturgin arbeiten. Ein kurzer, aber groÃer Krach mit meinen Eltern fÃ¼hrte dann doch zum schneller verfÃ¼gbaren Germanistikstudium. Schon wÃ¤hrenddessen habe ich mein Geld freiberuflich verdient. Die Texterzunft wurde mit den Jahren jedoch immer weniger lukrativ. AuÃerdem stÃ¶rte mich schon damals, dass Unternehmen ihre Inhalte oft nicht gut durchdacht hatten. Da konnte auch die beste Rhetorik nichts reiÃen. Diese StÃ¶rung hat sicherich auch einen Beitrag zu meiner Gegenwart geleistet.

Ein paar Jahre habe ich journalistisch fÃ¼r einen Dresdner Zeitungsverlag gearbeitet, ehe ich dann im Agenturbereich landete. Lange Zeit verfolgte mich hier eine tiefe Unzufriedenheit. Ich wusste aber auch nicht so recht, woher sie kam.

Vor zwei Jahren dann starb mein Vater. Das erste Mal in meinem Leben habe ich einen Menschen in den Tod begleitet. Und dann gleich einen so nahestehenden. Noch dazu mit einem sichtbaren Leidensweg, den zu erleichtern man selbst keine Macht hat. Das hat mich und meine Sicht auf die Welt gravierend verÃ¤ndert. Zu meinem Vater hatte ich grundlegend ein tolles VerhÃ¤ltnis, zuletzt aber auch einen fundamentalen Krach inklusive jahrelanger Kontaktpause â ich schiebe es auf unsere temperamentvollen Sternzeichen Widder und Skorpion :-). Erst im Zuge seiner Diagnose Lungenkrebs fanden wir wieder zusammen. Knapp acht Monate blieben uns, und das war die intensivste Zeit meines Lebens. Sie brachte mich an meine emotionalen Grenzen. Viele Erlebnisse kamen ohne Worte aus, es stellte sich auf eine fÃ¼r mich nicht greifbare Weise eine tiefe, vieldimensionale Klarheit ein. Erst da begriff ich das dicke, dicke Band, das mich immer mit meinem Vater verbunden hatte. Bis heute bin ich total baff Ã¼ber diesen kurzen, aber umkrempelnden Erkenntnisprozess â Ã¼bersinnliche SpielplÃ¤tze sind mir sonst eher suspekt. Dieser Prozess jedoch beantwortete mir im Nachgang so viele ungestellte Fragen. Das mich immer begleitende Warum hatte plÃ¶tzlich alle Antworten.

Deshalb nimmt dieses kleine WÃ¶rtchen seit zwei Jahren ganz stark mein Leben ein. Es fÃ¼hrte mich auch zu der Erkenntnis, weshalb ich im Job andauernd so unzufrieden war: Chefs betrachten ambitionierte Mitarbeiter gern als Gefahr. Die Hierarchie wird tÃ¤glich im Fahnenappell klargemacht. Jemand, der mit dieser MentalitÃ¤t nichts anfangen kann, sondern einfach was Richtung Welt verÃ¤ndern machen will, wird schief angeguckt. Dienst nach Vorschrift bitte, gern auch mal ein ImpÃ¼lschen einstreuen, aber bitte keine groÃen Visionen! Was auf der Strecke bleibt: Das Bewusstsein, dass wir alle nur Menschen sind und uns, wie alle Elemente in der Natur, perfekt ergÃ¤nzen. NatÃ¼rlich, manche fÃ¼hren, manche folgen. Aber erst in dieser Kombination kann das Zusammenspiel funktionieren.

Schon 2016 hatte ich eine Agentur gefunden, in der der Hase grundlegend anders lief. Da waren Ideen gern gesehen, VerÃ¤nderungen willkommen, Mitmacher ausdrÃ¼cklich erwÃ¼nscht. Bis heute fÃ¼hle ich mich hier pudelwohl, kann mich verwirklichen und weiterentwickeln. Das mÃ¼ndete in der gemeinsamen UnternehmensgrÃ¼ndung mit meinem einstigen Chef und nun GeschÃ¤ftspartner. In meiner heutigen Leidenschaft zeigt sich auch, was meiner Berufsbiografie bis dato fehlte: das konspirative Miteinander von Arbeitgeber und Arbeitnehmer. Wir verbringen den GroÃteil unserer Lebenszeit auf und mit der Arbeit. Das klassische Angestelltendasein mit Weisungsempfang war fÃ¼r mich noch nie ein passendes Modell. Der Freigeist und Machertyp in mir wollte mehr. Ich bin allerdings auch ein Mensch, der Sicherheit im Leben braucht. Das hat mit meiner persÃ¶nlichen Geschichte zu tun. Deshalb kam fÃ¼r mich ein eigenes Unternehmen von Null an nie infrage. Umso grandioser die FÃ¼gung.

In Hinblick auf meine eigene Story mÃ¶chte ich in Unternehmen deshalb das Bewusstsein prÃ¤gen, dass es anders geht. Alle sind ein Team. Der Boss ist ohne seine Mitarbeiter nichts und andersherum. Alle haben ihre Lebenswirklichkeit, in die man sich hineindenken muss. Einander verstehen und nach gemeinsamen Potenzialen forschen, ist so wichtig, um eine moderne und zukunftsfÃ¤hige Unternehmenskultur zu schaffen. "My roots are in Brandenburg, a federal state that became famous because of Rainald Grebe. The avenues he sung about also led to my home village; well researched, Mr Grebe! Originally I wanted to study theater studies and work as a dramaturge. A short, but big quarrel with my parents led to me doing a more quickly available course of German studies. I was already earning money as a freelancer during this time. But the text racket became less and less lucrative over the years. Moreover, even then it bothered me that companies often didn't think their material through well. Even the best rhetoric couldn't help. This disturbance has certainly also contributed to my present life.

I worked as a journalist for a newspaper publisher in Dresden for a few years before I ended up in the marketing agency sector. For a long time, I was haunted by a deep dissatisfaction here. But I didn't really know where it came from either.

Then two years ago, my father died. It was the first time in my life that I was with a person until they died. And it was someone so close in such visible suffering that one had no power to ease. That changed me and my view of the world dramatically. I had a great relationship with my father, but recently I also had a fundamental conflict, which led to years of no contact - I blame it on our feisty star signs, Aries and Scorpio :). It was only when he was diagnosed with lung cancer that we found each other again. We had almost eight months left, and that was the most intense time of my life. It pushed me to my emotional limits. Many experiences were without words, and a deep, multidimensional clarity arose in a way that was intangible to me. Only then I understood the thick, thick bond that had always connected me to my father. To this day I am still totally baffled by this short but transformative cognitive process - supernatural playgrounds are otherwise rather suspect to me. This process, however, answered so many unasked questions for me afterwards. The Why that always accompanies me suddenly had all the answers.
That's why this little word has been taking over my life for two years now. It also led me to the realization why I was so dissatisfied with my job all the time: Bosses like to regard ambitious employees as a danger. The hierarchy is made clear daily in the roll call. Someone who cannot do anything with this mentality, but simply wants to change the direction of the world, is looked at askance. Serve by the book, please, and go ahead and contribute an idea, but please no big visions! What falls by the wayside is the awareness that we are all just people and, like all elements in nature, complement each other perfectly. Of course, some lead, some follow. But only in this combination can the interaction work.

As early as 2016 I had found an agency that was fundamentally different. Ideas were welcome, changes were welcome, participants were expressly welcome. To this day, I feel very much at home here, I can realize my ideas and develop them further. This led to the joint founding of a company with my former boss and now business partner. Today, my passion also shows what my professional biography has been lacking until now: the collusive cooperation between employer and employee. We spend most of our lives at work. The classic employee existence just receiving instructions has never been a suitable model for me. The free spirit and doer in me wanted more. But I am also a person who needs security in life. This has to do with my personal history. That's why building my own company from scratch was never an option for me and why the coincidence was all the more lucky.

Most employers do not use the entrepreneurial potential of their employees but often see it as a danger. But you can't change the world with this joy in doing things by the book. With regard to my own story, I would therefore like to shape the awareness in companies that things can be done differently. Everyone is a team. The boss is nothing without his employees and vice versa. Everybody has his own reality in which you have to think. Understanding one another and searching for common potential is so important for creating a modern and sustainable corporate culture. In my opinion, understanding is the key to a stable position in life. This applies not only to facts and the big picture, but also to the idiosyncrasies of people. This is one reason why, for example, I deal with behavior and use a model of behavioral description in my everyday consulting work. It helps managers and employees recognize how they tick, how the other person ticks and why communication is usually simply a broken mechanism -- because you don't communicate in a way that is appropriate for your type. The individual should learn where his strengths lie and can develop them with numerous tools in a goal-oriented way. I have a soft spot for personalities. This is the basis of my work at September MarkenfÃ¼hrung GmbH. Starting from the personality, the identity of people and companies, we develop brands and support our clients in the long term through this never-ending process. One focus is on employer brands. In this way, I hope that others are spared what I had to learn painfully for many years: only follow the call that is music to your ears. Most of my questions contain the simple word "why". Because it creates clarity. And it is the linchpin for a self-determined life -- at work, privately and in general."

Sie wollten was Neues zu essen ausprobieren und haben mich immer wegen Couscous gefragt. So habe ich gemerkt, dass die Leute hier so etwas mÃ¶chten. Meine Freunde haben mich gefragt, ob sie nicht jeden Tag zu mir essen kommen kÃ¶nnten - so habe ich die Idee gehabt, dieses Restaurant zu erÃ¶ffnen.

In normalen Zeiten lÃ¤uft es gut, aber jetzt ist es ganz schÃ¶n weniger geworden. Im Moment machen wir nur Abholservice von 12 Uhr bis 16 Uhr. Ich hoffe, dass es bald wieder ganz normal wird und mehr Kunden kommen. Am Anfang hatte ich ein bisschen Angst, aber jetzt Ã¼berwiegt die Hoffnung, dass die Pandemie bald vorbei ist und das normale Leben zurÃ¼ckkehrt."

"I have been in Germany since 1992. I was traveling then. In the 1990s, there were a lot of problems at home in Algeria. That's why I stayed here.

I opened this place in 2006. I serve Algerian food. People from all over the world come here to eat. I opened the restaurant because of friends in the Neustadt. They wanted to try something new and always asked me for couscous. That's how I could tell that people here would like something like couscous. My friends asked me if they could eat at my place every day. So, I had the idea of opening a restaurant.

In normal times, the business runs well, but now there is less business. At the moment, we are doing pick up service from 12 until 16. I hope that it will be normal again soon and more people will come. At first, I was a little afraid, but now that is outweighed by the hope that pandemic is over soon and that normal life comes back."

In Flensburg, I started my Bachelor of Education Sciences, specializing in special education and health and nutrition, and I am currently writing my Bachelor thesis. Before Corona broke out in the spring, the plan was to write the bachelor's thesis and then travel for half a year. So I left my apartment and part-time job and enjoyed the last days in Flensburg with great anticipation. Well - then everything changed and a new plan had to be made. Somehow the wide view into the distance always gave me something, that I never really had here.

I did a lot of environmental work with children that year. I looked after NAJU groups and did workshops on various topics at schools. And then it was clear that I wanted to go in that direction. Besides, I always did leisure activities for disabled people during the holidays. And I really enjoyed that too. And then I was told that in Flensburg you can study special education to become a teacher, which sounded like a jackpot to me!

Life by the sea is really just as I imagined it. But what strikes me in retrospect is that at some point you don't feel it is so "special" anymore and make less of it and appreciate it. The fact that one lives by the sea is then so commonplace and unconscious. "This flower shop has existed since 1892 and is the oldest flower shop in all of Dresden. We are mentioned by Erich KÃ¤stner in his books. In _When I Was a Little Boy_ he recounts how he bought his flowers here from the tiny little Mrs. Stammnitz. The whole house was only built because of the flower shop. At the back of the yard, there were big greenhouses. So we are a real legacy business.

I've had the business for 20 years. It's changed a lot in that time. In the past, it used to be a shop for people from the neighborhood, but today we rely more on big events, hotels and restaurants. "The ZentralOHRgan has been around since 1990; we thought it was cool to have a record store back then. We didn't have a plan - it all came about by chance. Between then and now was the CD era. There are still a few left, but they are slowly disappearing. And so in the end it will be a record shop again like in the beginning. We have what I like myself, but also things that people often ask for. One half is second-hand, the other half is new. Some things I just have to have, because I think they are good, and if nobody buys them, that's okay. But there are also many things I wouldn't listen to. The people were really very supportive; they ordered and bought vouchers, but still it was of course much less than usual. Maybe we could have left stores open. My grandma always said everything will be fine. And it has to be said that she went through much harder things in her life than we have - two world wars, twice total monetary devaluation, once inflation. I don't think we have anything to complain about."

"In 2004, I was going to the Caucasus myself and couldn't get maps in Dresden for the area I wanted to go to. But I noticed that they were available in another city where there was a travel bookstore. Since I had nothing to do anyway, and this is also a bit of a hobby of mine, it was the inspiration to open my own travel bookstore. I opened the shop in 2004, offering travel guides and everything else that has to do with travel: hiking maps, mountain bike maps, bike guides, hiking guides, even exotic stuff. People who are doing research in Afghanistan and need a topographical map for this section of the country also come to me. I have everything from classic illustrated books to calendars.

I myself take the time to travel. The shop is not doing badly. It's not a goldmine, but that's not what I'm after either. It's a thing that I enjoy and where my time is flexible. Of course, this is at the expense of sales, but I accept that. At the moment I'm worried about the future, of course. The travel sector is really bad right now, and it doesn't look like normal traveling will be possible in the next weeks or months. I don't want to seem overly pessimistic right now, but I think I have reason to be. A hiking map of the Heide now and then - nothing more is happening now. And that is of course not enough. Normally I would be earning my money for the autumn now. If things continue the way they are now, I'll have to come up with something else, and the shop will be history."

"Originally I come from the Oder region in Brandenburg - more precisely from the Schlaubetal. After finishing school, I started an apprenticeship and then moved to Jena to study art history and education. From there I moved on to Dresden. Here in Dresden I studied at the art pedagogy institute. I got my final degree at the Leipzig University
.
Now I work as an intern at the Museum of Transportation in Dresden. In addition, I curate exhibitions together with artist friends and work as an art educator in the GTA area in schools. What I find interesting about art education is not necessarily the pedagogy, but rather the history of art and its connection with social processes, i.e. the interrelationships, and also my own creative process, and the mediation of this through different interactive media is then brought with the pedagogy into play.

My attitude toward looking at different phenomena and orientations has changed. Initially I thought that what is written is law and you have two possibilities - agreement or rejection. But over time I have become more open. I really like working in multi-professional teams and combining content and viewpoints A lot is possible and your own perspective becomes a bit broader. Besides, I can't stand the saying: "Is this art or can it be thrown away?" at all. This normative ruling on the supposed quality of a work. You should always look at what's around it. Rarely does something stand alone and in isolation. That's why I try to get other people on board as often as possible.

I think families and artists should not be played off against each other as the AfD tries to do, but rather both should be supported as much as possible. There is no question of either-or. Basic income is important for all people. Many artists also have children. One should strive for more solidarity with one another. Statements like: "Not a cent for politically motivated art" certainly do not bring about peaceful coexistence in the cultural sector. What is considered culturally relevant from today's "bourgeois" point of view is absolutely political from an art historical perspective. For example the works of Caspar David Friedrich or Heinrich von Kleist.

As for the consequences of Corona - I think that private collectors will continue to buy. Especially in the time of crisis and in succession. The support for art and culture will certainly continue. Especially with regard to large institutions. It's a difficult time for small shops, galleries and self-employed people. I hope that the support will reach them and that a way will be found to support them well. Politics, and I mean this regardless of party affiliation, requires a lot of sensitivity. Because in my opinion, savings should not be made in art, culture and basic education. We need a vibrant cultural life, well-trained specialists, a social coexistence in which everyone can find themselves. Identity is a question of the environment - precisely this environment must be broadly based and also offer room for broad personal expression.

Coming to Dresden was not easy for me. During my time in Jena, I was used to a relaxed atmosphere. You were able to establish contacts quickly and, certainly also due to the size of the city, you were in contact with people of the same background. Friendships, some of which still exist today. A good friend of mine had been in Dresden for quite some time when I arrived. As students in the first semester at the huge organism of the TU, we had to learn to self-organize first and foremost. An intense phase in the streets of the Neustadt followed. Drunken nights and superficial contacts. Over time, I have become very "fond" of the city, which initially scared me off by its conservatism. There are great people here! We always used to meet at the wooden stairs in front of the "Scheune" and watched the hustle and bustle. I appreciate the networks in Dresden, the collegial cooperation.

What I can't understand is there is so much skepticism towards "strangers." Perhaps this is a legacy from the post-reunification period. Sometimes I miss the tolerant cooperation and the courage and openness to engage in new things. But there are also enough examples to refute this statement. For example the MalJam Jumble, the Broiler Jam, and many more. Dresden should be aware of its creative potential. There are many smart people here who live the dream of being free. In my perception there are more of them than the intolerant "angry citizens."

photo credit: Erik Gross

Ich habe Arbeit in einem Hotel. Alles war gut, aber jetzt in der Corona-Zeit machen wir leider nichts. Im Moment ist es sehr, sehr langweilig, aber jetzt machen wir Ramadan. Leider dÃ¼rfen wir im Moment nicht in die Moschee gehen, aber das ist okay - wir warten, bis Corona weg ist, und dann geht es wieder los."
--
"I am from Libya. I have lived in Dresden since 2014. I am having problems with my asylum application. I learned the language, and I have worked. I don't know why my asylum application was rejected. Other people from Libya have gotten asylum. You don't know why and how it's decided.

I have a job in a hotel. Everything was fine, but now in the Corona period, we aren't doing anything unfortunately. At the moment, it's very, very boring, but we are celebrating Ramadan. Unfortunately, we aren't allowed to go to the mosque, but that's ok. We are waiting until Corona is gone, and then everything will start again."

Es macht krank, und wenn man sich kaum noch bewegt und kaum noch drauÃen ist, weil man nicht das nÃ¶tige Kleingeld dazu hat, kommt dann sowas raus. Ich habe Diabetes; das ist auch eine der Ursachen.

Ob ich mir wegen Corona Sorgen mache? Ja und nein. Ich sage mal so: Man probt damit auch einen Ernstfall, so wie in den vergangenen Wochen die BevÃ¶lkerung an die Kandare genommen wurde - ob das richtig ist, bleibt mal dahingestellt. Was mich stÃ¶rt ist, dass auch von den sechzehn BundeslÃ¤ndern jeder sein eigenes SÃ¼ppchen kocht und es keine Zentrale gibt, die bestimmt, wie es richtig gemacht wird. Auch wenn das jetzt ein bisschen provokant klingt und man anderer Meinung ist - vor Ã¼ber 30 Jahren wÃ¤re das anders verlaufen, da gab es nicht den Weg des Bezirks Rostock, den Weg des Bezirks Gera oder den Weg des Bezirks Dresden - es gab einen Weg.

Das ist symptomatisch fÃ¼r das gesamte System der Bundesrepublik. Meine Meinung ist, dass das bessere Deutschland vor dreiÃig Jahren untergegangen ist. Auch wenn man alles mit Stasi und wer weiÃ was erklÃ¤ren mÃ¶chte und wir ein Volk wÃ¤ren, das nicht frei gewesen ist, die Wahrheit sah anders aus. So wie man die DDR in den Massenmedien darstellt, so war das nicht, so habe ich das nicht erlebt. Dass hinter jedem ein Stasimann stand oder dass man sich jetzt Ã¼ber den AbschnittsbevollmÃ¤chtigten lustig macht - das war vollkommen anders. Das System damals war vor allem sozial gerechter. NatÃ¼rlich werden Fehler gemacht, natÃ¼rlich ist nicht alles Gold was glÃ¤nzt, aber zu sagen, die DDR war schlecht - das war nicht der Fall.

Man muss bedenken, dass letztendlich die wirtschaftliche Macht des Westens die DDR ruiniert hat. Das Geld haben sich die Konzerne weltweit geholt, dort wo sie ihre Fabriken hatten. Eine DDR-Wirtschaft war eine nationale Wirtschaft. Wir waren genauso boykottiert wie Kuba jetzt wieder. Man muss sagen: Wenn ihr schon sprecht, dann sprecht auch die RealitÃ¤t, die Wahrheit. Dass man jetzt immer sagt, dass die Wirtschaft am Boden war - das stimmt nicht."

"I was the head chef at the TU Dresden. Shortly after the so-called "turnaround," they got rid of me. Since then, I have not been able to get a foot in ordinary life. It makes you sick, when you hardly move and you are hardly outside because you don't have the money, something like this happens to you. I have diabetes; that is also one of the causes.

Do I worry about Corona? Yes and no. Let me put it this way: The state is rehearsing an emergency, just as the population has been curbed in the past weeks - whether that is correct is a matter of debate. What bothers me is that each of the sixteen federal states is doing its own thing, and there is no central office to determine how it should be done properly. Even if that sounds a bit provocative now and other people are of another different opinion - more than 30 years ago things would have been different. There wouldn't be the Rostock district way, the Gera district way or the Dresden district way- there was just one way.

It is symptomatic of the entire system of the Federal Republic. My opinion is that the better Germany ended thirty years ago. Even if you want to explain everything with Stasi and who knows what and we were a people who was not free, the truth looked different. The way the GDR is portrayed in the mass media, that's not how it was, that's not how I experienced it. The idea that there was a Stasi man chasing everyone, or that people now make fun of the neighborhood citizen police - that was completely different. The system at that time was socially fairer. Of course, mistakes are made, of course not all that glitters is gold, but to say that the GDR was bad - that was not the case.

One has to consider that in the end, it was the economic power of the West that ruined the GDR. The money was taken by corporations worldwide, where they had their factories. The GDR economy was a nationalized economy. We were boycotted just like Cuba is again. It should be said, "If you speak, then speak about reality, the truth." It is not true what they say now that the economy was devastated."

"I moved from Frankfurt am Main to Dresden in 1993. Well, actually I come from Kelsterbach, five minutes away from the Frankfurt Airport. It's a small town, but the airport always gave me the feeling that I was connected to the whole world. I wanted to go to another city after school, but for a long time I didn't know what I wanted to do. I was very undecided and did internships at the Theater fÃ¼r KostÃ¼m in Frankfurt, then at a film internship in Munich, then I observed wood restoration in Bielefeld and took classes with a sculptor in Paderborn, where I carved my first sandstone; it became a Janus head.

Then I applied to a fashion school in Berlin and would have been accepted, but somehow it was too academic for me. I did not like going to school. Then a cousin of my grandmother from Riesa said that she knew a stone sculptor from Dresden who was looking for a girl apprentice. I called the Hempel company in Dresden. I didn't understand my future master very well. Between the Saxon language and the mumbling, I guessed that I should come by and bring my portfolio. I called my father from Berlin, and he came with my portfolio, and we introduced ourselves. Yes, it was quite strange, because after a quick look at the folder, my master sent me out to the journeymen and arranged everything else with my father - very old school.

But then I saw something outside that I had never seen before: It was summer and the boys were almost all shirtless, and they looked like Greek statues. I probably had my mouth hanging open for a while, but between the stones and the sculptures, these men were some of the most beautiful things I had ever seen; you can't say it differently than that. Then there was a break for breakfast and I was taken into the breakfast room. Besides some boys and men, there were only two women there. The first thing I asked was whether the two very similar boys were related to each other. Very stupid - because later I found out that they were identical twins. I had the feeling that I was saying one stupid thing after another all the time. I felt very strange, but I was also fascinated. Anyway, they took me and some time later I started my three-year stone sculpting apprenticeship in Dresden.

I was very naive when I came to Dresden. At that time I didn't care if I went to Munich, Berlin, Hamburg or Dresden. I didn't realize that I was going to another country; it was still East Germany at that time. There were different rules. In retrospect, it was the hardest, loneliest time of my life, but some of the most exciting and formative years. And I'm so glad that I had the youthful inexperience to let myself fall into it.

Since 2013, I have been running a silk scarf manufactory together with a friend. We met at the HfbK, where Irina runs the silk-screen printing workshop. We screen print the silk by hand and do it in small editions. Like a print edition in art, each scarf gets a small certificate with a number of the edition. We design the patterns for the scarves ourselves. Irina works with found structures, which she overlays and arranges to an abstract pattern, and I mostly work with my drawings and silhouettes, which I assemble into a picture. It started with a commission for a couture house in Frankfurt. There I designed patterns for a small collection and printed them together with Irina. One of the fabrics we printed was a crÃªpe satin silk. The effect was amazing. The printing ink dried matte on the shiny fabric, and something like a spatial effect was created. We were thrilled.

Silk is a wonderful material. In the beginning we had to try a lot and a lot went wrong, but by now, I can say that we have become silk printing experts in our own way. But we also had to become experts because the material is so valuable. Pure luxury!"

I was very undecided and did internships at the Theater fÃ¼r KostÃ¼m in Frankfurt, then at a film internship in Munich, then I observed wood restoration in Bielefeld and took classes with a sculptor in Paderborn, where I carved my first sandstone; it became a Janus head.

Then I applied to a fashion school in Berlin and would have been accepted, but somehow it was too academic for me. I did not like going to school. Then a cousin of my grandmother from Riesa said that she knew a stone sculptor from Dresden who was looking for a girl apprentice. I called the Hempel company in Dresden. I didn't understand my future master very well. Between the Saxon language and the mumbling, I guessed that I should come by and bring my portfolio. I called my father from Berlin, and he came with my portfolio, and we introduced ourselves. Yes, it was quite strange, because after a quick look at the folder, my master sent me out to the journeymen and arranged everything else with my father - very old school.

But then I saw something outside that I had never seen before: It was summer and the boys were almost all shirtless, and they looked like Greek statues. I probably had my mouth hanging open for a while, but between the stones and the sculptures, these men were some of the most beautiful things I had ever seen; you can't say it differently than that. Then there was a break for breakfast and I was taken into the breakfast room. Besides some boys and men, there were only two women there. The first thing I asked was whether the two very similar boys were related to each other. Very stupid - because later I found out that they were identical twins. I had the feeling that I was saying one stupid thing after another all the time. I felt very strange, but I was also fascinated. Anyway, they took me and some time later I started my three-year stone sculpting apprenticeship in Dresden.

I was very naive when I came to Dresden. At that time I didn't care if I went to Munich, Berlin, Hamburg or Dresden. I didn't realize that I was going to another country; it was still East Germany at that time. There were different rules. In retrospect, it was the hardest, loneliest time of my life, but some of the most exciting and formative years. And I'm so glad that I had the youthful inexperience to let myself fall into it.

Since 2013, I have been running a silk scarf manufactory together with a friend. We met at the HfbK, where Irina runs the silk-screen printing workshop. We screen print the silk by hand and do it in small editions. Like a print edition in art, each scarf gets a small certificate with a number of the edition. We design the patterns for the scarves ourselves. Irina works with found structures, which she overlays and arranges to an abstract pattern, and I mostly work with my drawings and silhouettes, which I assemble into a picture. It started with a commission for a couture house in Frankfurt. There I designed patterns for a small collection and printed them together with Irina. One of the fabrics we printed was a crÃªpe satin silk. The effect was amazing. The printing ink dried matte on the shiny fabric, and something like a spatial effect was created. We were thrilled.

Silk is a wonderful material. In the beginning we had to try a lot and a lot went wrong, but by now, I can say that we have become silk printing experts in our own way. But we also had to become experts because the material is so valuable. Pure luxury!"
