"I was born near Berlin in 1920, and I knew Berlin as a city in ruins after the war and also before that. I was a cargo glider pilot during the war. When the war ended, I was at the Semmering Pass in Austria. I was one of the few who ever came home unscathed and unharmed from this war. People born between 1915 to 1925 were the ones who had the most casualties in the Second World War. From the two classes with whom I went to school, two thirds of my classmates did not return home. It was insanity, madness.

From 1946 to 1952, I studied at the Technical University Berlin-Charlottenburg and became a civil engineer. I wouldn't want to miss some of the things from the GDR time. It was a completely different life - first of all politically, and I was never politically active, but I always had something to say, I always had leading positions, although I wasn't in any party.

I was locked up for three years by the Stasi. I came home from the war as an officer and was very much involved in humanitarian work and always gave help wherever it was needed. For this purpose, I also met with former war comrades in Berlin. Those who observed this took it as a reason to tip off the Stasi about these meetings. I was taken off the street. But after that I was allowed to work as a civil engineer. My life's work as a civil engineer was the construction of a pipe manufacturing plant in Riesa."

"Am 6. Januar 2017 habe ich meinen Vater in der Neustadt besucht. Dort wurde mir von der Ehefrau von meinem Vater gesagt, dass er am 16.10 2016 verstorben ist. Uns hat keiner informiert. Ich bin ein Kind aus erster Ehe. Es wurde alles totgeschwiegen. Ich vermute, das lag daran, dass mein Vater ein Testament fÃ¼r uns Kinder gemacht hat und das wollte man nicht. Der Rechtsanwalt hat das Testament gefÃ¤lscht und hat deshalb angefangen, mich zu bekÃ¤mpfen, weil ich alles wusste.

Ich hatte einen Oberschenkelhalsbruch und wurde am 19. MÃ¤rz 2019 operiert. Am 20. MÃ¤rz bin ich auf die geschlossene psychiatrische Station in Friedrichstadt gekommen. Der Rechtsanwalt wollte mich fÃ¼r unzurechnungsfÃ¤hig erklÃ¤ren, damit ich nicht weiter gegen ihn vorgehen kann. Ich habe dort schwere Medizin bekommen. Der Rechtsanwalt wollte mich in eine geschlossene psychiatrische Anstalt bringen. Es geht um eine an den Haaren herbeigezogene psychische Krankheit. Aber ich habe ein zwÃ¶lfseitiges Gutachten hier liegen, dass ich ein normaler Mensch bin. Mit einer Handvoll Ãrzten hat er da geschÃ¤ftlich irgendwas gemacht, um mich in die Knie zu zwingen.

Mein Vater war ein GroÃunternehmer, auch GeheimnistrÃ¤ger. Es geht um Millionen. Ich wÃ¼rde das Geld verschenken, weil das fÃ¼r mich dreckiges Geld ist. An diesem Geld klebt Blut. Ich wÃ¼rde es fÃ¼r gute Zwecke verschenken oder der Stadt Dresden fÃ¼r Kinderheime geben.

Das ist kein Mensch, das ist eine Bestie, und man hat alle Hebel in Bewegung gesetzt, um mich auszuschalten und hat es nicht geschafft. Ich bin durch die HÃ¶lle gegangen. Hier in der Klinik geht's mir sehr gut. Ich habe mich auch sehr erholt. Ich mÃ¶chte, dass dieser Mensch hinter Schloss und Riegel kommt, dass er alles verliert, dass das alles geprÃ¼ft wird, wie er seine Millionen verdient hat."

"On January 6, 2017 I visited my father in the Neustadt. There I was told by my father's wife that he died on October 16, 2016. Nobody informed us. I am a child from his first marriage. It was all hushed up. I suppose it was because my father made a will for us children and they didn't want that. The lawyer forged the will and started to fight me because I knew everything.

I fractured my femur and was operated on March 19, 2019. On March 20, I was taken to the closed psychiatric ward in Friedrichstadt. The lawyer wanted to declare me insane, so that I could not proceed further against him. I was heavily medicated there. The lawyer wanted to put me in a closed psychiatric ward. It's a far-fetched mental illness. But I have a 12-page report lying here that says that I am a normal person. With a handful of doctors, he went into business for himself and tried to bring me to my knees.

My father was a big-time entrepreneur. He kept secrets. We're talking millions. I would give that money away because I think it's dirty money. There's blood on that money. I would give it away for good causes or give it to the city for children's homes.

The lawyer is not a human being, he is a beast, and they have done all they could to take me out and they didn't succeed. I have gone through hell. I'm doing very well here at the clinic. I've recovered a lot, too. I want this person to be put under lock and key, I want him to lose everything, I want all of this to be checked out, how he earned his millions."

Neben dem DaZ-Unterricht hatten wir noch FÃ¶rderunterricht, um schneller Deutsch zu lernen. Bei mir hat es gereicht, bei ihr nicht ganz, weil sie Ã¤lter ist. Sie war damals 15, ich erst 12. Deswegen spreche ich ohne Akzent, aber sie hat einen.

Mit 12, 13 Jahren will man ja cool sein. Ich habe in der siebten Klasse einen Aufsatz geschrieben darÃ¼ber, wie wir hergekommen sind, Ã¼ber diesen Abschied und alles. Mein Deutsch war zum Teil besser als das von den anderen Kindern. Und die Klassenlehrerin hat es auch noch vorgelesen vor der ganzen Klasse. Ich dachte mir "Ohnein!" Und die anderen guckten mich alle so an: "HÃ¤, wasn das fÃ¼rn Streber?" Das wollte ich nicht, deswegen sind meine Noten ab da schlechter geworden.

Ich denke dass Dresden freundlicher sein kÃ¶nnte. Gerade im Osten sind die Leute eher nicht so offen fÃ¼r andere Kulturen. Sie sehen das eher als etwas Schlechtes an anstatt als etwas Gutes. Andere Kulturen kÃ¶nnen die Welt auch bereichern, aber viele sehen das nicht so. Sobald man mit Akzent spricht, reagieren die meisten ablehnend. Ich denke, die Leute haben Angst vor dem, was fremd ist, und durch diese Angst sind sie eher zurÃ¼ckhaltend. Ich war mehrmals in den USA. Dort ist das ganz anders. Wenn man dort mit Akzent spricht, wollen die sofort wissen, wo man herkommt, was man macht und warum man hergekommen ist. Die Menschen dort sind sehr offen. Ich denke, die Leute hier sollten mehr reisen und andere Kulturen selbst entdecken, um andere Kulturen zu akzeptieren. Das erweitert den Horizont und baut diese Mauer ab."

"We come from Kazakhstan and moved to Germany with our parents 24 years ago. First we were in a reception camp in Radebeul, but after three months we came to Dresden. We only had German as Second Language classes (DaZ) for one year and then we were in a normal school. Besides the DaZ lessons, we had remedial classes to learn German more quickly. With me it was enough, with her not quite, because she is older. She was 15 then, I was only 12. So I speak without an accent, but she has one.

When you're 12, 13, you want to be cool. I wrote an essay in the seventh grade about how we got here, about that leaving-taking and everything. My German was better than some of the other kids'. And the class teacher read it out loud in front of the whole class. I thought to myself "Oh no!" And the others looked at me like: "What a geek!" I didn't want that, so my grades got worse from then on.

I think Dresden could be friendlier. Especially in the east, people are not so open to other cultures. They see it as something bad instead of something good. Other cultures can also enrich their world, but many don't see it that way. As soon as you speak with an accent, most people react negatively. I think people are afraid of what is foreign, and because of this fear, they tend to be reticent. I have been to the USA several times. It's very different there. If you speak with an accent there, they want to know immediately where you come from, what you do and why you were there. The people there are very open. I think that people here should travel more and discover other cultures themselves in order to accept other cultures. That broadens your horizons and breaks down these walls."

Nachdem ich in den USA, Deutschland und Irland gelebt habe, habe ich das GefÃ¼hl, ein sehr gutes VerstÃ¤ndnis dafÃ¼r zu haben, was bei Bier im Trend liegt. In Irland liebt man Trends. "I was a student in Cottbus for two years, and in between Cottbus and Dresden, I lived in Ireland for two years. My former boss offered me a job in Dresden, and so we came here. I ended up in Cottbus by searching a database for masterâs programs in English, because I couldnât afford one in the States, and the one that matched my interests was there. It was called world heritage studies.

When I was in Cottbus, I worked for the Bieratorium. I worked there for about a year. I kept in touch with my former boss while I was in Ireland, asking if there were any jobs, and he finally told me about this place. He told me if I could come manage the store if I wanted to.

My partner is Irish. We met in the masterâs program in Cottbus. We went back to Ireland for two years to see if we could find work, but that was hard. In the cultural world, it all depends on who you know, and it turns out, I didnât know anyone in Ireland. My partner had twice the experience in the field, and he could barely get a job.

So far, itâs been pretty good in Dresden. I have only been here for eight months, so itâs pretty new. In my head, I thought, I just have to get to summer, because I feel like you canât really judge a city until its summer. But now, all of this is happening. I am not sure how to read Dresden yet.  There is a lot more happening here than in Cottbus. I probably like Cottbus a lot more than the average person, but Dresden is a big step up. And itâs significantly more affordable than Dublin.

Die haben alle schon einen schweren Start. Zwischendurch hatten wir drei Jahre lang einen jungen afghanischen Mann bei uns als Pflegesohn wohnen gehabt. Die sind wirklich in groÃer Not. Und ich kann da auch nicht nein sagen."

"I am a dental technician by profession. But I also studied trauma pedagogy. This has less to do with my association, but with the fact that we still have foster children at home. Almost all foster children are also traumatized. We always wanted to have many children. Unfortunately, that didn't work out as it should have - the dear God has decided it that way. We had dealt with adoption and then came one after the other. We were in contact with the youth welfare office and the social welfare office. They said that adoption is difficult, but they had a lot of foster children. We were involved, we took the classes, and at some point we said, "Yes, we'll do it. We had three foster kids in total. We currently have a ten-year-old daughter.

The children are all traumatized. I don't know of any that are not. They have either been taken into care by the youth welfare office or have had experiences - that the parents neglected them or that they were put into a home. They've all had a rough start. At some point we had a young man from Afghanistan living with us for three years as a foster son. Even he was traumatized by the journey here. He came here on foot. It was impossible to walk with him through the forest, he was afraid of the forest. If you don't stick with it, depression will develop later. We can only guide them. We can only tell them through a lot of love and a lot of relationships and security that they never had before: There's a safe place in the world where they can be as they are. And talk again and again, talk very, very much. Through my own experience with depression - and I am also very open to the children - we have a completely different relationship. When our Masud moved out, we initially said, that's it now, we are now in our mid-40's. But it didn't take long and the Youth Welfare Office called and asked how things were going. They are really in great need. And I also can't say no."

Part 2 of 2

"I had a car accident on the way to work thirteen years ago. There were six of us in the car. I lay in a coma for four days. I had to be resuscitated. The doctors only gave me a small chance to survive at all and if I did, with considerable damage. My partner visited me every day in the hospital. The driver died unfortunately. He was a good friend of mine, as old as my oldest son. It was pretty hard for me to bear. In 2013, I was lucky enough to be able to do trauma therapy here in the Uniklinik in Dresden. I waited for it for four years. The therapy helped me a lot. Up to that point, I had a lot of problems. It does a number on you when you have never been unemployed before.

In some respects, the accident made it difficult to be a father. I canât set limits. Because of the accident, I fell into a phase where I fell down psychologically and sometimes behaved like a child myself, didnât want to be treated â itâs difficult to describe. I let a lot of things slide. I didnât set boundaries; I didnât make announcements. I fell short of my role as a father. Itâs still difficult for me, although itâs been thirteen years. In some ways, itâs pretty complicated. Thatâs why we decided that we would separate, that I would get my own apartment, and find myself first.

I have discovered that the menâs network is stabilizing for me. I am around people and can speak normally, something that was incredibly difficult at first. For instance, the day clinic was difficult for me. I also went to meetup places for psychologically struggling people. It is difficult to find the right thing for yourself. Here in the menâs network, there is a workshop that I can use. Itâs good for me. I like to work with wood anyway, and I like to take on orders. I have now been here for a year, and itâs really fun. I take advantage of opportunities like todayâs foosball get-together or the menâs cafÃ©. That it is just men â thatâs the way it is. You can talk and exchange ideas about certain experiences, something that is really, really important. Some people would just like to talk, just want someone to listen. I notice that in myself, and I happily accept when someone comes to me and just speaks with me. There are some things that you canât do alone. Like when I got help from trained psychotherapists or like they helped me in the Uniklink, I am of the opinion that I also need help from professionals, who know what they are doing and can help me. And here in the menâs network, I have feeling that I can help other people. Just that alone helps."

We will be on the vacation until the middle of August. Until then, please enjoy some of our favorite interviews from the past few years...

Es war etwas kompliziert in der DDR mit Organisationen und der Partei, da haben sie immer versucht zu werben, obwohl ich nie drin war. Ab und zu bin ich vom Bereichsleiter hochzitiert worden, dann wurde eine kurze Werbung gemacht, aber wie gesagt, das ist ja jetzt alles weggefallen, und ist jetzt effektiver und schÃ¶ner.

Seit 2003 bin ich schon in Rente. Ich war glÃ¼cklich, als die Wende kam, ich habe ja bei der Armee Flugzeuge repariert, und endlich konnte ich mal ein Flugzeug reparieren bei Airbus fÃ¼r den Frieden. In der Zeit, von 1990 bis 1995 ungefÃ¤hr, sind wir ja in den AirbusstÃ¤dten rumgefahren, Hamburg, MÃ¼nchen und Ã¼berall, da haben wir viel dazugelernt. Und die haben auch was dazu gelernt, nÃ¤mlich dass wir gar nicht so sind, so auf den Kopf gefallen, sondern uns immer zu helfen wissen, wenn was ist.

Ich habe auch noch mal einen Lehrgang gemacht, Computer, Technik. Ich hab immer gesagt, ich rechne meinen Mist selber aus, dafÃ¼r brauch ich keinen Computer. Wir haben in der Schule das Einmaleins bis sonstwohin gelernt, aber bei Airbus wurden die FuÃbodenplatten an einer groÃen FrÃ¤se gemacht, und da wurde ich drangesetzt, also musste ich. Am Anfang habe ich schon ein bisschen gerudert, aber mit der Zeit hat sich das dann ergeben, und da war ich dann auch ganz zufrieden mit mir."

--
"I am a war baby born in 1943, lived in the GDR the whole time, then came the reunification. I worked in aircraft manufacturing and then at Airbus and then in Dresden at the dockyard. That is my basic life trajectory; we are doing well comparatively.

I had a good youth. It was somewhat complicated in the GDR with organizations and the party; they were always trying to recruit, although I was never part of it. Once in a while, I was given a citation by the division manager, then a short advertisement would be made, but like I said, itâs all over now, and now itâs more effective and nicer.

I have been retired since 2003. I was happy when the reunification came. I repaired airplanes for the army and finally I could repair a plane at Airbus for the peace. In the time between about 1990 and 1995, we went to the Airbus cities â Hamburg, Munich, and everywhere, and we learned a lot there. And they also learned, namely that we werenât born yesterday but that we knew what to do.

I also did another course of study, computer, technology. I always said âI can do the math in my head; I donât need a computer.â We learned one times one to whatever in school, but at Airbus the floor panels were made on a big mill, and I tried my best, I had to. At first, I was a little at sea, but with time, it fell into place, and I was very happy with myself.â

I think thatâs really nice; you get an awareness of life back.

I am also professionally involved in this scene right now. I work at the Saxon regional association of social culture. It has now been especially exciting with the mayoral election in GÃ¶rlitz, where the AfD said that there was no room for social culture. We also have seen at the HfBK that they donât understand the form of free art and culture. Perhaps you have heard of Marwa-El-Sherbini, the Egyptian pharmacist who was murdered in Dresden. In the context of my fellowship, I do a lot of activities involving intercultural meetings between Dresden natives, refugees, and migrants, in order to dismantle prejudices. Unfortunately, you know what the atmosphere is like in Dresden. Today, I am doing an event that I have wanted to realize for a long time. We are inviting people to eat and drink for free in order to bring them into conversation. I hope that we are successful. We are mixed team of Germans and migrants. We are really hoping for lively discussion. The goal is to talk to each other instead of about each other. There are a lot of prejudices on both sides. We would like to dismantle them and that only happens with speaking, but food connects people as well, of course.

I have been active in diverse ways â socially and civically. I have also been active in refugee work. I noticed that refugees also have prejudices. When they have a bad experience â if they are insulted or abused â they think, âAll Germans are xenophobic.â On the other side, Dresden natives say that everyone who comes here are social parasites and not educated and canât speak any languages.

Seven years ago, I was one of the very, very few women who wore a headscarf here in Dresden. I thought that Germans were more enlightened in terms of religion, but when I got here, I found out that because of the historical background here in the east, people are not religious, that religion doesnât play any role. I pictured it differently. At the start, I was sometimes asked whether there were schools in Egypt or if I was allowed to go to school in Egypt. I thought the people here would be more educated than in Egypt, that they would maybe know that Egypt doesnât consist out of just camels and sand, but that there are also autos, schools, and universities. I have also often had people say to me: âYou speak German, I didnât know that.â Or they are amazed that I went to university. I was a little shocked at first, but with time, I also found it interesting that people come to me and ask why is this so and why is that so, why do I do this, why do I wear a headscarf? I actually found it really nice that people would ask.

To be honest, I have been insulted a lot, but at some point, I developed a thicker skin. I know that people are afraid, that they have prejudices. Some people donât want to have a conversation. There are really unreachable people, no matter how long you stand there and talk. In the end, you are the foreigner, maybe a terrorist, who wants to islamicize the city, and who is definitely oppressed -- because there are no intelligent women who wear headscarves, they have to be dumb and dominated by men. But there are also people who want to talk and be enlightened.

Itâs difficult to reach everyone. I said to myself: âIf someone insults you, who either thinks that all Muslim women are dominated or that I would like to behead people here, who has prejudices in other words, I donât have to engage. I wish that when people say something that they would stay and stand behind their words, but they walk away. If someone calls me a terrorist, I say, âThank you very much!â or âI am certainly not a terrorist.â Then they look a little surprised and keep walking. They seem to think that they can insult the weaker sex, that maybe women wonât understand or maybe they will be afraid and crawl away.

For that reason: Just seeing doesnât achieve much. At StraÃburger Platz, where the mosque is, you see a lot of foreigners on Friday, but if you watch the grandmas, how they look, they are more shocked. They donât know any of them. For them, these people are more like dangerous extremists or something."

Ich glaube, dass der Andrang anwÃ¤chst. Und die Stadt denkt, es kommen nicht mehr so viele, was aber auch nicht wahr ist, weil viele aus dem Umland nach Dresden kommen. Die brauchen auch wieder Hilfe und UnterstÃ¼tzung.

Die Menschen sind erfolgreich, wenn sie sich hier auf irgendeine Art gut fÃ¼hlen und einen Plan haben, wie sie vorwÃ¤rts kommen wollen. Ich denke, es wÃ¼rde Ziele und Wege geben, aber einige haben es nicht gefunden. Ich glaube, solche Angebote wie SPIKE mÃ¼sste es noch mehr geben. Ich kann nicht sagen: âDas musst du aber kÃ¶nnen.â Wenn ich merke, er kann es nicht, nicht weil er doof oder faul ist, unser bÃ¼rokratisches System ist der Horror, muss ich ihm helfen. Wir haben jetzt viele, die eine Idee haben. Sie machen eine Ausbildung oder gehen erst mal arbeiten. Es steckt viel Arbeit von SPIKE dahinter. Man muss dran bleiben. Wir arbeiten wohlwollend mit den Leuten zusammen und entwickeln zusammen eine Idee, wo es hingehen kÃ¶nnte. Und wir bleiben dran, wir verlieren das Ziel nicht so schnell aus den Augen. Wenn sie die MÃ¶glichkeit haben zu arbeiten, machen sie das. Wir mÃ¼ssen sie dann immer dazu bringen, erst mal eine Ausbildung zu machen.

Da freut sich der Mann und denkt, 150 Euro mehr, super Sache. Dann kommt er her und ich sage dem: âJa, aber jetzt darf dein Kind nicht mehr in die Kita gehen.â Das heiÃt, das Kind lernt kein Deutsch. Es ist mit der Mutter zu Hause. Die Mutter lernt kein Deutsch. SpÃ¤ter kann das Kind nicht normal eingeschult werden. Wir produzieren Probleme in der Zukunft, die viel teurer sind als jetzt das Einsparen eines Kitaplatzes. "I have been advising at SPIKE since 2015. I think that a lot of the structures in the city are thinking that the things are normalizing, that they are going back to the way they were in the middle of 2014. They are thinking, âThe big rush is over. What do you all want? Everything is orderly now, blah, blah, blah.â But I donât think that. Through my advising, I have learned that itâs slowly getting more dramatic for those people who are here. Most of them start families, have kids. They come into this chaos where itâs not at all clear all the things you have to do. I think the push will get worse. And the city thinks that there arenât so many who are coming, but thatâs also not true because a lot of people who have been living in the area around Dresden are coming here. They also need help again and support.

People are successful when they in some way feel good here and have a plan, how they will make progress. I think there would be goals and ways but some of them havenât found them. I think there need to be more places like SPIKE. People need help with bureaucracy. I canât say, âBut you have to be able to do that.â If I see that a person canât do it â not because he is dumb or lazy, but because our bureaucratic system is a horror â I have to help him. We now have a lot of people who have an idea. They are doing a training program or first going to work. There is a lot of work by SPIKE behind that. You have to stay at it. We work with people with their best interests at heart and develop an idea together of what they could do. And we stay with it; we donât lose sight of the goal. If they have they opportunity to work, they do that. We have to convince them to do a training program.

I would wish that Dresden didnât think so short term. At the moment, for example, there arenât a lot of Kita places. The agency says to the fathers, who are usually the ones who deal with the bureaucracy, âLook, we have education funds from the state, take the 150 euros, they wonât be deducted from your Jobcenter account. Thatâs nice, isnât it?â The man is happy and thinks, â150 Euros more! Cool!â Then he comes here, and I tell him, âYeah, but now your child canât go to Kita anymore.â That mean that the child wonât be normally enrolled in school. We are producing problems in the future, which are much more expensive than the savings we get for one Kita place. I think thatâs dumb. The city makes a lot of decisions that I know will be problematic in the future. There is actually enough experience with the Turkish guest workers about what you could do wrong, but they arenât interested. A lot that is being done today is just as wrong."

"I volunteer with Stolpersteine e.V. and with âLaubegast is Colorful.â I came across the Stolpersteine project through my engagement with âLaubegast is Colorful,â because we care about the promotion of democracy and openness to the world and were thinking about what we could do to awaken an awareness of democracy and openness, of living together. And then we came to the idea of Stolpersteine. I then took over the research. That pulled me in. I researched the people who were victims of National Socialism in Laubegast. It really grabbed me. We then installed five Stolpsteine in Laubegast and Kleinschachwitz.

At the moment, it is becoming ever more clear why it is so important that we donât forget what happened. I personally believe -- and I know that is also the reaction of the relatives â that it has an importance. There was the Steinhard family in Dresden for whom we set 23 Stolpersteine. Only two of them survived, two brothers who emigrated to Canada. The brothers have been here in Dresden, and the grandchildren, and the great-grandchildren, and for them, it has an unbelievable meaning, that we memorialize the family at the place where they lived. One of the sons said to me, âThank you for bringing the Steinhart family back to life!â They had never talked about Dresden. They were totally finished with Dresden, they never wanted to have anything to do with Germany or Dresden again. And now, they come to Dresden. Basically, we have reconciled them with the city and also with the history of their own family. You really give people the names back at the place where they lived, from which they had to flee or were deported. Most of the Steinharts died in Auschwitz.

I like this image: If I want to read what is on a stone, then I have bend before the victim. The special thing is that itâs not about famous people â itâs about totally normal people, who lived there, who disappeared. You kind of bring back the people to the place where they lived."

"I applied for asylum around the time that a lot of refugees were arriving from Arab countries. I ended up in Heidenau. We were driven to a 'Baumarkt' that had been made into a huge dorm. There were around 800 of us. When we arrived, there was a bunch of people shouting and protesting. We had to get protection from the police. I didn't understand what was happening. The people in charge in the buses told us to close the curtains and try not to look through the windows. Everyone was grouped together in their different ethnic groups, and everyone could only communicate with their people. They separated us into religions too. They asked me, and I said I was Protestant, and they said they would put me with the Catholics. In the end, we are all Christians. I was together with all the black people. Itâs funny, but it happens to me everywhere. When a black person spots me, they greet me as if we had something in common, which we do -- our color.

I had to try to use the little English I knew. Maybe one thing we Venezuelans have in common is that we need to be in action. I can't sit around looking at Facebook. I tried to find ways to occupy myself. Cleaning up or doing something. In the end, all the security people and staff ended up liking me. I helped them organize all the newcomers. There is one thing I knew: I couldn't let myself fall into depression. It is very easy to become depressed when you are in such situation. Having so many people with different ethnicities in one room can be challenging. Once when we were queuing to get our food, some guys from Iraq exchanged some words with some others from Iran, and it ended up in a huge fight and the special police had to come in calm them down. It looked like in the movies, when the SWAT team breaks in.

Three months later, I was transferred to another camp here in Mickten. One of the volunteers (Sebastian) and I became good friends. He invited me to a jogging group, and we used to go running every Wednesday. I ran my first half marathon. I was very humbled by the experience, because an uncle of mine wanted to do the same back in Caracas, and one day he was killed while he was running because criminals wanted to steal his shoes. It's amazing how many opportunities you have to fulfill your dreams here.

Sebastian invited me to live at his place. He asked me about what I used to do for fun back in Venezuela, and I said I used to do fencing. He found me a club where I could exercise. They accepted me with open arms, offering me all the equipment. I have already been in four competitions.

Then I learned about a project called Paradiesisch Musizieren. I have been playing there every Thursday. I have had so much luck. I am very, very grateful. I am looking forward now to getting my credentials as a radiologist. I need to do a four-month course. Unfortunately, I canât do it here in Dresden. Another possibility for me would be to start another career as an emergency paramedic.

I am in a band here called EMBER/The Christopher Molina Trio, and we already recorded our first CD. I am pretty happy with my life right now."

media.description:
"Ich komme ursprÃ¼nglich aus Leipzig und wohne seit vier Jahren in Dresden. Ich bin hierher gezogen, um eine Ausbildung zur Tourismuskauffrau anzufangen. Fremde LÃ¤nder und Kulturen haben mich schon immer sehr interessiert und ich bin immer gern gereist. Ich dachte, das ist eine schÃ¶ne MÃ¶glichkeit, das zum Beruf zu machen.

Die franzÃ¶sische Kultur hat mich schon immer sehr interessiert, auch durch einen SchÃ¼leraustausch und eine Reise nach Paris. Deshalb habe ich mich nach dem Abi entschieden, fÃ¼r ein Jahr nach Frankreich zu ziehen und dort als Au-pair zu arbeiten. Danach bin ich noch nach Tansania gegangen, um an einer Vorschule als Volunteer zu arbeiten. Im Ausland gab es positive und negative Erfahrungen, wobei ich sagen muss, dass die negativen Erfahrungen eher in Frankreich waren. Das war 2015, als gerade Pegida auflebte. Gerade wenn ich gesagt habe, dass ich aus Ostdeutschland komme, wurde ich oft gefragt, ob ich ein Nazi oder sowas in die Richtung bin. FÃ¼r die war klar, dass ganz Ostdeutschland rechts angehaucht ist. Das sind natÃ¼rlich negative Erfahrungen, aber schÃ¶n ist es, wenn einfach Interesse von der anderen Seite da ist, etwas Ã¼ber dein Heimatland, deine Herkunft und deine Sprache zu erfahren.

Seit einem Jahr studiere ich an der TU Dresden sprach Literatur-, Sprach- und Kulturwissenschaften fÃ¼r FranzÃ¶sisch und im zweiten Teilbereich Kunstgeschichte, um mich weiter auf Frankreich zu spezialisieren. Neben dem Studium habe ich angefangen, mich ehrenamtlich bei Start with a friend zu engagieren, einem gemeinnÃ¼tzigen Verein, der Tandem-Partnerschaften zwischen Eingewanderten und Locals vermittelt. Seit zwei Monaten arbeite ich dort als Fellow; das ist mein Minijob neben dem Studium. So habe ich weiterhin Kontakt mit vielen internationalen Leuten und lerne immer mehr Ã¼ber fremde Kulturen.

Ich hatte mein Studium angefangen mit dem Hintergrund, weiter im Tourismus zu arbeiten. Gerade auch durch die derzeitige Situation ist mir aber bewusst geworden, dass Tourismus eine der ersten Sachen ist, die wegfÃ¤llt und nicht unbedingt lebensnotwendig ist. Ich hatte die Ausbildung aber auch angefangen, weil mich andere LÃ¤nder und Kulturen interessieren. Durch die Organisation habe ich gemerkt, dass es auch andere MÃ¶glichkeiten gibt, Kontakt zu diesen Kulturen aufzubauen. Ich weiÃ nicht, ob ich das hauptberuflich machen werde. Ich mÃ¶chte aber die Arbeit bei Start with a friend so lange wie mÃ¶glich machen. Vielleicht ergeben sich dadurch die neue Wege - wer weiÃ?"

Teil 1/2
--
"I am originally from Leipzig and have lived in Dresden for four years. I moved here to start training as a tourism management assistant. Foreign countries and cultures have always interested me a lot and I have always enjoyed traveling. I thought that this would be a great opportunity to make it my profession.

French culture has always interested me a lot, partly through a student exchange and a trip to Paris. That's why I decided to move to France for one year after my high-school graduation and work as an au-pair. Afterwards, I went to Tanzania to work as a volunteer at a pre-school. There were positive and negative experiences abroad, although I must say that the negative experiences were more in France. That was in 2015, when Pegida was coming to life. When I said that I came from East Germany, I was often asked if I was a Nazi or something like that. For them it was clear that the whole of East Germany is right-wing. These were negative experiences, of course, but it's nice when there is simply interest from someone else to find out something about your home country, your origin and your language.

I have been studying literature for a year, French linguistics and cultural studies and art history at the TU Dresden, in order to further specialize in France. Besides my studies, I started volunteering at Start with a Friend, a non-profit organization that arranges tandem partnerships between immigrants and locals. I have been working there for two months as a fellow; it is my mini-job alongside my studies. So I continue to have contact with many international people and learn more and more about foreign cultures.

I started my studies with the intention of continuing to work in tourism. But especially because of the current situation, I realized that tourism is one of the first things that is eliminated and that is not necessarily essential for life. But I had also started my studies because I am interested in other countries and cultures. Through the organization, I realized that there are also other possibilities to get involved with these cultures. I don't know if I will do this full-time. But I would like to do the work at Start with a Friend as long as possible. Maybe this will open up new opportunities - who knows?"

Part 1/2

"I had registered myself at Start with a Friend to get a tandem partner and then increasingly became part of the volunteer team. My own tandem partner grew up in Syria. We met at a Start with a Friend game night and then met a few times afterwards. Mostly we went to a bar or cafÃ© in the new town. By now, we have many mutual friends, so that we usually don't meet up as a pair but in a group. We have also gone dancing or organized game nights together.

Common interests are very important at Start with a Friend. That's why we get to know everyone personally. That way we can match people so that they have similar interests or hobbies. We have people of all ages. At the moment, there are many young immigrant families who have registered with us. So we are currently looking for young German families. But we also have older applicants on both sides. We have people from twenty to sixty years old.

Before Corona, ten to twenty people always came to the community events. You can also attend them without your tandem partner. At the moment, we can only invite a maximum of ten people, but the interest is still there. We still arrange around five tandems every month. Even in the most difficult times, things continued to go on.

Although I am German and come from Leipzig, it was so hard to settle into Dresden and meet people. If you don't know anyone and have no contacts, it is very difficult to make friends in Germany. It usually only works through people you already know. You rarely talk to someone on the street whom you don't know at all. That's exactly what I wanted to try to change - that you can meet strangers. With Start with a Friend, the first step is already taken for you a little bit. I think no matter where you go, it's always important to have people and friends in order to really feel at home. Without that, no city is really beautiful. Where you feel at home is rarely related to the city itself, but rather to the people you have there."

Wenn man niemanden kennt und keinen Kontakt hat, ist es in Deutschland sehr schwer, Freunde zu finden. Es funktioniert meistens nur Ã¼ber Leute, die man schon kennt. Man spricht selten jemanden auf der StraÃe an, den man noch gar nicht kennt. 
Genau das wollte ich versuchen zu Ã¤ndern - dass man fremde Leute kennenlernen kann. Bei Start with a friend wird dir der erste Schritt ein bisschen abgenommen. Ich glaube, egal wo man hinkommt ist es immer wichtig, Personen und Freunde zu haben, um sich wirklich zuhause zu fÃ¼hlen. Ohne das ist jede Stadt nicht schÃ¶n. Es hÃ¤ngt selten mit der Stadt an sich zusammen, wo man sich zu Hause fÃ¼hlt, sondern eher mit den Personen die man hat."
--
"I had registered myself at Start with a Friend to get a tandem partner and then increasingly became part of the volunteer team. My own tandem partner grew up in Syria. We met at a Start with a Friend game night and then met a few times afterwards. Mostly we went to a bar or cafÃ© in the new town. By now, we have many mutual friends, so that we usually don't meet up as a pair but in a group. We have also gone dancing or organized game nights together.

Common interests are very important at Start with a Friend. That's why we get to know everyone personally. That way we can match people so that they have similar interests or hobbies. We have people of all ages. At the moment, there are many young immigrant families who have registered with us. So we are currently looking for young German families. But we also have older applicants on both sides. We have people from twenty to sixty years old.

Before Corona, ten to twenty people always came to the community events. You can also attend them without your tandem partner. At the moment, we can only invite a maximum of ten people, but the interest is still there. We still arrange around five tandems every month. Even in the most difficult times, things continued to go on.

Although I am German and come from Leipzig, it was so hard to settle into Dresden and meet people. If you don't know anyone and have no contacts, it is very difficult to make friends in Germany. It usually only works through people you already know. You rarely talk to someone on the street whom you don't know at all. That's exactly what I wanted to try to change - that you can meet strangers. With Start with a Friend, the first step is already taken for you a little bit. I think no matter where you go, it's always important to have people and friends in order to really feel at home. Without that, no city is really beautiful. Where you feel at home is rarely related to the city itself, but rather to the people you have there."

Ich kann es mir nicht anders vorstellen als Theater und Ruine zusammen. Ich habe in den letzten Jahren eine ganze Reihe von Vorstellungen dort gesehen. Das ist schon eine mentale Verbundenheit mit dem Ort. Es ist niemals konventionell, immer sehr lustig und auch ein bisschen progressiv. Vielleicht stÃ¶rt das so manchen, der als Kulturschaffender in der Stadt sitzt.

Jetzt hat man denen zum 31.12. den Mietvertrag gekÃ¼ndigt. Das habe ich vorige Woche bei einer Vorstellung von âFaust rockt!â erfahren. Ich habe noch wÃ¤hrend der Vorstellung eine Petition geschrieben. Ich habe an diesem Abend mit den Leuten vom Theater gesprochen und es hat mich einfach furchtbar geÃ¤rgert. Ich muss zugeben, dass meine Petition im Moment noch ein bisschen schwÃ¤chelt. Von dem Quorum, das Openpetition berechnet hat, bin ich noch weit entfernt. Das ganze lÃ¤uft bis zum 24.11. Ich mÃ¶chte jetzt auch den auf den Vorstand des Vereins zugehen und mal gucken, ob man etwas gemeinsam macht. Die Theaterleute beschrÃ¤nken sich auf ihre Unterschriftensammlung an der Abendkasse. Ich hatte die Hoffnung, dass eine Online-Petition mehr ermÃ¶glicht.

Die Stadt will wohl, dass die Ruine noch mehr ins Viertel eingebunden wird, also noch viele andere kulturelle Institutionen daran partizipieren kÃ¶nnen. Das findet aber im Moment schon statt; es ist nicht nur das Theater in der Ruine, sondern auch verschiedene Vereine aus dem Viertel, so dass es das, was die eigentlich als Konzept haben wollen, schon gibt. Das St.-Pauli-Theater hat 20.000 Besucher pro Jahr; das ist ja nicht klein. Ich finde, jetzt muss man sich an einen Tisch setzen. Mein Wunsch wÃ¤re, dass das Theater die FederfÃ¼hrung behÃ¤lt, dass man einen festen Punkt hat - das Theater - und dann drumherum andere gemeinnÃ¼tzige kreative Geschichten bastelt.
Man sagt ja so schÃ¶n, dass die Hoffnung zuletzt stirbt. Ich bin auch bereit, noch weitere Schritte zu unternehmen. Als nÃ¤chstes mÃ¶chte ich Herrn Hilbert anschreiben und mal gucken, ob man dort ein bisschen sticheln kann. Ich glaube, dass die Chance da ist. Es gibt in Dresden nicht A-Kultur und B-Kultur, sondern es gibt Kultur, und da gehÃ¶rt eben sehr viel dazu. Ich glaube, die Leute vom St. Pauli machen da einfach einen coolen Job. Die Inszenierungen, die die machen, fernab vom Mainstream, finde ich schon total genial. Ich bin ein absoluter Fan und das ist meine Triebfeder. Kein Mensch im Stadtrat wÃ¼rde auf die Idee kommen, dem Sempernopernensemble oder dem Staatsschauspielhaus den Mietvertrag zu kÃ¼ndigen. Aber beim St-Pauli-Theater, so einer kleinen Klitsche, traut man sich das eben.

1.000 Unterschriften ist jetzt mein erklÃ¤rter Meilenstein. Ich glaube, dass das realistisch ist. Und wenn ich mit tausend Unterschriften zum Vorstand des St. Pauli hingehen kann, dann ist das schon etwas."

https://www.openpetition.de/petition/online/sankt-pauli-theater-dresden-darf-nicht-sterben
--
"I have been going to the St. Pauli ruins for many years. For me, St. Pauli-Ruine and St. Pauli-Theater have always been a single entity. I can't imagine it any other way than the theater and ruin together. I have seen a whole series of performances there in recent years. I already have a mental attachment to the place. It is never conventional, always very funny and also a bit progressive. Maybe that disturbs a lot of people who work for the city in the cultural sector.

Now they have been given notice that their lease is terminated as of 31.12. I found out last week during a performance of "Faust rockt!" I wrote a petition during the performance. I talked to the people from the theater that evening, and I was so annoyed. I have to admit that my petition is still a bit weak at the moment. I am still far away from the necessary quorum as calculated by Openpetition. The whole thing runs until November 24. I would like to approach the board of directors of the association and see if we can do something together. The theater people have limited themselves to collecting signatures at the box office. I had the hope that an online petition would make more signatures possible.

The city says it wants the ruin to be even more integrated into the district, so that many other cultural institutions can participate. But that's already happening at the moment; it's not only the theater in the ruins, but also various associations from the neighborhood, so that what they want as a concept actually already exists. The St.-Pauli-Theater has 20,000 visitors per year; that's not small. I think you have to sit down at a table now. My wish would be that the theater stays in charge, that you have a fixed point - the theater - and then build other non-profit creative narratives around it.
They say so beautifully that hope dies last. I am also prepared to take further steps. Next, I would like to write to Mr. Hilbert and see if you can achieve something there. I believe that the chance is there. In Dresden, there isn't A-culture and B-culture; there is culture, and there is a lot of it. I think the people from St. Pauli do a cool job there. I think the productions they do, far removed from the mainstream, are totally brilliant. I am an absolute fan and that is my driving force. No one on the city council would think of terminating the lease with the Sempernopernensemble or the Staatsschauspielhaus. But they dare to do so at the St-Pauli-Theater.

1,000 signatures is my declared goal. I think that's realistic. And if I can go to the St. Pauli board of directors with a thousand signatures, then that is something."

"Ich komme aus SÃ¼ddeutschland, aus der NÃ¤he vom Bodensee. Ich bin dort aber schon nicht mehr, seitdem ich neunzehn war. Ich habe achteinhalb Jahre lang in der Tourismusbranche Saison gearbeitet, in Ãsterreich, in der Schweiz, in Australien. Es war einfach ein anderes Leben. Zu der Zeit hat es mir sehr gut gefallen. Jetzt kÃ¶nnte ich es mir nicht mehr vorstellen. Es ist auch schÃ¶n, eine Wohnung zu haben, Freunde zu haben. Das kann man nicht, wenn man jedes halbe Jahr woanders ist.

Nach Dresden bin ich damals gekommen, weil meine Freundin hier studiert hat. Wir haben uns in Davos kennengelernt. FÃ¼r sie war klar, dass sie studieren geht, und ich bin einfach mitgekommen und hÃ¤ngen geblieben. Jetzt bin ich seit vier Jahren wieder in Dresden; davor waren wir schon mal drei Jahre hier, als sie studiert hat. Dresden hat mir sehr gut gefallen, deswegen sind wir auch wieder zurÃ¼ckgekommen. Bevor ich hierher gezogen bin, hatte ich keine Ahnung, wie es hier Ã¼berhaupt ist. Ich war noch nie in Dresden gewesen. Ich hatte ehrlich gesagt auch ein Vorurteil, was sich so aber gar nicht bewahrheitet hat. Man kennt halt die Bilder. Wenn man die Medien anschaut, sieht man, was hier montags abgeht, und man denkt, hier laufen nur rechte Leute rum, was aber gar nicht der Fall ist. NatÃ¼rlich hast du das, aber ich glaube nicht mehr oder weniger als in anderen StÃ¤dten. Es fÃ¤llt eben hier ein bisschen mehr auf, das ist der Unterschied. Im sÃ¼ddeutschen Raum sind es wahrscheinlich genauso viele, aber es wird nicht so offen darÃ¼ber geredet und man sieht sie nicht so oft.

Ich verstehe nicht, warum das immer noch in der Altstadt ist. Meinungsfreiheit und Versammlungsfreiheit â ja, aber man kÃ¶nnte das auch im Ostragehege oder am Flughafen stattfinden lassen. Dieser Umzug jedesmal - wie viele Polizisten da sind. Das sind ja alles Steuergelder, die dort verprasst werden. Oder von mir aus im Stadion, da kÃ¶nnen sie im Stadion einmal rumlaufen, das ist doch super und wÃ¤re viel, viel einfacher als jedes mal die komplette Altstadt abzusperren. Auch fÃ¼r den Tourismus ist das blÃ¶d. Jedem Touristen sagt man montags, geht einfach nicht hin. Ich finde, das gibt ein komplett falsches Bild von Dresden ab."

Teil 1 von 2
--
"I come from southern Germany, from the vicinity of Lake Constance. But I have not been there since I was nineteen. I have worked in the tourism industry for eight and a half years, in Austria, Switzerland and Australia. It was simply a different life. At the time I liked it very much. I could not imagine it any more now. It's also nice to have an apartment, to have friends. You can't do that when you move somewhere else every six months.

I came to Dresden because my girlfriend studied here. We met in Davos. It was clear to her that she was going to go to university, and I just came along and got stuck. Now I've been back in Dresden for four years; before that we were here for three years when she was going to school. I really liked Dresden, that's why we came back. Before I moved here, I had no idea what it was like here. I had never been to Dresden before. To be honest, I also had prejudices, but they weren't really true. You just know the pictures. If you look at the media, you see what goes on here on Mondays, and you think that only right-wing people are running around here, which is not the case at all. Of course there are some, but I don't think any more or less than in other cities. It's a bit more noticeable here, that's the difference. In southern Germany, there are probably just as many, but people don't talk about it so openly and you don't see them as often.

I don't understand why it's still in the Altstadt. Freedom of opinion and freedom of assembly - yes, but you could also have it in the Ostragehege or at the airport. This parade every time - how many policemen are there. This is all tax money that is being squandered there. Or in the stadium, they can walk around the stadium, that's great and would be much, much easier than closing off the entire Altstadt. It's also stupid for tourism. Every tourist is told, "just don't go thereon Mondays." I think it gives a completely mistaken picture of Dresden."

Part 1 of 2

media.description:
"Die Kneipe haben wir jetzt ein bisschen lÃ¤nger als ein Jahr. Wir wohnen Luftlinie fÃ¼nfhundert Meter von hier. Es war Zufall, dass wir das hier gesehen haben. Wir sind mit dem Hund spazieren gegangen und haben gesehen, dass es frei war. Es war eine ganz spontane Entscheidung. Ich arbeite jetzt seit neunzehn Jahren in der Gastronomie, war aber immer nur angestellt. Wir haben gesagt, was fehlt, sind Kneipen. Seit dieses Rauchergesetz rauskam, ist immer mehr von diesem Kneipenfeeling kaputt gegangen, was extrem schade ist. Wir finden es schÃ¶n, wenn man sich mit Leuten trifft - oder auch alleine ist - und zum Quatschen herkommt und vielleicht ein bisschen trinkt und eine Kleinigkeit isst. Die Gesellschaft steht im Vordergrund. Man geht hin, um Leute zu treffen und einen schÃ¶nen Abend zu haben.

In der Neustadt braucht das niemand mehr, in Pieschen auch nicht. Dort gibt es genÃ¼gend. Wenn wir etwas trinken gehen wollten, sind wir immer weg von hier. Das ist doch schade. Man wohnt hier in einem Viertel, und dann ist es doch schÃ¶n, wenn man spontan sagen kann, man geht noch etwas trinken. Unser Konzept ist regional angehaucht, wenn Fleisch, dann regional und gutes Fleisch. Weniger ist immer mehr. Wir haben kleine Brauereien, wir haben keine Konzerne. Deswegen bieten wir diese typischen GetrÃ¤nke nicht an - wir haben kein Radeberger, keine Coca-Cola, keine Fanta. Uns ist es wichtig, gute Produkte zu haben.

Vom Grundprinzip haben wir schon Stammpublikum. Gruna ist ja nicht so groÃ. Aber das schÃ¶ne ist, und das sagen die Leute auch, dass die sich im Normalfall nie begegnet wÃ¤ren oder nie miteinander reden wÃ¼rden. Das ist schÃ¶n. Es geht darum, die Leute aus seinem Umfeld kennenzulernen, damit es nicht nur anonym ist."

Teil 2/2
--
"We have had the pub for a little longer than a year now. We live five hundred meters from here as the crow flies. It was a coincidence that we saw it. We went for a walk with the dog and saw that it was for rent. It was a very spontaneous decision. I've been working in the restaurant business for nineteen years now, but I've always been worked for someone else. We said what was missing from the area were pubs. Since this smoking law came out, more and more of that pub feeling has been destroyed, which is a real pity. We think it's nice to meet up with people - or to be alone - and come here to chat and maybe drink a little and eat a little something. People are in the foreground. You go there to meet people and have a nice evening.

Nobody needs that in the Neustadt any more, not even in Pieschen. There are enough places there. If we wanted to go for a drink, we would always leave the neighborhood. That is a pity. You live in a neighborhood here, and then it's nice to be able to say spontaneously that you're going for a drink. Our concept is regional. If meat, then regional and good quality meat. Less is always more. We serve beer from small breweries, we don't have corporations. That's why we don't offer the typical drinks - we don't have a Radeberger, no Coca-Cola, no Fanta. It is important to us to have good products.

We already have a regular audience from the basic principle. Gruna is not so big. But the nice thing is, and people say so, that normally they would never have met each other or would never talked to each other. That is nice. It's about getting to know people from your own community, so it's not just anonymous."

Part 2/2

"Ich habe mein Volontariat beim Deutschlandfunk gemacht und danach 2015 in Dresden angefangen. Seitdem bin ich hier der Korrespondent fÃ¼rs Deutschlandradio und berichte aus ganz Sachsen fÃ¼r die drei Programme Deutschlandfunk, Deutschlandfunk Kultur und Deutschlandfunk Nova. Ich hatte vorher schon Beziehungen nach Sachsen und auch nach Dresden. Deswegen hatte ich schon erste EindrÃ¼cke gesammelt und wusste, dass Dresden ein bisschen komplex ist und auch mit Komplexen behaftet. Als die Stelle ausgeschrieben wurde, bin ich auch noch einmal her gefahren und habe es mir angeguckt.

Als ich kam, war Pegida schon ein Jahr alt und so ein bisschen am Abflauen. Es war nur noch ein lokales, hÃ¶chstens noch ein regionales Thema. Die Auseinandersetzung dort, wie das ablÃ¤uft, hat mich immer sprachlos gemacht, wenn man dahin geht und Fragen stellt, aber auch wie die Leute sich anbrÃ¼llen, wie man miteinander umgeht, die Auseinandersetzung innerhalb der Stadtgesellschaft. In keiner anderen Stadt hat sich das so gehalten. Das ist schon sehr dresdenspezifisch, auf der einen Seite die Leute, die zu Pegida gehen, auf der anderen Seite, dass es hier nie so eine groÃe Mehrheit gegeben hat, die gesagt hat, wir haben keinen Bock drauf, wir wollen das nicht. Stattdessen hat man lange versucht, VerstÃ¤ndnis zu haben. Jetzt haben vor ein paar Monaten die CDU und die FDP angefangen, mitzudemonstrieren. Das wÃ¤re in anderen StÃ¤dten ganz normal von Anfang an gewesen.

Ich bin am Anfang immer hingegangen - schon bewusst mit einem anderen Kollegen, damit wir mindestens zu zweit sind. Ich bin auch in unangenehme Situationen geraten. Man steht da irgendwo und plÃ¶tzlich behauptet jemand, man dÃ¼rfe dort nicht sein und keine Interviews fÃ¼hren. So eine Dynamik entwickelt sich ganz schnell, dann kommen fÃ¼nf, sechs Leute, die rufen dann die Polizisten, die nicht wissen, was die Rechte der Medienvertreter sind. Ich bin auch Ã¶fter beschimpft worden. Aber als ich hier anfing - Ende 2015 -, war das grÃ¶Ãte ja schon vorbei. Ich habe da weniger abgekriegt als zum Beispiel meine VorgÃ¤ngerin, die richtig heftig beschimpft wurde und wo es auch einen Gerichtsprozess gab, bei dem jemand verurteilt worden ist. Auf der anderen Seite ist es so, wenn man sich zehnmal eine Abfuhr geholt hat, findet man auch jemanden, der einem eine halbe Stunde erzÃ¤hlt, warum er da hingeht, warum er das alles macht. In dem Moment hÃ¶re ich mir das alles an. Es ist natÃ¼rlich oft schwierig nachzuvollziehen.

Auf der anderen Seite gibt es eine hohe Politisierung, die man nicht in vielen anderen StÃ¤dten hat. Die Leute setzen sich ein fÃ¼r etwas oder gegen etwas. Und es ist schon eine sehr schÃ¶ne Stadt, die Wege sind sehr kurz, es gibt sehr viele Leute, die sehr engagiert sind. Genau wie es viele Leute gibt, die sehr anstrengend sind, gibt es auch viele Leute, die nett sind."

Teil 1/2
--
"I did my internship at Deutschlandfunk and then started in Dresden in 2015 as the correspondent for Deutschlandradio here. I report from all over Saxony for three programs Deutschlandfunk, Deutschlandfunk Kultur and Deutschlandfunk Nova. I already had connections to Saxony and Dresden. That's why I already had first impressions and knew that Dresden is a bit complex and also has its complexes. When the job was advertised, I drove back here and took a look at it.

When I came, Pegida was already one year old and a little bit slowed down. It was only a local, at most regional issue. The discussion there, how things go, always left me speechless when I went to the demonstrations and asked questions -- how people shout at each other, how they deal with each other, the debate within the urban society. In no other city has it been like that. It's very specific to Dresden -- on the one hand, the people who go to Pegida, on the other hand, the fact that there has never been such a large majority that said we don't like, we don't want it. Instead, people have long tried to be understanding. Now, a few months ago, the CDU and the FDP started to join in the demonstration. That would have been normal in other cities from the beginning.

I always went at the beginning - intentionally with another colleague so that there would be at least two of us. I got into some unpleasant situations. You're standing there somewhere and suddenly someone claims that you're not allowed to be there and conduct interviews. A dynamic like that develops very quickly, then five or six people come along and call the police, who don't know what the rights of media representatives are. I have also been insulted often. But when I started here - at the end of 2015 - the worst was already over. I got less abuse than my predecessor, for example, who was insulted really badly and where there was also a court case in which someone was convicted. However, if you've been rejected ten times, you'll find someone who tells you for half an hour why he goes to the demonstration, why he does all this. At that moment I listen to it all. Of course it is often difficult to understand.

On the other hand, there is a high degree of politicization, which you don't have in many other cities. People stand up for something or against something. And it's a very beautiful city, the distances are very short, there are a lot of people who are very involved. Just as there are many people who are very involved, there are also many people who are nice."

Part 1/2

"Ich habe 2019 angefangen, mich zu engagieren. Am 15. MÃ¤rz waren die ersten Schulestreiks in Dresden, bei denen ich dabei war. Danach war ich auch noch zur anderen Demos. Mir ist das wichtig, weil ich mÃ¶chte, dass das Thema Klimagerechtigkeit in der Gesellschaft mehr wahrgenommen wird. Corona ist eine Krise, die jetzt ist, die vielleicht noch die nÃ¤chsten Jahre sein wird, aber die Klimakrise wird auch nach Corona weitergehen und ist nicht umkehrbar.

Das ist nicht nur ein Camp von Fridays for Future, sondern auch von anderen Klimabewegungen, zum Beispiel Ende GelÃ¤nde. Viele Einzelpersonen, die sich in Dresden um Klimagerechtigkeit sorgen, sind hier dabei. Wir wollen mit unserem Klimacamp vor allem Aufmerksamkeit. Wir wollen gerne mit Menschen ins GesprÃ¤ch kommen. Wir hoffen, dass wir hier in der Altstadt eine andere Zielgruppe an Menschen erreichen. AuÃerdem wollen wir das in den Stadtrat bringen. Wir wollen mit Politikern ins GesprÃ¤ch kommen. 

Deshalb haben wir hier auch den Platz nah am Rathaus gewÃ¤hlt. Wir mÃ¶chten einfach zeigen, dass wir hier sind und durchhalten, auch wenn uns zum Beispiel durch die VersammlungsbehÃ¶rde Steine in den Weg gelegt werden, dass wir trotzdem weitermachen und zu mehr als nur Demos bereit sind.

Ich finde es total schade, dass es uns von der Stadt so schwer gemacht wird. Das hier ist eine Dauerkundgebung. Uns wurde untersagt, hier zu schlafen. Ich finde, da wird unser Recht auf kÃ¶rperliche Unversehrtheit eingeschrÃ¤nkt."
--
"I started getting active in 2019. On March 15th, there were the first school strikes in Dresden, and I was involved. After that, I also went to the other demos. This is important to me because I want the issue of climate justice to be more visible in society. Corona is a crisis that is now, that will perhaps be for the next few years, but the climate crisis will continue after Corona and is not reversible.

This is not only an encampment of Fridays for Future, but also of other climate movements, for example Ende GelÃ¤nde. Many individuals who are concerned about climate justice in Dresden are here. With our climate camp, we want to attract attention above all. We want to get into conversation with people. We hope to reach a different target group of people here in the Altstadt. We also want to bring this to the city council. We want to get into conversation with politicians. That's why we chose the place close to the town hall. We simply want to show that we are here and that we will hold out even if the authorities are putting obstacles in our way, that we will continue and are ready for more than just demonstrations.

I think it is really too bad that the city is making it so difficult for us. This is going to be a long-term demonstration. We were forbidden to sleep here. I think this is a restriction to our right to physical integrity."

Ich denke, das hÃ¤ngt auch damit zusammen, dass es keine allgemeine europÃ¤ische LÃ¶sung gibt, dass es in Europa viele LÃ¤nder gibt, die sich komplett verweigern und niemanden aufnehmen wollen. Und die Rhetorik von der AfD zum Beispiel basiert ja auch sehr auf Angst und auf Hetze - dass die Menschen, die anders sind, unserer Kultur irgendwie schaden wÃ¼rden.

Das sehe ich persÃ¶nlich Ã¼berhaupt nicht so. Ich denke, jeder hat das Recht, dort zu leben, wo er gern leben will. Das Recht auf Asyl ist im Grundgesetz festgeschrieben. "I have been working at Mission Lifeline for the last two years. I did a little crewing and have done a lot of project organization. In June 2018, I was on the MV Lifeline mission, when it had to wait seven days for a safe haven off Malta with 234 rescued people on board. The boat was only 32 meters long and almost 8 meters wide. After the mission the ship was confiscated for about a year and is now unfortunately no longer in use.

At the beginning of the year, I thought about the fact that there is no longer a sea-bridge local group in Dresden. The group, which existed in 2018, unfortunately broke up after the city council refused to declare Dresden a safe haven. We have made it our mission to tackle the topic anew and to convince the politicians once again that the idea is actually a good one. On the one hand, we want to make a declaration of solidarity for refugees, and on the other hand, we want Dresden to be prepared to accept more refugees than the KÃ¶nigsteiner quota dictates. The need that exists in camps like Moria or generally on the Aegean islands, and among other places, is so great that the people should actually be evacuated immediately. We believe that there is enough space and resources in Germany.

If you know a little bit about the political situation here in the city, you know it's not that easy. It has relatively little to do with being open to the world. There are already more than 170 cities and municipalities in Germany that have agreed to be a safe haven. But then there is also the federal level on top, which has the last word in politics and which does not. The political will to do so has not yet fully arrived in Germany. I think this is also related to the fact that there is no general European response, that there are many countries in Europe that refuse to accept anyone at all. I think it is a great pity that the basic idea of solidarity does not exist. The measures are becoming more and more restrictive. The political situation is so inflamed. Obviously people are afraid, there is a great fear of the foreign. There have been many changes in the last few years, which also has to do with the people who have arrived here. And the rhetoric of the AfD, for example, is also based on fear and agitation - that people who are different would somehow harm our culture.

I personally don't see it that way at all. I think everyone has the right to live where they want to live. The right to asylum is enshrined in the German constitution. Actually, the Federal Republic should be a role model there. The streams of refugees are not diminishing. There are now 70 million who are displaced. Of these, only a small percentage go to other countries. With climate change and the economic conditions that currently prevail, this number will increase. People will probably move more and more to the North. It has always been the case, throughout world history, that people have been on the move. I think we should rather be concerned with preparing ourselves, preparing our society and raising awareness that cultures will mix. We will not get around it. It's better to be prepared for it and approach it with a little understanding and also empathy, rather than with rejection and border fences or walls."

It's a practice evening that is open to everyone who wants to learn tango or who already knows a little bit about it. It should also be an intervention in public space to promote life on the street.

I like the tango very much. I see it as a danced embrace, which means it is a lot about communication. I like the music, and I think the dance is very elegant. For me, the beauty is that you can dance Tango Argentino anywhere in the world because it is so widespread. You have a shared language, a way of communicating even with people whose language you don't speak, and with whom you can experience beautiful moments, communicating in dance. My goal is to make the tango democratic, so that people who cannot afford tango lessons can still easily access the dance and the culture. I believe that it is something beautiful and enriching."

Wir sind durch das ganze Land gezogen und ich habe Texte vorgelesen. im Jahr 1989 haben wir im FrÃ¼hjahr noch ein Programm gemacht, das hieÃ âMorgen hau'n wir auf die Paukeâ, da wusste noch niemand, was im Herbst kommen wÃ¼rde. Im Laufe des Jahres 1989 haben sich die Texte, die wir gesungen haben, einer nach dem anderen erledigt."

"I developed my career aspirations in high school. We had a vocational training program, at that time all high school students had to do a vocational training course. That's how I became a bricklayer in the German Democratic Republic. The real bricklayers showed us how to do it. They almost laughed themselves to death that these intellectuals were coming to them. They did things with us that you can't imagine. For example, we had to catch chickens from dawn until dusk because a friend of our boss needed someone to catch his chickens. We tried for eight hours to get the plaster stuck up there, and the workers soon laughed themselves silly. I told all this to a journalist, and he made a whole page out of it in the Junge Welt. After the summer, we had a new foreman and a new construction site, and we were trained properly. That was my motivation to become a journalist. I wanted to change something in the GDR.

"Ich bin zu Jens Reich zum Neuen Forum gegangen und habe gefragt, ob sie Journalisten brauchen. Die machten gerade so ein kleines BlÃ¤ttchen. Ich bin dort mit hin, und dann wurde die Zeitung âDie Andereâ gegrÃ¼ndet. Dort wurde ich der Chefredakteur, aber nur, weil ich der einzige Journalist war. Das hat sich dann aber auch wieder erledigt und ich war arbeitslos. Irgendwann kam in Berlin die Lene Voigt auf, die grÃ¶Ãte Dichterin sÃ¤chsischer Sprache. Ich habe angefangen, Lene-Voigt-Programme zu machen. So bin ich bis vor einiger Zeit mit Lene-Voigt-Programmen durchs Land gezogen. Ich war zum Beispiel viel in Rehakliniken. Es war sehr schÃ¶n, den Menschen, die es gerade schwer haben, mal ein bisschen eine Freude zu bereiten. Ich habe Lieder gesungen und Texte vorgetragen. Das war wunderbar.

Ich habe den Eindruck, dass ich als Journalist einen guten Ãberblick Ã¼ber den Teil der deutschen Geschichte zur Wendezeit habe. Ich war 1989 in Berlin und habe bei allen diesen groÃen Veranstaltungen mitgemacht. Wir, das heiÃt wir vom Neuen Forum und auch die anderen, wollten damals eigentlich was anderes. Wir wollten eine bessere DDR, wir wollten nicht diese schnelle Wiedervereinigung, die auch ganz viel Schlimmes gebracht hat. Ich bin damals von Berlin aus zu meinen Auftritten nach Sachsen gefahren, und der wichtigste Satz, den ich nach 1990 Ã¼berall gehÃ¶rt habe, war: âSo haben wir das nicht gewollt:â Ganz viele Leute haben ihre Arbeit verloren, die sie ein Leben lang hatten. Viele haben keine Arbeit wieder gefunden und waren plÃ¶tzlich arbeitslos. Das konnten die sich vorher nicht vorstellen.

Ich hatte mal ein Erlebnis, das mich ein bisschen dazu gebracht hat, die Pegida-Demos zu verstehen. Ich war mal auf einer Anti-Pegida-Demo und bin mal durch diese Polizeiwagen durch zu der richtigen Demo hin, um mir das anzusehen. Danach bin ich zur Haltestelle gegangen. Dort saÃ neben mir eine alte Frau und hat gesagt: âJetzt geht das schon wieder los! Dresden ist zweimal schon zerdroschen worden. Und jetzt kommen diese AuslÃ¤nder. Nee, das ist doch furchtbar!â Da habe ich das ein bisschen verstanden - es ist eine groÃe Angst, die dahinter steckt. Dadurch ist die AfD in den letzten fÃ¼nf Jahren grÃ¶Ãer geworden. Das ist schon schlimm."

--
"I went to Jens Reich at the New Forum and asked if they needed journalists. They were just making a little leaflet. I joined them there, and then the newspaper "Die Andere" was founded. I became the chief editor there, but only because I was the only journalist. But then that was all over, and I was unemployed. At some point, Lene Voigt, the greatest poet of the Saxon language, came up in Berlin. I started doing Lene Voigt programs. So I travelled the country with Lene-Voigt programs until recently. For example, I spent a lot of time in rehabilitation clinics. It was very nice to bring a little joy to people who are having a hard time at the moment. I sang songs and performed texts. That was wonderful.

I think that as a journalist I have a good overview of German history at the time of the fall of the Berlin Wall. I was in Berlin in 1989 and took part in all these big events. We, that is, we from the New Forum and the others, actually wanted something different back then. We wanted a better GDR, we didn't want a quick reunification, which also brought a lot of bad things. At that time I drove from Berlin to Saxony for my performances, and the most important sentence I heard everywhere after 1990 was: "This is not what we wanted." Quite a few people lost their jobs, which they had had for a lifetime. Many did not find work again and were suddenly unemployed. They couldn't imagine anything like that before.

I once had an experience that made me understand the Pegida demonstrations a bit. I went to an anti-Pegida demo once and went through these police cars to the actual demo to see it. After that I went to the bus stop. There was an old woman sitting next to me who said: "Here we go again! Dresden has already been battered twice. And now these foreigners are coming. No, it is terrible!" So I understood a little bit - there is a great fear behind it. As a result, the AfD has grown larger in the last five years. That is certainly bad."

Ich bin sehr zufrieden in Deutschland. In meinem Land ist es ganz anders als hier. Hier leben alle Leute zusammen. In Pakistan leben die reichen Leute in ihren eigenen Bezirken und bestimmen Ã¼ber Kultur, Politik, Religion und die Armee. Das gehÃ¶rt dort alles zusammen. Hier ist es so: wenn man arbeiten geht und das gut macht, kann man fÃ¼r sich selbst bestimmen. In Pakistan geht das aber nicht. Dort ist alles verboten. Man kann nicht frei in der Ãffentlichkeit reden. Der Staat und die ReligiÃ¶sen entscheiden alles. Die Macht liegt bei einer kleinen Gruppe von Leuten. Frauen haben gar keine Rechte. Das ist eine komplett andere Welt. Mir ist wichtig, dass der Staat gut funktioniert, und das ist in Deutschland so. Hier funktioniert es viel besser als in den meisten anderen LÃ¤ndern.

Meine Frau ist jetzt auch sehr glÃ¼cklich. Meine Kinder kÃ¶nnen jetzt lernen, was sie wollen, nicht das, was diese Leute entscheiden. FÃ¼r mich ist das total in Ordnung, wenn  sie machen, was sie mÃ¶chten. Wenn sie erwachsen sind, kÃ¶nnen Sie selbst entscheiden. Ich mÃ¶chte mit meiner Familie hier bleiben und in Frieden leben. Mein Sohn ist sechs Jahre alt. Er sagt: âIch gehe nicht zurÃ¼ck nach Pakistan. Es gibt dort keinen Spielplatz und man wird in der Schule geschlagen.â Er hat Angst. Er ist ein Kind. Aber ich bin ein erwachsener Mensch und denke noch mehr Ã¼ber dieses Thema nach."

"I am from Pakistan. I have been in Germany for ten years. I came as an asylum seeker. My first application was rejected, but the second application was accepted. I am married and have two children, a daughter and a son.

I am very happy in Germany. In my country it is very different than here. Here everyone lives together. In Pakistan, the rich people live in their own districts and control culture, politics, religion and the army. It all belongs together there. Here if you go to work and do it well, you can decide for yourself. But in Pakistan that is not possible. Everything is prohibited there. You cannot speak freely in public. The state and the religious leaders decide everything. The power lies with a small group of people. Women have no rights at all. It is a completely different world. It is important to me that the state functions well, and that is the case in Germany. Here it works much better than in most other countries.

My wife is very happy now too. My children can now learn what they want, not what these people decide. For me it is totally okay if they do what they want. When they are grown up, they can decide for themselves. I want to stay here with my family and live in peace. My son is six years old. He says: "I am not going back to Pakistan. There are no playgrounds there and you get hit at school." He is afraid. He is a child. But I'm an adult and I have thought more about this subject."

"I am 64 years old and moved to Dresden five years ago. I came here from Berlin. Berlin is a big city, and in everyday life, it is too anonymous and people are lonely. A small city like Dresden is a bit more tranquil. I used to come here a lot, I worked here, and I always liked Dresden. It's also only two hours away from Berlin.

But I have also experienced a little provincialism here. Fortunately I live here in the Neustadt. I can always go for a walk with my dog here on the Elbe. There is no atmosphere like it in Berlin, everything is a bit more condensed there. There are also beautiful places there, but Dresden has the Elbe meadows, which always open my heart.

What I miss about Berlin are the nice, uncomplicated people. Everyone here has such narrow minds - or many people, particularly the older ones. That goes away on its own, the young ones are ok, but the older ones are quite small-minded. I'm also astounded that these Pegida demonstrations in the city center are still going on. I would give them a place somewhere in Prohlis, they can demonstrate there. But the Dresdeners aren't capable of doing that."

"Ich arbeite als Krankenschwester im Krankenhaus auf einer Tumorchirurgiestation mit Schwerpunkt HNO-Tumoren. Das ist sehr stressig und auch sehr aufopferungsvoll. Wir begleiten die Leute bis zum Ende. Das ist belastend. Wir sind zu wenig Personal und zu viele Patienten. Man kann sich nicht genug Zeit nehmen. Dieser Personalmangel hat sich vor zehn Jahren angedeutet, und seitdem wird es immer weniger, weil die KrankenhÃ¤user nicht bereit sind, Leute einzustellen, die Leute zu bezahlen. Das ist schade. FÃ¼r die, die noch da sind, ist es sehr schwierig.

Ich genieÃe meine Zeit sehr gerne in der Natur - ein bisschen abspannen und entspannen. Ich suche mir andere Dinge auÃerhalb der Arbeit, um ein gutes Gleichgewicht zu haben. Ich tanze sehr gern Tango Argentino. Das hat viel mit Freude und KÃ¶rper zu tun; es ist ein guter Ausgleich."
--
"I work as a nurse in a hospital on a tumor surgery ward with a focus on ear, nose and throat tumors. It is very stressful and also very demanding. We are with people until the end. That is stressful. There are too few staff, and too many patients. One cannot take enough time. The staff shortage was apparent ten years ago, and since then it has been getting worse and worse because the hospitals are not willing to hire people or pay people. It' s a shame. For those of us who are still there, it is very difficult.

I really enjoy my time in nature - relaxing and unwinding a bit. I look for other things outside of work to have a good balance. I love to dance Tango Argentino. It has a lot to do with joy and body; it is a good compensation."
