"Ich hatte das GlÃ¼ck, dass bei uns im Gymnasium das Fach Psychologie im Abitur angeboten wurde. Dort wurden zwar eher die klassischen Inhalte angeschnitten, das fand ich aber spannend genug, um das als Studium zu machen. Ich hatte damals diese Psychotherapeutenschiene im Auge. Ich bin aber im Bachelor relativ schnell darauf gekommen, dass ich die Intervention nicht ganz so spannend finde wie die PrÃ¤vention. Die Arbeit so zu gestalten, dass man gar nicht erst im Burnout landet, finde ich viel spannender als dann tatsÃ¤chlich die Burnoutpatienten vor mir sitzen zu haben. Ich habe mich deswegen auch im Master fÃ¼r diesen Schwerpunkt entschieden.

Nach einem kleinen Job und einer Elternzeit bin ich wieder in die Forschung gegangen. Das heiÃt, ich habe eine Stelle als wissenschaftliche Mitarbeiterin an der HTW Dresden in einem sehr spannenden Projekt angefangen. Es geht um Serviceroboter in der stationÃ¤ren Altenpflege. Unser Projekt versucht als eine von sehr vielen SÃ¤ulen das Problem des Pflegenotstandes aufzuarbeiten. Wir haben ja den demografischen Wandel - es gibt perspektivisch immer mehr PflegebedÃ¼rftige. Dem gegenÃ¼ber steht der FachkrÃ¤ftemangel, so dass es irgendwann schwierig wird, eine gute PflegequalitÃ¤t zu erhalten. Es gibt natÃ¼rlich viele MÃ¶glichkeiten, daran zu arbeiten. Eine davon ist, die Technologien zu Hilfe zu nehmen. Bei unserem Projekt geht es darum, ganz eng mit einer Pflegeeinrichtung zusammen in Fokusgruppen zu diskutieren, was die sich wÃ¼nschen und was machbar ist, dass ein Roboter das Ã¼bernimmt. Wir gucken ein bisschen globaler darauf. Wir haben eine relativ umfangreiche Arbeitsanalyse gemacht, wir haben Arbeitsbegehungen gemacht, Mitarbeiterbefragungen, Ratings, ein Interview mit der GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrung gefÃ¼hrt und versucht zu verstehen, wie eine stationÃ¤re Altenpflegeeinrichtung aufgebaut ist. Das war sehr, sehr spannend.

In meiner Dissertation geht es darum, welche Faktoren relevant zu sein scheinen, wenn es um die Implementierung von Servicerobotern in der stationÃ¤ren Altenpflege geht - was sollte man bedenken, was wird hilfreich sein, damit das funktioniert, damit die Mitarbeiter das annehmen. Es geht nicht darum, jemanden zu ersetzen - wir reden ja hier von unbesetzten Stellen. Die LÃ¼cken, die schon da sind, sollen irgendwie abgepuffert werden, damit die TÃ¤tigkeiten, die anfallen, ausgefÃ¼hrt werden kÃ¶nnen und die Bewohner nicht noch mehr unter dem Personalmangel leiden mÃ¼ssen. Fast jede Aufgabe kann ein System perspektivisch oder auch aktuell schon Ã¼bernehmen. Die Frage ist nur, was wollen wir, dass der Roboter Ã¼bernimmt. Nur weil man etwas bauen kann, heiÃt das nicht, dass man es auch bauen sollte, oder dass das fÃ¼r alle Einrichtungen oder Mitarbeiter passend ist."

Teil 1/2
--
"I was fortunate that the subject of psychology was offered in our high school in senior year. There, the classical topics were just touched upon, but I found that exciting enough to do it as a course of study. At that time I had the psychotherapist track in mind. But in my bachelor's degree, I came to the conclusion relatively quickly that I didn't find intervention quite as exciting as prevention. I find it much more exciting to design jobs so that you don't burnout in the first place than to have the burnout patients sitting in front of me. That's why I decided to focus on this topic in my master's degree.

After a small job and parental leave, I went back to research. I started a position as a research assistant at the HTW Dresden in a very exciting project. It's about service robots in inpatient geriatric care. Our project is one of many pillars attempting to solve the problem of the nursing crisis. We have the demographic change - there are more and more people in need of care. On the other hand, there is a shortage of skilled workers, so that at some point it will be difficult to obtain good quality care. There are of course many opportunities to work on it. One of them is to take advantage of technology. In our project, we work very closely with a care facility with focus groups to discuss what they want and what is feasible for a robot to do. We look at it a little more globally. We have done a relatively extensive labor analysis, we have conducted work inspections, employee surveys, ratings, an interview with the management, and we have tried to understand how an inpatient nursing home is structured. It was very, very exciting.

My dissertation is about which factors seem to be relevant when it comes to the implementation of service robots in inpatient geriatric care - what should be considered, what will be helpful to make it work, to encourage employees to adopt it. It is not about replacing someone - we are talking about unfilled positions. The gaps that are already there should be buffered somehow so that the activities that arise can be carried out and the residents do not have to suffer even more from the lack of personnel. Almost every task can be taken over by a system in the future or at present. The only question is what do we want the robot to do. Just because you can build something doesn't mean that you should build it, or that it is suitable for all facilities or employees."

I got to know Oli through our joint project. He is from the IT-sector, I handle the occupational science and occupational psychology component. At some point, we grew from being colleagues to friends. Then the idea arose that our subjects we were discussing might interest others as well. We decided on the podcast format and the focus on working life. I've done the math - you get a solid seventy thousand hours of work in a lifetime. I think that's a considerable number, especially when you hear from a lot of people that things aren't going so smoothly at work, that they don't go into Monday mornings with a smile on their faces and that they tend to pass the time rather than use it. We have accumulated a lot of knowledge in our respective areas, both theoretical and practical, so that we can perhaps give others a few tips on how to be proactive in their working lives. In August, we created and published the podcast manege frei.

We have made four episodes of our podcast so far. The first episode is a bit like the "love it, change it or leave it" episode. It's all about putting a magnifying glass on your own work and seeing how satisfied you are with your job. I think that the majority of people have room for improvement and are not one hundred percent satisfied and see potential for improvement on one side or the other - be it in their relationship with the boss or what the pay or commute is or the working hours are. We have suggested a few steps to see where there is room for improvement. Does it make sense to try out the improvements within the current company, in the job, i.e. to actively work on making the current job better, or does it all come down to a "leave it" in the end, because there are factors that you can't influence, or major compatibility problems, where people realize that they simply don't fit into this job or this company. To see what other alternatives there are and if a job change might make sense. We then also packed a fantasy trip into it. It was about not always consciously sitting down and thinking: what do I want for a job now? Sometimes it is not so easy to know what you want. This was an attempt to tickle the subconscious and to see how the best-case Monday would look for you with a little meditative fantasy trip. If an alarm clock rings at all, when do I get up, if I get to choose, how many days a week do I work, do I even go to work or do I stay at home because I prefer working from home. It's obvious that not all of this will come true, that's not the point. But I think it's a good idea to get closer to the goal. It might help you to negotiate things or to attach importance to certain things when choosing a career later or during job interviews.

I think that everyone can get something out of our podcast. We'll see how the formats evolve, whether we do some more interviews or a series on a certain topic. I would like to do something about non-violent communication, for example. We have a long list of ideas. It's all still in the making and we have to see what the next topics will be."

Ich bin aus Bonn hergezogen und finde es eigentlich ziemlich cool hier. Ich vermisse Bonn nicht. Meine Eltern sind noch da, deswegen fahre ich immer mal wieder hin, aber die meisten meiner Freunde sind auch weggezogen. Lange Zeit war ich noch Ã¶fter in KÃ¶ln, weil meine Freundin da gewohnt hat, aber die wohnt jetzt auch hier. In Bonn war mir zu wenig los. Da ist Dresden deutlich besser aufgestellt mit Nachtleben und kulturmÃ¤Ãig.

Diese ganze Ossi-Wessi-Geschichte ist mir erst hier wirklich bewusst geworden. Ich hatte den Eindruck, dass in Bonn - zumindest in dem Umfeld, in dem ich da unterwegs war - das Ã¼berhaupt nicht so ein Thema war, dass das gar nicht in den KÃ¶pfen von den Menschen drin war. Erst hier wurde mir bewusst, dass sich die Leute hier sehr benachteiligt fÃ¼hlen, nach wie vor. Ich glaube, dass viele Leute hier noch das GefÃ¼hl haben, dass sich die Wessis als etwas Besseres sehen. Das ist mir vorher aber nicht bekannt gewesen.

Ich kann mir vorstellen, hier zu bleiben. Meine Freundin ist jetzt hier Lehrerin, deswegen wird es darauf hinauslaufen, dass ich, wenn ich endlich mal fertig bin, auch noch ein bisschen hier bleibe. JobmÃ¤Ãig, in der Autoindustrie, geht es dann auf lange Sicht doch eher in den SÃ¼den."

"I am 27 years old and have lived here in Dresden for six and a half years. I came here to go to university, and I still am. I moved here from Bonn, and I think it' s actually pretty cool here. I don't miss Bonn. My parents are still there, so I go from time to time, but most of my friends have moved away, too. For a long time I went to Cologne a lot because my girlfriend used to live there, but she lives here now, too. In Bonn, there wasn't enough going on for me. Dresden has much better nightlife and culture.

This whole Ossi-Wessi thing only really became clear to me here. I had the impression that in Bonn - at least in the environment in which I lived - it wasn't such a big issue at all, that it wasn't even in people's minds. But I didn't know that before.

I can imagine staying here. My girlfriend is now a teacher here, so when I'm finally finished, it will mean that I will stay here for a while. In terms of jobs in the car industry, I'll be heading south in the long run."

That's how it started with a group of friends - we met and did yoga together. Then they brought people with them. At some point we rented a room in the Neustadt where we could do yoga every Friday evening. That went on until Corona started. Because I didn't know what would happen then, I gave up the room. "Ich komme aus Moskau. Seit 2017 lebe ich hier. Wir sind von San Sebastian in Spanien, wo mein Mann und ich vier Jahre lang gelebt haben, hierher gezogen. Er kam wegen seiner Arbeit hierher, und ich bin erst sechs Monate spÃ¤ter umgezogen, weil ich eigentlich in Spanien bleiben wollte. Er kommt ursprÃ¼nglich aus Brasilien, aber er hat in Spanien in Physik promoviert. Wir haben uns dort kennengelernt und geheiratet.

Ich habe hier angefangen, als Direktionsassistentin zu arbeiten. Dann bin ich schwanger geworden. Ich habe gehÃ¶rt, dass Dresden die hÃ¶chste Anzahl junger Familien pro Kopf in Deutschland hat. Wir leben in Pieschen, wo der durchschnittliche Einwohner zu einer jungen Familie mit Baby gehÃ¶rt. Wir haben das GefÃ¼hl, unseren Platz gefunden zu haben. Ich war in einem Geburtsvorbereitungskurs, und ich habe dort Menschen in der gleichen Lebensphase getroffen, und alle meine Freundinnen sind MÃ¼tter mit Kindern. Manchmal ist es ein bisschen viel.

Es gibt auch viele Russen. Ich hatte nicht erwartet, dass es in Dresden so viele Russen gibt. In der Altstadt scheint jeder dritte Mensch Russe oder Halb-Russe zu sein. In unserem Kindergarten gibt es so viele russische Kinder, dass die Erzieherin alle grundlegenden WÃ¶rter auf Russisch gelernt hat. Unser Sohn lernt Portugiesisch, Russisch und Deutsch. Portugiesisch ist im Moment sein Favorit. Es ist eine Art Experiment; schauen wir mal, wie es lÃ¤uft.

Ich weiÃ nicht, ob wir in Deutschland bleiben werden. Mein Mann mÃ¶chte es, aber manchmal mÃ¶chte ich zurÃ¼ck nach Spanien, weil es sich einfach viel einfacher anfÃ¼hlt. Die Lebensweise passt mir so viel besser. Man kann ungezwungen auf andere Menschen zugehen oder Fremden gegenÃ¼ber eine Bemerkung zu machen. Diese offene Kultur gefÃ¤llt mir viel besser. Ich will den deutschen Lebensstil nicht kritisieren, aber wenn ich hier bin, denke ich immer darÃ¼ber nach, was ich sagen soll, wie ich reagieren soll. Ich versuche immer, mich zurÃ¼ckzuhalten, weil ich jemanden stÃ¶ren kÃ¶nnte. Die Deutschen denken so viel darÃ¼ber nach, dass sie niemanden stÃ¶ren wollen. Irgendwie habe ich das unbewusst akzeptiert, deshalb telefoniere ich einfach nicht in der StraÃenbahn. Wenn ich nach Spanien zurÃ¼ckkomme, ist es eher wie "Ach, was soll's, scheiÃ drauf!"

"I come from Moscow. I have lived here since 2017. We moved here from San Sebastian, Spain, where my husband and I lived for four years. He moved here because of his work, and I moved six months later because I wanted to stay in Spain. He is from Brazil originally, but he did his PhD in physics in Spain. We met there and got married there.

I started working here as an executive assistant, and then I got pregnant. I heard Dresden has the highest number of young families per capita in Germany. We live in Pieschen, where the average resident belongs to a young family with a baby. We feel like we have found our place. I was in a birth preparation class, and I met people there in the same situation, and all of my friends are mothers with children. Sometimes, itâs a bit much.

There are also a lot of Russians. I didnât expect there to be so many Russians in Dresden. In the Altstadt, it seems like every third person are Russian or half-Russian. At our kindergarten, there are so many Russian kids, that the teacher has learned all the basic words in Russian. Our son is learning Portuguese, Russian, and German. Portuguese is his favorite right now. Itâs a kind of experiment; letâs see how it goes.

I donât know if weâll stay in Germany. My husband wants to, but sometimes, I want to go back to Spain, because it just felt much easier. The way of life suits me so much better. I donât want to criticize the German lifestyle, but when I am here, I always think about what I should say, how I should react. I have accepted this subconsciously somehow, so I just donât talk on the phone on the tram. When I get back to Spain, itâs like âWhew, whatever, fuck it!â

Den Gedanken, man ist nur Deutscher, konnte ich nie richtig nachvollziehen. Ich weiÃ gar nicht ganz genau, ob ich mich jemals vertieft mit meiner deutschen IdentitÃ¤t auseinandergesetzt habe. Mein Vater kommt aus Nicaragua. Da ist man natÃ¼rlich erst mal mit der Frage konfrontiert, ob man auch deutsch genug ist oder ob man sich wirklich damit identifizieren kann. Man kann sich gerne Ã¼ber Traditionen und Werte identifizieren, aber fÃ¼r mich war das nie ein Gedanke, zu sagen, ich identifiziere mich Ã¼ber Deutschland oder das was andere Leute vielleicht meinen, was das ausmacht.

At the end of the day, we are very lucky to have the political system in our own hands. Unfortunately, we still use it too little."

"Ich bin 27 Jahre alt. Ich bin Schauspielstudent. Ich komme eigentlich aus SÃ¼ddeutschland und studiere eigentlich in Leipzig. Die Leipziger Hochschule hat ein System, dass die Studenten, die dort studieren, die ersten zwei Jahre an der Hochschule sind und dann zwei Jahre an einem der vier Theater, die da mitmachen, sind. Und da ist Dresden eins davon. Ich bin einer der glÃ¼cklichen neun Studenten, die hier am Staatsschauspiel sein dÃ¼rfen. Ich bin jetzt hier in meinem zweiten und letzten Jahr als Student. Wir sind ein kleines Mini-Ensemble das zum groÃen Ensemble dazu gehÃ¶rt. Wir werden ganz normal fÃ¼r StÃ¼cke eingesetzt und haben nebenher noch unsere studentischen Angelegenheiten. Wir machen ein bisschen Unterricht, aber auch eigene Projekte, die wir am Theater realisieren kÃ¶nnen und dÃ¼rfen.

Dass ich Schauspieler werden will, wusste ich schon meine ganze Kindheit und Jugend. Ich habe in meiner Heimatstadt schon Theater gespielt. Ich hatte das GlÃ¼ck, dass ich dort auch groÃe Sachen mitmachen durfte. Nach dem Abitur habe ich beschlossen, dass das alles ein bisschen zu schnell geht und dass ich noch einen kleinen Exkurs in die Welt machen will. Ich habe dann erstmal noch andere Sachen studiert, Geisteswissenschaften und ein bisschen Medizin. Irgendwann habe ich das alles abgebrochen, habe noch kurzzeitig als Barista gearbeitet und habe dann meinen Platz an der Schauspielschule gekriegt.

Mir war schon als kleines Kind klar, dass ich das bin. Ich glaube, Schauspieler zu sein ist ein Teil der PersÃ¶nlichkeit. NatÃ¼rlich ist das auch ein Beruf und vor allem ein Handwerk, aber ich glaube, es gehÃ¶rt schon in der Grundverankerung des Menschen dazu. Ich interessiere mich sehr fÃ¼r Gegenwartsliteratur und neue Texte, bin aber auch ein ganz ganz groÃer Schillerfan. Ich wÃ¼rde da gar nichts ausschlieÃen. Viel wichtiger ist, mit welchen Menschen man zusammen arbeitet und dass man auf einer WellenlÃ¤nge ist und mit den Leuten auf AugenhÃ¶he und zusammen arbeitet. Wenn das gegeben ist, macht es wirklich SpaÃ und ist der schÃ¶nste Beruf, den es Ã¼berhaupt nur gibt auf der Welt."

"I am 27 years old. I am an acting student. I am from Southern Germany, and I am actually studying in Leipzig. The Leipzig university has a system whereby the students who study there spend the first two years at the university and then two years at one of the four theaters that participate. And Dresden is one of them. I am one of the lucky nine students who are allowed to be at the Staatsschauspiel here. I am now in my second and final year here as a student. We are a small mini-ensemble that is part of the big ensemble. We are normally assigned to plays and have our student matters on the side. We have some classes, but we also have our own projects that we can and are allowed to realize at the theater.

I knew all through my childhood and adolescence that I wanted to be an actor. I already did theater in my hometown. I was lucky that I was allowed to do bigger things there. After graduating from high school, I decided that it was all going a bit too fast and that I wanted to make a little excursion into the world. I studied other things first, humanities and a little bit of medicine. At some point I broke it all off, worked as a barista for a short time and then got my place at acting school.

Even as a small child I knew that this was me. I think being an actor is a part of your personality. Of course, it's also a profession and above all a craft, but I think it's already part of the basic human being. I'm very interested in contemporary literature and new texts, but I'm also a big Schiller fan. I wouldn't rule anything out. The people you work with are much more important than the material, that you are on the same wavelength and work with people on an equal footing. If that's the case, it's really fun and the most wonderful job there is in the world."

"Ich komme eigentlich aus Ãsterreich. Ich habe dort die ersten zehn Jahre gelebt. Dann sind wir in die Schweiz umgezogen. Dort habe ich noch mal zehn Jahre gelebt, dann bin ich erst nach Leipzig fÃ¼rs Studium gezogen und jetzt bin ich hier in Dresden.  Ich finde meine Arbeit in Dresden super. Es ist ein totaler GlÃ¼cksfall. Es ist einfach toll, mitten im Beruf zu stehen, und ich mag die Stadt auch gern.

Ich bin in so einem Gemisch von Dialekten aufgewachsen. Ich kann auch nicht einen Dialekt so direkt - das ist auch ein bisschen schade. Bei uns in der Familie ist das sowieso so ein Gemisch; die ganze Familie ist ein bisschen eine Wanderfamilie. Seit meinen GroÃeltern ist niemand mehr am gleichen Ort geblieben. Nach dem Zusammenbrechen der k. & k. Monarchie wurden die aus Slowenien, RumÃ¤nien, Polen und Ungarn nach Ãsterreich zusammengekarrt. Meine Eltern sind auch beide Schauspieler; da bleibt man auch nicht immer an einem Fleck. Das war auch der Grund, warum wir umgezogen sind, als ich zehn war, weil mein Papa ein Engagement an einem Theater in der Schweiz hatte. Ich habe auch so eine Unruhe in mir. Ich merke, wenn ich lÃ¤nger als drei, vier Jahre an einem Ort bin, dann ist irgendwas in mir drin, was eigentlich weiter will. Ich glaube, ich kann gar nicht so gut lÃ¤nger an einem Ort bleiben.

Ich war ein super, super schÃ¼chternes Kind. Mein Papa hat mich immer wieder gefragt bei TheaterstÃ¼cken, wo es noch Kinder gebraucht hat, ob ich da nicht mitmachen will. Ich habe mich gar nicht getraut, auf eine BÃ¼hne zu gehen. Mit vierzehn bin ich in eine neue Schulklasse gekommen. Dort war ein MÃ¤dchen, das in einem Theaterjugendclub gespielt hat. Die hat gesagt: âEy, wir haben zu wenig Jungs, komm doch mit!â, und hat mich so halbfreiwillig mitgeschleift. Ich stand dann plÃ¶tzlich auf der BÃ¼hne gestanden und habe gemerkt: Oh, das geht irgendwie doch, es ist irgendwie ganz toll! Das erste Mal auf einer BÃ¼hne zu stehen, war wie ein AufblÃ¼hen. Dieses GefÃ¼hl habe ich immer noch, wenn ich auf der BÃ¼hne stehe. Deswegen ist Theater fÃ¼r Kinder- und Jugendclubs auch so gut. Es gibt einem die Freiheit, ein bisschen offener zu werden. Ich kann auf die BÃ¼hne gehen und irgendwas machen. Und die Verabredung mit dem Publikum ist, das hat nichts mit mir zu tun. Darum ist das schon immer noch so eine Freiheit, einfach alles zu machen."

"I am actually from Austria. I lived there until I was ten. Then we moved to Switzerland. I lived there for another ten years, then I moved to Leipzig for my studies and now I'm here in Dresden. I think my work in Dresden is great. It is a total stroke of luck. It's just great to be in the middle of the profession, and I also like the city.

I grew up with such a mixture of dialects. I can't speak one dialect so directly either - that's also a bit of a pity. In our family, it's such a mixture anyway; the whole family is a bit of a wandering family. Since my grandparents, nobody has stayed in the same place. "I am an educator, and I volunteer. I work with refugees. We play soccer together at VfB Hellerau-Klotzsche. In 2015, we founded a team there that consists of refugees and Germans.

"Ich bin, seitdem ich in Dresden lebe, regelmÃ¤Ãig im Umfeld des 13. Februar gegen Menschen mit rechter Gesinnung auf der StraÃe. Seitdem es Pegida gibt, bin ich immer wieder auch dort dabei. Ich finde es wichtig, dass wir einen Gegenpol gegen Pegida setzen. Es geht darum, zu vermitteln, dass Dresden nicht durch Menschen mit rechter Gesinnung und rechter Hetze beherrscht werden darf. Mir ist es total wichtig, dass, egal wie groÃ oder klein die Demo ist, es immer auch einen Gegenprotest gibt, wenn in der Ãffentlichkeit Pegida genannt wird. Ich war auch bei den Demos dabei, die ganz ganz klein waren, wo vielleicht nur zwanzig Leute waren. Ich will nicht den Tag erleben, wo Pegida unkommentiert und vor allem unkritisiert durch Dresden ziehen und auf den PlÃ¤tzen Dresdens demonstrieren darf.

Im Prinzip bin ich so aufgewachsen. Meine Eltern haben mir schon in Leipzig vermittelt, dass es wichtig ist, gegen Nazis auf die StraÃe zu gehen. Ich glaube, gerade in Dresden ist es ein Thema, dass die Stadtregierung sich leider lange Zeit schwer tat und noch immer tut, sich konkret politisch zu positionieren. Das ist etwas, was ich zum Beispiel in Leipzig immer anders erlebt habe. Dort gibt es einen OberbÃ¼rgermeister, der die BevÃ¶lkerung ganz regelmÃ¤Ãig dazu aufruft, sich gegen rechte Demos auf die StraÃe zu stellen. Jetzt hat OberbÃ¼rgermeister Hilbert auch hier dazu aufgerufen, sich gegen den Jahrestag zu positionieren - und vor allem fÃ¼r Weltoffenheit zu positionieren, was ich viel wichtiger finde. Ich glaube das ist ein grundlegendes Problem, dass Dresden sehr historisch geprÃ¤gt und sehr konservativ ist und dadurch eine lange Zeit braucht, um wieder etwas Neues zu akzeptieren. Ich gestehe es ganz offen: Meine Oma lebte viele Jahre in Hagen im Ruhrgebiet. Ich war auch erstmal irritiert, als ich als Kind dort zu Besuch war, wie viele muslimische Menschen dort leben. Es hat mich nicht schockiert, aber es hat mich erstmal verwundert. Ich glaube, das ist der Unterschied zwischen Dresden und vielen anderen Gebieten in Deutschland - dass diese kulturelle Vielfalt hier noch nie den Platz hatte."

Teil 1/2
--
"Since I moved to Dresden, I have regularly protested against people with right-wing sentiments on the occasion of February 13. Since Pegida has existed, I have been there again and again. I think it is important that we set a counterpole to Pegida. It is about conveying the message that Dresden should not be dominated by people with right-wing sentiments and by right-wing agitation. It is very important to me that no matter how big or small the demonstration is, there will always be a counterprotest when Pegida is mentioned in public. I was also present at the demonstrations, which were very small, where there were maybe only twenty people. I don't want to witness the day when Pegida is allowed to march through Dresden without comment and above all without criticism and to demonstrate on the streets of Dresden.

I basically grew up that way in Leipzig. My parents taught me that it is important to take to the streets against Nazis. I think that in Dresden, it is subject on which the city government unfortunately had an especially hard time taking a concrete political position for a long time, and still does. It's different in Leipzig, for example. There, there is a mayor who regularly calls on the population to take to the streets against right-wing demonstrations. Now Mayor Hilbert has called on the people to take a stand against the anniversary - and above all to take a stand for openness to the world, which I find much more important. I think the fundamental problem is that Dresden is very historically oriented and very conservative and therefore needs a long time to accept something new. I admit it quite openly: My grandmother lived in Hagen in the Ruhr area for many years. I was also initially perplexed when I visited there as a child, how many Muslim people lived there. It didn't shock me, but it surprised me at first. I think that's the difference between Dresden and many other areas in Germany - that this cultural diversity has never had a place here before."

Part 1/2

Trotzdem - wenn man unterwegs ist und Ã¶ffentlich zeigt, dass man homosexuell ist, gucken trotzdem immer die Leute und sagen so etwas wie: âGuck mal, da sind zwei Schwule!â oder sonst irgendwas. Es sind Ã¶fter Jugendliche, die so etwas sagen. Eigentlich sollte es gerade fÃ¼r die schon normal sein, weil es auch in der Gesellschaft inzwischen normal geworden ist. Es ist immer unangenehm. Jedes andere Paar, das nicht homosexuell ist, kann einfach so auf der StraÃe herumlaufen und seine Liebe zeigen. Man mÃ¶chte einfach auch mit seinem Partner auf der StraÃe HÃ¤ndchen halten, ihm einen Kuss geben, ohne dass die Leute mit dem Finger auf einen zeigen.

Dresden ist wirklich eine schÃ¶ne Stadt. Man sollte nicht von solchen Momenten das Image zerstÃ¶ren lassen. Es gibt sehr viele Leute hier, die auf der falschen Seite stehen, aber auch umso mehr Leute, die dagegenhalten. Ich finde, das sollte man bewahren und solche Veranstaltungen wie heute Ã¶ffentlich machen, damit die Leute auch sehen, dass Dresden nicht so ist wie die ganzen VorfÃ¤lle, die hier passieren.

"I am 21 years old. I have been studying to teach English and Russian at the high school level for two years here in Dresden and have been living here for 2 years. Dresden is so far the most beautiful city I have seen in Germany. I feel very comfortable here.

I have not yet experienced any homophobia here. Dresden is a big city and everybody moves in his or her own circles. Nevertheless - when you are out and about and show publicly that you are gay, people always look at you and say something like: "Look, there are two gays" or something like that. It is more often young people who say things. It should actually be normal for them, because it has become normal in society as well. It is always unpleasant. Any other couple that is not gay can just walk the streets and show their love. You just want to hold hands with your partner on the street, give him a kiss without people pointing their fingers at you.

Dresden is really a beautiful city. You can' t let moments like that destroy its image. There are a lot of people here who are on the wrong side, but there are also a lot of people who are against it. I think that this fact should be preserved and that events like today should be made public so that people can see that Dresden is not the same as all the things that happen here.

I don't think that such an incident will increase xenophobia. But I do believe that people who are xenophobic will continue to use such things to make it clear. You have to tell yourself that this was one person who attacked two people, not all of Syria."

Unfortunately, I could have imagined that it would happen here. Especially here in the eastern part of Germany where the AfD is more present, always stronger than in the western part. It is a man who was murdered because of a circumstance for which he can do nothing. It does not matter what religion the murderer has. A hate crime does not depend on a religion. Whether a Christian kills a homosexual or whether it was a Jew, a Muslim or a Buddhist is completely irrelevant. Murder is murder and a hate crime is a hate crime, regardless of which religion.

I think the only thing that can be done from the political side is enlightenment. And of course to make sure that something so avoidable doesn't happen again. Because it could have been avoided; the authorities knew that he was a danger.

When we walk through the city together, I repress the fear. I do not want fear to determine my life. I walk through all the streets, I walk through all the districts. We live with a fear, but the fear must not determine our lives, because if it does, they win."

"Ich bin gelernter Krankenpfleger. Die AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde verbietet mir seit zwei Jahren zu arbeiten. Vor  einem Jahr musste ich dort meinen Reisepass abgeben; und bis jetzt darf ich nicht arbeiten. Ich bekomme von der BehÃ¶rde keine Auskunft. Meine Chefin hat dort auch immer wegen der Erlaubnisse angerufen, aber auch sie wird immer vertrÃ¶stet. Ich weiÃ nicht, warum das so ist. Bei anderen klappt es auch, nur bei mir nicht.

Ich wÃ¼rde den Leuten gerne helfen. Geld ist mir egal. Ich habe den Beruf gelernt, weil ich helfen will. Ich verfolge jeden Tag die Zahl der Neuinfizierten und der Gestorbenen. Gestern waren 164 Gestorbene. Wenn einer davon wegen mir weiterleben kÃ¶nnte, wÃ¼rde mich das stolz machen.

Ich mÃ¶chte gerne hier mit meiner Frau leben. Sie ist Deutsche. Wir sind schon vier Jahre zusammen. Ich habe schon einen Antrag bei der AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde eingereicht, dass ich mit meiner Frau zusammen leben kann, aber ich bekomme keine Antwort. Ich kann auch nicht nach Pakistan zurÃ¼ck. Ich habe dort Probleme. Ich hoffe dass ich hier arbeiten darf und mit meiner Frau zusammenwohnen kann.

Ich bin fertig mit den Nerven wegen dem, was mir passiert. Ich habe den ganzen Tag frei und laufe durch die Stadt. Das gefÃ¤llt mir nicht. Ich darf keinen Deutschkurs machen, ich darf nicht arbeiten, ich darf nicht bei meiner Frau sein. Ich lebe wie ein Hund. Das tut mir wirklich nicht gut. Ich brauche jemanden, der mir hilft."
--
"I am a trained nurse. The immigration authorities have forbidden me from working for two years. A year ago I had to hand in my passport there; and I am still not allowed to work. I am not getting any information from the authorities. My boss has been calling them for permission, but they always put her off too. I do not know why that is. The process works for other people, but not for me.

I would like to help people. I don't care about money. I chose this profession because I want to help. Every day I keep track of the number of people who are newly infected and the number who have died. Yesterday, 164 people died. If one of them could live because of me, that would make me proud.

I would like to live here with my wife. She is German. We have been together for four years. I have already submitted an application to the immigration authorities that I can live together with my wife, but I don't get an answer. I cannot return to Pakistan either. I have problems there. I hope that I can work here and live with my wife.

My nerves are frayed because of what is happening to me. I have the whole day free and just walk around the city. I do not like that. I am not allowed to take a German course, I am not allowed to work, I am not allowed to be with my wife. I live like a dog. It really isn't good for me. I need someone to help me."

"Originally I am from Hannover, but I lived in Berlin for ten years. And there I lost everything. I had worked as an animal caretaker for ten years and lived with my girlfriend. I came home and all things were at the door, the bank account was empty. Then I had to quit my work and went back to Hannover. I struggled with the public authorities there for three months. The first month it worked, the other two were at odds, so I had to decide: either fight with the agencies - from the street, in winter - or act independently. Then I started to act on my own.

Since then I have always been on the road to help others who are on the streets - and myself, of course. There are homeless people all over Germany, because there is too little social housing or overcrowded facilities, or maybe the government offices don't work. There are also some who stay outside voluntarily because they can't make it at all. There should be a simpler social network so that it is easier for people without a residence to get something, that they can get money quickly and do not have to fill out millions of pieces of paperwork to get a place to stay quickly. Single apartments would be best. Homeless shelters are good, but there you stay in the same environment, drugs, alcohol, and never get out.

Street workers can't do all that on their own. That's why I'm doing this even though I'm homeless. I look at what people need. I have put what is needed for me and others all over Germany on the internet. I talk to them and see what can be done. In Dresden, I haven't had contact with so many people yet, because they are more on the outskirts and I am more in the center, but what you hear is that it is very, very difficult to find places for the winter time, especially because of the Corona virus. We can't stay in front of entrances anymore, where it is a bit warm, because security is sending us away. We are struggling with it now. Most of the time you get a bit chased away in the city.

I like being at the traffic lights where people stop, take their time, read the signs and maybe take a look online. I talk a lot with people who pass by. Because I'm a well-groomed, seemingly homeless person, I make a good impression, a fresh impression. Then all age groups come to me - I have talked to school children, school classes, I have older people who listen or just want to know something and maybe go on without a donation. I think that's also good - that people just listen. I can't complain. I have a lot to talk about during the day. And that is actually also very frightening - that the people are so badly informed that they always think "government office." But what do you do if the agency doesn't work or someone doesn't want to be involved with the government or doesn't want to go to the homeless shelter because it's dangerous. Then you have hardly any possibilities.

I'm saving up for a caravan now, so that I have a roof over my head. I want to put it somewhere permanent and work from there again. But I do not want to give up my social activism. I think it's good to talk to people, and I also think it's good when they have the courage to come. I am one whom they really dare to approach. It' s scary, but somebody has to do it. It would be nice if people would stop somewhere more often - even with others - and question why that is they are on the street."

"Originally I am from Hannover, but I lived in Berlin for ten years. And there I lost everything. I had worked as an animal caretaker for ten years and lived with my girlfriend. I came home and all things were at the door, the bank account was empty. Then I had to quit my work and went back to Hannover. I struggled with the public authorities there for three months. The first month it worked, the other two were at odds, so I had to decide: either fight with the agencies - from the street, in winter - or act independently. Then I started to act on my own.

Since then I have always been on the road to help others who are on the streets - and myself, of course. There are homeless people all over Germany, because there is too little social housing or overcrowded facilities, or maybe the government offices don't work. There are also some who stay outside voluntarily because they can't make it at all. There should be a simpler social network so that it is easier for people without a residence to get something, that they can get money quickly and do not have to fill out millions of pieces of paperwork to get a place to stay quickly. Single apartments would be best. Homeless shelters are good, but there you stay in the same environment, drugs, alcohol, and never get out.

Street workers can't do all that on their own. That's why I'm doing this even though I'm homeless. I look at what people need. I have put what is needed for me and others all over Germany on the internet. I talk to them and see what can be done. In Dresden, I haven't had contact with so many people yet, because they are more on the outskirts and I am more in the center, but what you hear is that it is very, very difficult to find places for the winter time, especially because of the Corona virus. We can't stay in front of entrances anymore, where it is a bit warm, because security is sending us away. We are struggling with it now. Most of the time you get a bit chased away in the city.

I like being at the traffic lights where people stop, take their time, read the signs and maybe take a look online. I talk a lot with people who pass by. Because I'm a well-groomed, seemingly homeless person, I make a good impression, a fresh impression. Then all age groups come to me - I have talked to school children, school classes, I have older people who listen or just want to know something and maybe go on without a donation. I think that's also good - that people just listen. I can't complain. I have a lot to talk about during the day. And that is actually also very frightening - that the people are so badly informed that they always think "government office." But what do you do if the agency doesn't work or someone doesn't want to be involved with the government or doesn't want to go to the homeless shelter because it's dangerous. Then you have hardly any possibilities.

I'm saving up for a caravan now, so that I have a roof over my head. I want to put it somewhere permanent and work from there again. But I do not want to give up my social activism. I think it's good to talk to people, and I also think it's good when they have the courage to come. I am one whom they really dare to approach. It' s scary, but somebody has to do it. It would be nice if people would stop somewhere more often - even with others - and question why that is they are on the street."

Dann habe ich Papierkunst gemacht mit einem Atelier in Sao Paulo. In Sao Paulo habe ich elf Jahre gelebt. Es gibt dort eine sehr spannende Kunstszene - die ganze Graffiti-Kunst. Es ist eigentlich eine der besten GraffitistÃ¤dte, finde ich - groÃe HÃ¤userwÃ¤nde angesprÃ¼ht, feinste Sachen, sowas findest du nicht im Museum. Es gibt Galerien auf offener StraÃe. Verglichen mit Sao Paulo ist es hier in der Neustadt eher dÃ¼nn.

ZurÃ¼ck nach Deutschland bin ich gekommen, weil die ganze politische und Ã¶konomische Situation nicht mehr so gut war. Es ist alles sehr teuer geworden, die Entwicklung ist wieder zwanzig Jahre zurÃ¼ckgegangen, von dem her, was sie sich aufgebaut hatten. Jetzt bin ich in Dresden und das gefÃ¤llt mir auch gut â durch die Neustadt vielleicht. Wenn es die Neustadt nicht gÃ¤be, mÃ¶chte ich vielleicht nicht in Dresden sein. Das ist wie Klein-Brasilien fÃ¼r mich."

"I am not quite from Dresden - from Stolpen. Later I went to Dresden. But I was also in Brazil for a long time. First I was a German teacher there. Then I made paper art and had a studio in Sao Paulo. I lived in Sao Paulo for eleven years. There is a very exciting art scene there - all the graffiti art. It's actually one of the best graffiti cities, I think - big walls of buildings sprayed, beautiful things, you don't find that in a museum. It's like galleries on the open street. Compared to Sao Paulo, it's rather thin here in the Neustadt.

I came back to Germany because the whole political and economic situation was not so good anymore. Everything has become very expensive, development has gone back twenty years from what they had built up. Now I'm in Dresden, and I like it too - thanks to the Neustadt perhaps. If the Neustadt didn't exist, I might not want to be in Dresden. It' s like little Brazil for me."

Ich bin nicht weit von hier aufgewachsen, also bin ich im Leben nicht so weit gekommen... Nein, eigentlich habe ich Dresden als Stadt schon immer geliebt. Ich finde, es ist eine wirklich schÃ¶ne, schÃ¶ne Stadt.

Dresden hat einen wirklich schlechten Ruf, aber - vor allem in der Neustadt, ist es wirklich nicht so. Keiner meiner Freunde ist fremdenfeindlich, und ich kenne niemanden von Pegida. Pegida ist eigentlich nicht so prÃ¤sent, vor allem nicht fÃ¼r junge Leute.

Aber man kÃ¶nnte schon behaupten, dass die Deutschen unflexibel sind. Wir mÃ¶gen unsere Art. Wir sind sehr unkompliziert. Wir wollen, dass die Dinge auf unsere Art und Weise erledigt werden."

"Im Moment mÃ¶chte ich in Dresden bleiben, weil die Corona-Situation hier besser ist. In diesem Fall gefÃ¤llt mir, wie die Deutschen die Regeln befolgen, Masken tragen, sich die HÃ¤nde waschen. Im Moment fÃ¼hle ich mich sicher."

âI guess I am a little more boring, because I am German. I am studying English and German at the TU. I grew up not so far from here, so I didnât make so far in lifeâ¦ No, I have actually always loved Dresden as a city. I think itâs a really beautiful, beautiful city.

âI might have to move at some point for my studies. But I would actually like to stay in Dresden. Itâs got a great transportation system.â

"Ich komme aus Leipzig. Ich bin mit meinen Eltern in Dresden zu Besuch. Wir hatten gerade auf der Hinfahrt das Thema, dass es noch immer die montÃ¤glichen ZusammenkÃ¼nfte gibt. Meine Eltern waren ganz erstaunt, dass es das wirklich noch gibt. Ich habe das mehr beobachtet und finde es ganz schÃ¶n erschreckend, dass es das nach sechs Jahren immer noch gibt.

Ich persÃ¶nlich empfinde es so, dass Dresden ein bisschen altbackener oder ein bisschen konservativer, bÃ¼rgerlicher auf eine nicht so gute Art ist. Ich denke, dass Leipzig weltoffener ist. Aber auch in Leipzig gibt es Ã¤hnliche Tendenzen und Problematiken. Ich glaube aber, dass die Gesellschaft da vielleicht ein grÃ¶Ãeres Auge drauf hat oder mehr versucht, entgegen zu steuern. Legida wurde zum Beispiel in Leipzig relativ schnell unterbunden. Ich halte Leipziger schon fÃ¼r ein bisschen weltoffener. Eine Bekannte von, die lange Zeit in Dresden gewohnt hat, ist jetzt auch nach Leipzig gezogen, weil sie das GefÃ¼hl hatte, dass sie hier eingeengter ist. Ich denke auch, dass das in ganz Deutschland immer noch ein Thema ist, wenn man an Dresden denkt. Das tut mir auch wirklich leid fÃ¼r Dresden.

Trotzdem ist Dresden eine sehr schÃ¶ne Stadt. Wir sind gerade durch die Neustadt her gelaufen; da gibt es zum Teil auch ganz viele bunte kulturoffene Sachen. Ich bin hin und wieder in Dresden; ich komme in die Stadt, um Ausstellungen und Konzerte zu besuchen oder um gesellige Abende mit Freunden und Bekannten in kleinen Kiez-und Eckkneipen zu verbringen. Mein GroÃvater ist in Dresden geboren und daher fÃ¼hle ich mich auch ich ein StÃ¼ck weit in der Stadt verwurzelt. Ich habe viele positive Erinnerungen an Dresden. Es ist und wÃ¤re so unglaublich schade, wenn immer nur dieser olle und vergleichsweise winzige Splitter ins Licht gerÃ¼ckt wird. Dresden und seine vielen unterschiedlichen Menschen kÃ¶nnen so viel mehr als nur stÃ¤nkern, Hass schÃ¼ren und rumlamentieren. Ich wÃ¼nsche mir, dass der Fokus unbedingt auf die vielen bunten, aktiven, interessierten, weltoffenen und schaffenden Akteure*innen gelegt wird und sich diese facettenreichen Splitter zu einem groÃartigen, und vor allem sichtbaren Mosaik formen!"
--
"I am from Leipzig. I am visiting Dresden with my parents. We just were discussing the fact that there are still the Monday meetings on our journey here. My parents were quite astonished that it really still exists. I was paying more attention, and I find it quite frightening that it still exists after six years.

I personally feel that Dresden is a bit more old-fashioned or a bit more conservative, more middle-class in a not so good way. I think that Leipzig is more open-minded. There are similar tendencies and problems in Leipzig as well, but I think that society is perhaps keeping a closer eye on the problems or trying to counteract them more. Legida, for example, was stopped relatively quickly in Leipzig. I think Leipzigers are a bit more cosmopolitan. An acquaintance of mine who lived in Dresden for a long time has now moved to Leipzig because she had the feeling that she is more confined here. I also think that this is still an issue throughout Germany when you think of Dresden. I am really sorry for Dresden.

Nevertheless Dresden is a very beautiful city. We just walked through the Neustadt; there are a lot of colorful and cultural things to see. I am in Dresden now and then; I come to the city to see exhibitions and concerts or to spend pleasant evenings with friends and acquaintances in small neighborhood and corner pubs. My grandfather was born in Dresden and therefore I also feel a bit rooted in the city. I have many positive memories of Dresden. It is and would be such an unbelievable pity if only this old and comparatively tiny splinter is always put into the spotlight. Dresden and its many different people can do so much more than just lament and stir up hatred. My wish is that the focus would be on the many colorful, active, interested, cosmopolitan and creative agents and that these multi-faceted splinters would form a great and above all visible mosaic!"

Deswegen habe ich mich dann entschieden, Deutsch zu lernen beziehungsweise Germanistik zu studieren. Ich habe in Ãgypten schon ein Jahr im Tourismus gearbeitet. "I am from Egypt. I studied the German language and culture in Egypt. At the moment, I'm doing my doctorate and working - teaching, translating and also interpreting. At this point I am also a certified translator.

media.description:
"Ich komme aus Syrien. Ich bin 27 Jahre alt. Ich bin seit drei Jahren in Deutschland, die ganze Zeit in Dresden. Ich liebe Dresden, weil es hier viel Geschichte gibt. Ich interessiere mich fÃ¼r Malerei und das finde ich hier in Dresden.

Was die Leute angeht, ist es schwierig, Kontakt zu bekommen. Ich weiÃ nicht, warum das so ist. In Syrien ist es so, dass wenn man einen Fremden auf der StraÃe sieht, alle Interesse haben und ihn kennenlernen wollen. Das gibt es hier nicht. Die Leute sind hier nicht so offen. Wenn man dann Kontakt hat, sind sie meistens hÃ¶flich, aber nicht immer. Ich glaube das liegt an der Angst oder weil sie unglÃ¼cklich sind. Die Jungen sind zum GlÃ¼ck offener als die Alten. Das freut mich, weil ich Dresden mag und ich fÃ¼r immer hier bleiben will."
--
"I am from Syria. I am 27 years old. I have been in Germany for three years, all that time in Dresden. I love Dresden because there is a lot of history here. I am interested in painting, and there's that here in Dresden too.

As far as the people are concerned, it is difficult to make contact. I don't know why that is so. In Syria, when you see a stranger on the street, everyone is interested and wants to get to know him. There is nothing like that here. People are not so open. When you have contact, they are usually polite, but not always. I think it's because of fear or because they are unhappy. Fortunately the young are more open than the old. I'm happy about that because I like Dresden and I want to stay here forever."

Ich habe dann einen Kurs an der Volkshochschule belegt, um das ein bisschen zu vertiefen, BÃ¼cher gekauft, Kurse besucht. Irgendwann bin ich dann selbstsicherer geworden. Das mit dem MÃ¤dchen beeindrucken hat auch funktioniert.

Ich bin sehr zufrieden mit meinem Leben in Dresden. Es ist nicht zu groÃ, es ist nicht zu klein, es gibt von jeder politischen Richtung was, die Menschen sind ultrafreundlich. Ich bin viel in der Welt rumgekommen, aber nirgendwo ist es schÃ¶ner als zu Hause. Ich denke, ich bin ein anspruchsloser Mensch. Ich glaube, man kann mich in die WÃ¼ste stellen und ich bin immer noch frÃ¶hlich, wenn es Schatten gibt. Die Leute denken: Ich will ein Bild und deshalb gehe ich auf Google und das lade ich mir jetzt runter. Deswegen sind dann viele mit der Einstellung dabei: Warum sollte ich denn fÃ¼r ein Bild, das ich fÃ¼r mich machen lasse, extra bezahlen, wenn ich einfach auf Google gehen kann? Das kann man zwar machen, aber es ist ja nicht das, was man fÃ¼r sich persÃ¶nlich will, es ist nicht sein Bild. Deswegen ist Kunst auch ein Luxusgegenstand."

"I am a freelance artist. I work on a commission basis, which means that someone has an idea for a picture, discusses it with me and then I make it. I work digitally and in oil. I taught myself how. It is a good income - not the biggest, not the smallest, not my main income, but it is a good extra income.

I've been interested in art for quite some time - ten, twelve years - but I've only been actively drawing for four years. I wanted to impress a girl. It all started with a simple ballpoint pen. At some point, it increased and became more and more refined. I then took a course at the adult education center to improve a bit, bought books, took courses. At some point, I became more confident. I was also able to impress the girl.

I am very happy with my life in Dresden. It's not too big, it's not too small, there is something from every political direction, the people are ultra-friendly. I have travelled a lot in the world, but nowhere is it more beautiful than home. I think I am an undemanding person. I think you can put me in the desert, and I would still be happy if there were shadows. But Dresden still has that special something, especially the history of the whole city, which is everywhere.

Art is a highly competitive field, there is a lot of competition. It is very much about how far you can reduce yourself so that it still makes money. That is a very unattractive part, how many artists underbid and sell below value. When I make an A3 size drawing, that's 18 hours of work, I ask for 200, and then I see others taking 50 for the same amount of work. I ask myself either how fast they are or what they live on. Art is always a luxury item; it is not something that you can and should simply be able to afford. It is always an investment for any money you have left over. But it's hard when you lose a competition, because the other artist simply wins by this massive price advantage.

What really bothers me is this "don't want to pay" mentality that has become common everywhere, especially on the internet. People think, "I want a picture so I go to Google and download it." Consequently, many people have the attitude: "Why should I pay extra for a picture that I have made for myself, if I can just go to Google?" You can do that, but it is not what you personally chose, it is not your picture. That's why art is a luxury item."

Jetzt mache ich gerade an der TU meinen Master in klinischer Psychologie. Ich habe entschieden, dass ich noch mal Bock habe, in Deutschland zu leben. Jetzt bin ich wieder hier und seit einem Jahr in Dresden.

Ich bin auf jeden Fall zufrieden mit meiner Entscheidung. Lima war toll; Lima ist eine richtig, richtig schÃ¶ne Stadt, aber ich hatte schon ziemlich Heimweh nach Deutschland. Jetzt bin ich sehr glÃ¼cklich, in Dresden gelandet zu sein. Es hat genau die richtige GrÃ¶Ãe. Ich bin eine Millionenstadt gewÃ¶hnt und jetzt ist es einen Ticken kleiner. Das finde ich ganz angenehm. Ich bin happy.

Der Menschentyp in SÃ¼damerika ist einfach anders. Menschen in Peru sind herzlicher, offener, es ist ein bisschen leichter, Anschluss zu finden. Alles in allem ist es eine Gesellschaft, die sehr darauf bedacht ist, sich gegenseitig zu unterstÃ¼tzen, weil der Staat einem so wenig hilft. Deutschland ist ein bisschen mehr einzelgÃ¤ngerisch - aber eigentlich weniger als ich gedacht hatte. Ich habe relativ schnell Anschluss gefunden, schneller als ich dachte. Der Staat ist hier in Deutschland sehr viel prÃ¤senter als in vielen anderen LÃ¤ndern. Deswegen wird sich sehr darauf verlassen. Ich habe das GefÃ¼hl, dass dieses âWir stehen auf und protestieren dagegenâ wie in Peru â auÃer bei so ganz schrÃ¤gen Sachen wie bei den Querdenkern â hier weniger vorhanden ist."

"Originally I am from Munich, but I have family both in Munich and Peru. My mom is from Peru. I grew up bilingual. My parents separated; my mom went back there, and I went with her. I went to school there, and did my Bachelor's degree. Then I worked there for a few years. Now I am doing my Master's degree in clinical psychology at the TU. I decided that I would like to live in Germany again. Now I'm back, and I have been in Dresden for one year.

I am definitely happy with my decision. Lima was great; Lima is a really, really beautiful city, but I was pretty homesick for Germany. Now I am very happy to have landed in Dresden. It has just the right size. I am used to a city of millions and it's a tick smaller. I find that quite pleasant. I am happy.

The people in South America are just different. People in Peru are warmer, more open, it's a bit easier to make friends. All in all, it is a society in which people are very keen to support each other because the state helps so little. People in Germany are a bit more isolated - but actually less than I thought. I made contacts relatively quickly, faster than I thought. The state is much more present here in Germany than in many other countries. That's why people rely on it so much. I have the feeling that the Peruvian "we stand up and protest against it" is less present here - except for some really weird things like the Querdenker."

"We are street social workers working with adults. It is an addiction-specific street work, which means that the focus is on the consumption of both illegal and illicit substances. Usually we are out and about, which means that as street workers, we go on the streets or in public places to find the people we work with or who we think might need support. But we are here every week on Mondays from 15:30 to 16:30 . For one thing, because our target audience doesn't have phones, doesn't have anything and sometimes doesn't know how to reach us. Then, they know that the street workers are here one hour every Monday, so they can come to us. But there are also people - residents, business people, passers-by - who don't know us and perhaps have questions or are affected by the topic themselves, directly or through family members. Because we are sitting out here and the traffic of passers-by is very high, it happens that people see us, suddenly start talking to us and there is a need for support. Then we can directly address the issue.

There are people who live on the street, who do not consume anything at all. There are people who live on the street, who drink something from time to time, as the average person probably does. But there are also people on the street who consume very, very much, and especially when it gets cold, use high-proof alcohol to warm up a little. You can't generalize about it, it's very different like with everyone else".

"It's very individual. On the one hand, it depends on the needs that people express. According to their wishes and how they want to achieve them, we are there as support to accompany the goals that people are pursuing. The need that we currently see on the streets here in Dresden is very, very substantial. We are received very positively. From all the people we get in contact with, we actually only get positive feedback. We have approached many, many people - we have had hardly any rejection".

"Even the people who were a bit hostile at the beginning come. A woman, for example, whom we met a year ago, was very negative. After a year, after she heard through her friends, "oh, they do help," she contacted us again. We are now working together with her very intensively and it is going well.

The need is great. There are two teams in total. One team is active in the Altstadt, the Neustadt and in Friedrichstadt. The other team is active in Gorbitz, Prohlis and at the Otto-Dix-Center. Our small team in the Altstadt and in the Neustadt alone has had over 3000 contacts between January and today, initial and follow-up contacts, including over 1000 different first contacts".

"You always get to know new people, but I think we are already known by many people who are regularly outdoors. It is a lot of work. You never have the feeling that the demand is going down. The more we work, the more new projects open up and the more you realize that people have need. We try to be on it as much as possible."

"We are street social workers working with adults. It is an addiction-specific street work, which means that the focus is on the consumption of both illegal and illicit substances. Usually we are out and about, which means that as street workers, we go on the streets or in public places to find the people we work with or who we think might need support. But we are here every week on Mondays from 15:30 to 16:30 . For one thing, because our target audience doesn't have phones, doesn't have anything and sometimes doesn't know how to reach us. Then, they know that the street workers are here one hour every Monday, so they can come to us. But there are also people - residents, business people, passers-by - who don't know us and perhaps have questions or are affected by the topic themselves, directly or through family members. Because we are sitting out here and the traffic of passers-by is very high, it happens that people see us, suddenly start talking to us and there is a need for support. Then we can directly address the issue.

There are people who live on the street, who do not consume anything at all. There are people who live on the street, who drink something from time to time, as the average person probably does. But there are also people on the street who consume very, very much, and especially when it gets cold, use high-proof alcohol to warm up a little. You can't generalize about it, it's very different like with everyone else".

"It's very individual. On the one hand, it depends on the needs that people express. According to their wishes and how they want to achieve them, we are there as support to accompany the goals that people are pursuing. The need that we currently see on the streets here in Dresden is very, very substantial. We are received very positively. From all the people we get in contact with, we actually only get positive feedback. We have approached many, many people - we have had hardly any rejection".

"Even the people who were a bit hostile at the beginning come. A woman, for example, whom we met a year ago, was very negative. After a year, after she heard through her friends, "oh, they do help," she contacted us again. We are now working together with her very intensively and it is going well.

The need is great. There are two teams in total. One team is active in the Altstadt, the Neustadt and in Friedrichstadt. The other team is active in Gorbitz, Prohlis and at the Otto-Dix-Center. Our small team in the Altstadt and in the Neustadt alone has had over 3000 contacts between January and today, initial and follow-up contacts, including over 1000 different first contacts".

"You always get to know new people, but I think we are already known by many people who are regularly outdoors. It is a lot of work. You never have the feeling that the demand is going down. The more we work, the more new projects open up and the more you realize that people have need. We try to be on it as much as possible."

"I have been living in Dresden for six years. I had finished my studies, then spent a year abroad and applied for a job. The area I studied is super small. It has something to do with theater stage technology and here in Dresden there is a company that builds and renovates theater stage technology. I came back from Australia with a backpacker attitude and thought I'd work for a while and if I don't like it, I'll leave again - which is what I did for a whole year with backpacking. And now, six years later, I am still here.

If I didn't like Dresden, I wouldn't be here. But of course there are always situations with where I think "Time to change." There are ups and downs. The city definitely challenges you. All of the social and societal issues are present in Dresden. As a resident of this city, I am part of this challenge. I see it from a subjective perspective, but I have the feeling that it is super polarizing and totally emotional here. Not far from here, Leipzig is the little lighthouse - at least that's what you hear. And here was recently the second vote on whether Dresden would become a safe haven. Almost all the major cities nationwide have managed to do it. It's a symbolic act, that's all it really is, and in Dresden it fails again.

These are the moments when I think to myself: "What's the point of this again? That Pegida has been running around here for years - okay, bad enough - but then some story comes along, funny coincidences like a pogrom night and a Pegida parade. Then they get the approval, even with the corona situations, but a counter-protest has to be rescheduled. There are always such things where I think "Typical Dresden," and it makes me sick. There is such a conservatism here, also the people who decide to move here. If you have the choice to go to Leipzig or to Berlin or to Hamburg - or you could go to Dresden, then people actively and consciously decide for a city. And a kind of conservative clientele moves here. That doesn't make it better."

Kanada und Australien war beides so eine Art Work and Travel. So eine Reise bereichert auf jeden Fall. Dadurch, dass es Work and Travel ist, muss man da ja auch arbeiten. Das sind nicht die Highlightjobs, sondern man arbeitet in Hotels, Restaurants, auf Farmen trÃ¤gt Gelbe Seiten aus. Der spannendste Job war das Branden von Rindern. In Kanada war ich die gesamten vier Monate auf einer Weinfarm.

Wenn man reist, sagt man Ã¶fter: âAch cool, ich wÃ¼rde gerne hier bleiben.â Aber trotzdem hat man ja eine Heimat und die ist hier. Ich habe nichts dagegen, mal wieder fÃ¼r eine lÃ¤ngere Zeit wegzugehen, aber hier ist es schÃ¶n, hier sind die Freunde, hier ist die Familie, hier sind die Kinder, hier ist die Arbeit. Gut, die Arbeit kann ich von Ã¼berall auf der Welt machen. Ich bin Grafiker. Kunden haben wir jetzt auch in der Schweiz und in Ãsterreich. Fotografie ist Bestandteil meiner Arbeit, ein kleiner Prozentsatz. Ich mache gerne Naturprojekte - alles was mit Ãkologie, Wald oder alternativen Lebensweisen zu tun hat.

Ich selbst lebe jetzt nicht mega alternativ, aber wir versuchen schon, auf ein Auto zu verzichten, wenn es geht. Ein Projekt, das ich hier in der Neustadt mit betreue, ist die Woche des guten Lebens. Das ist eine Woche, in der mÃ¶glichst mal der Verkehr aus der Neustadt verschwinden soll. Ich sehe das auch als ein spannendes Experiment. Ich wÃ¼rde mich freuen, wenn so viele Leute wie mÃ¶glich mitmachen. Wenn ich jetzt hier eine StraÃe hÃ¤tte, die ich ohne Autos fotografieren kÃ¶nnte, nur mit Fahrradfahrern, dann wÃ¼rde ich alleine heute schon ein viel besseres Foto hinbekommen. Ansonsten finde ich es spannend, wenn man in anderen LÃ¤ndern schaut, wenn man zum Beispiel nach Holland, Amsterdam, schaut mit dem ganzen Fahrradverkehr. Ich wÃ¼rde mir schon wÃ¼nschen, dass weniger auf Autos geachtet wird, jeder sich vielleicht auch ein bisschen selbst zurÃ¼cknimmt, weniger fÃ¤hrt. Ich glaube, alle wÃ¤ren weniger frustriert oder weniger depressiv, wenn sie sich einfach einen Meter mehr bewegen wÃ¼rden."

"I was born and raised here. At one point, I spent some time in Canada and Australia, but I am a Dresdener. I live in the Neustadt. This is certainly the most beautiful neighborhood we have; I wouldn't want to miss it. Especially in this Corona period, you don't have to leave it, because everything is here.

Canada and Australia were both a kind of work and travel. Such a journey is enriching in any case. Because it is work and travel, you have to work there. These are not the top jobs, but you work in hotels, restaurants, on farms, and you deliver the yellow pages. The most exciting job was the branding cattle. In Canada, I spent the whole four months on a wine farm.

When I travel, I often say: "Oh cool, I'd love to stay here." But I still have a home, and it is here. I don't mind going away for a longer period of time, but here it's nice, here are my friends, here is my family, here are my kids, here is my work. Good, I can do the work from anywhere in the world. I am a graphic artist. We have clients in Switzerland and Austria. Photography is part of my work, a small percentage. I like to do nature projects - anything that has to do with ecology, forest or alternative lifestyles.

I myself don't live super alternative now, but we try to do without a car when we can. One of the projects that I am involved in here in Neustadt is the Week of the Good Life. This is a week in which traffic should disappear from the Neustadt as much as possible. I also see it as an exciting experiment. I would be happy if as many people as possible would take part. If I could photograph a street here now without cars, just cyclists, then I would be able to take a much better photo today. Apart from that I find it exciting to look at other countries, for example Holland, Amsterdam, with all the bicycle traffic. I would wish that people would place less importance on cars, that everyone would take a little bit of time for themselves and drive less. I think everyone would be less frustrated and less depressed if they would just move a meter more."

"People often ask us why we spend one evening a week walking around the city, approaching strangers to ask them for an interview and a picture. I have a number of answers to this question. Most often, I say that we want to show the diversity of Dresden â and this also happens to be true. When People in Dresden started six years ago as Humans of Dresden, it began as a reaction to Pegida, as a platform for people to express their opposition and their outrage. Later, our site became a place where foreigners could talk about their experience in Dresden and tell their own stories, uninterrupted by German expectations or explanations.

Dresden can be a hard place for foreigners. As a foreigner myself, albeit a well-off, white one, I often feel weighed down by life in a city where no one smiles, and no one will tell you the rules until you have broken them. This brings me to my second explanation. Sometimes, I say, âWe want to make Dresden a friendlier place, to create empathy by allowing people to experience the humanity of their fellow residents of Dresden.â One of the things that I am proudest of is our interviews with refugees, which we have reproduced in their words as much as possible. I think we have allowed Germans to get a direct glimpse of their experience here, which is more affected by hostile, sometimes contradictory bureaucratic absurdities than by Pegida.

One could blame the agents of this bureaucracy in the Ordnungsamt, the Sozialamt, Jobcenter, the AuslÃ¤nderbehÃ¶rde, etc who seem completely opposed to the values of cosmopolitanism and openness, and I do. But it has slowly dawned on me that the average middle-aged or elderly Dresdener, the unfriendly case worker at BAMF or the grandma who shoots dirty looks at anyone who speaks a foreign language on the tram, is herself a migrant. She, and the land beneath her feet, have been moved from one country to another during her lifetime. She may have had to restart her career from scratch, or she may have witnessed her parents struggling under the new regime -- she has experienced her own kind of rupture and displacement. And this brings me to my third and last reason: I am nosy, and I just want to ask people about their lives. In recent years, I have pursued the questions and issues that interest me, including asking for oral histories of the Wende period. One evening a week, when Robert humors me, I conduct my own historical research on this place I now call home."

"Ich hÃ¤tte nie gedacht, dass dieses Projekt mal so einen groÃen Teil meiner freien Zeit einnimmt. Warum mache ich das Ã¼berhaupt? - ich muss mir einen Abend pro Woche freihalten und dazu noch jeden Tag irgendwas fÃ¼r die Seite tun, also die Fotos bearbeiten, Texte abtippen oder Ã¼bersetzen, Termine klÃ¤ren, Nachrichten beantworten und so weiter.

Der wichtigste Grund ist natÃ¼rlich, dass es ein schÃ¶nes Projekt geworden ist, das sich lohnt. Als es noch âHumans of Dresdenâ hieÃ und Anfang 2015 im Umfeld einer internationalen Gruppe gegrÃ¼ndet wurde, war es ja ein bisschen eine Antwort auf Pegida und deren Hass und Hetze. Seitdem ist es aber sehr viel mehr geworden. Was genau lÃ¤sst sich schwer sagen. Ich denke, fÃ¼r Jessica ist es etwas ganz anderes als fÃ¼r mich, und fÃ¼r unsere Leser ja sowieso. Es ist schÃ¶n, dass wir auf unserer Seite so eine groÃe Zahl von Migranten und ganz speziell geflÃ¼chteten Menschen zeigen. So kÃ¶nnen wir zeigen, dass es âden FlÃ¼chtlingâ nicht gibt, dass es alles individuelle Menschen mit unterschiedlichen HintergrÃ¼nden sind. Wobei das eigentlich auch schon wieder eine Nullaussage ist, es gibt eben nicht den Menschen, den Dresdner, den AuslÃ¤nder, den Ossi und so weiter. Aber obwohl das so selbstverstÃ¤ndlich ist oder jedenfalls sein sollte, tut es vielleicht doch gut, einmal am Tag gezeigt zu bekommen, dass es auch tatsÃ¤chlich so ist. Und auch wenn sich einige Aussagen in unseren Interviews wiederholen, bin ich immer wieder erstaunt, dass wir auch nach fast sechs Jahren und mehr als 2000 Interviews immer noch neue Themen entdecken.

Manchmal frage ich mich schon, ob wir solche Ziele wie âEmpathie erzeugenâ, âVielfalt zeigenâ oder âStreitkultur befÃ¶rdernâ tatsÃ¤chlich erreichen kÃ¶nnen. SchlieÃlich haben wir das Problem, dass die Leute, die sowas nicht hÃ¶ren wollen, unsere Seite vielleicht lesen, aber wohl eher nicht beeindruckt sind. Und wir sind auch nur zu zweit. Ich weiÃ es nicht. Es ist aber auch so, dass man so ein Projekt nicht einfach beendet. Solange es sich irgendwie einrichten lÃ¤sst, geht es also weiter. Noch dazu habe ich mir irgendwann mal Ã¼berlegt, dass wir lÃ¤nger da sind als Pegida. Wie es aussieht, haben wir ganz gute Chancen, das zu schaffen. Mal sehen, wer zÃ¤her ist."
--
"I never thought that this project would take up so much of my free time. Why do I do it at all? - I have to keep one evening free per week and also do something for the site every day, i.e. edit the photos, type or translate texts, arrange appointments, answer messages and so on.

The most important reason is, of course, that it has become a nice project that is worthwhile. Founded as "Humans of Dresden," at the beginning of 2015 in the context of an international group, it was a bit of a response to Pegida and its hatred and propaganda. Since then, however, it has become much more. What exactly it is is hard to say. I think it is something completely different for Jessica than for me, and certainly different than it is for our readers. It's nice that we can show such a large number of migrants, and especially refugees, on our site. In this way, we can demonstrate that there is no such thing as "the refugee", that they are all individual people with different backgrounds. Although this is actually non-statement, there is just not one person, the Dresdener, the foreigner, the Ossi and so on. But although that is so self-evident, or at least should be, it is perhaps good to illustrate it once a day. And even if some statements are repeated in our interviews, I'm always amazed that even after almost six years and more than 2,000 interviews, we still discover new topics.

Sometimes I do wonder whether we can actually achieve goals like "generating empathy," "showing diversity" or "promoting a culture of debate." After all, we have the problem that the people who don't want to hear such things may read our site but are probably not impressed. And there are only two of us. I don't know. But you can't just end a project like this. As long as it can be managed somehow, it will go on. What's more, I have started wondering at some point if we'd be around longer than Pegida. As it stands, we have a pretty good chance of achieving that. Let's see who's tougher."

"I started studying education in Jena in 2010. During my freshman week, various organizations made presentations, including the local Leo Club "Jena zur Rose". I didn't know anyone in Jena and wanted to get involved in community service in addition to my studies anyway. So it was a perfect fit for me. Leo stands for Leadership Experience Opportunity. I quickly got to know Jena better, met new people, was and still am part of a worldwide network, was able to learn people skills and have a lot of fun doing good things. When I moved to Dresden in 2013, I joined the club here and brought my husband with me as well. Now, we are the longest-standing members of the "Augustus the Strong" club, which has been around for over twenty years.

In Leo clubs, young people all over the world volunteer to do community service in their neighborhoods. Members are between 16 and 30 and enjoy doing something good in their communities. The activities are very diverse. There are about 180 clubs in Germany alone. Here in Dresden we have two, "Canaletto" and the one in which I am treasurer this term: "August der Starke". We have about ten active members and meet at normal times once a month for the club meeting. In addition, there is usually one activity per month. This year we helped with the Elbwiesen clean-up and put up compliments to go; we wanted to put a smile on people' faces and make them feel appreciated even in the current hard times. We also run pub quizzes and donate all the proceeds. Of course, we had to make changes due to Corona and were not able to do our annual car wash, nor a "one part more" campaign for the night cafÃ©s or day trips with the children and young people from a Lebenshilfe residential facility in Oschatz.

I hope that even more young people will feel like actively helping to shape something, that they will feel like getting involved on behalf of other people, and that everyone will not just be looking out for themselves. I hope for warmth in people' hearts and more humanity, friendliness, friendly encounters, tolerance and the ability to overcome great divides. Unfortunately, this sounds very utopian at the moment, but optimism and hope should never die. The only prerequisite is that you are under 31 and have the desire to get involved. We are politically and denominationally unaffiliated. We are always happy to meet people. We can be reached via our Facebook or Insta page and are happy to announce the next meeting - currently online.

I am an educator with my heart and soul. That's why activities with children are always my favorite, because they are especially close to my heart. We have been cooperating for years with a residential facility for children and young people with disabilities in Oschatz. Many of the thirty residents have been living there for a long time. We have been able to watch them grow up over the past years. They always look forward to our time together as much as we do. The activities range from Easter baskets to Halloween parties, vacation decorations, and visits to Dynamo Stadium. But my absolute highlight was probably last year's Christmas party, where they all performed something and were able to unwrap their individual gifts with great gratitude and joy. Everyone was very excited to show us their rooms and were so happy about the little gestures. It flooded me with so much love, and the children's shining eyes also made my face and heart glow. Moments like that and what it means to the kids can't be compared. I am proud to be able to give something back to society, to be a role model and to see opportunities instead of obstacles. It's so easy to make someone else happy. Most of us are doing so well. We should appreciate that with more gratitude and strive to give some of it to others."
