"At work, Covid was only moderately noticeable over the summer; the palliative care unit where I work was able to run relatively normally within Covid directives. Special visiting hours for the palliative patients were also possible. The worry and anxiety was still palpable. By November, things were moving rapidly, at least it felt that way. The already established Covid ward had to be quickly extended to the area of internal medicine and finally also - for logistical reasons - to the palliative ward, which had to be closed and now operates as a ward for suspected cases. This gives greater security to the staff, but the palliative patients were in turn discharged or transferred to normal wards. There, they cannot be cared for comprehensively due to the already existing shortage of specialists and the existing workload. This is a point that gives me particular cause for concern, even though I can well understand the measure.

For me, my view of reporting has also changed. A lot is written about the strain and overburden on intensive care units. That is true. But it is also true that the staff of the "normal" Covid ward is enormously challenged, especially since my colleagues have to focus on patient observation in order to be able to recognize deterioration in the patient's condition in time. But you also have to care for 10 to 15 patients, and even more on night duty. The amount of concentration required is enormous. I would therefore like to see a comprehensive view of all areas in the media. Just as I would wish that not only doctors speak for the nursing staff, but that we ourselves are asked. A doctor or physician knows only a fraction of what we in nursing do. I do not mean that physicians should not speak about nursing at all. But in public debates - when it comes to nursing specifically - the mic is too rarely handed to nursing colleagues.

In short, medical colleagues make medical diagnoses, that is, they diagnose diseases. Nursing expertise deals with the management of an illness, with self-care deficits, and has the goal of restoring a patient's autonomy on a physical, psychosocial, communicative level. And that is what is so important with Covid. We observe, we analyze. We perceive fears that are very palpable right now. And we also try to help people help themselves.

I think we all have to take responsibility right now in different areas. I also take responsibility by treating every patient the same, no matter what his or her opinion of Covid is, and by consistently applying protective measures, professionally and privately. Responsibility also falls to the media as to which voices they choose to provide a platform for. Responsibility is on each individual to realize that we need to change our thinking and act in solidarity for others rather than for ourselves alone. Much has been philosophized and debated about the term "freedom" in this context. But it can also mean being protected. Protection from illness. Protection from overwork.

I hope that many colleagues will have the opportunity to report what they experience and how they feel about it on various platforms, such as this one."

"I have lived in Dresden for six years. I was born in Poland in 1989. At that time, my parents were still able to come back to Germany as "SpÃ¤taussiedler" (ethnic German immigrants). My dad did not want to continue working in the country for peanuts in Poland, instead, he was determined to offer me a better future. So on 20.11.1989, they left with a beige "Polska Fiat 125" and a few diapers, clothes, and some provisions on the wobble track called Autostrada!

I still admire their courage, just leaving everything familiar behind for a piece of freedom and the prospect of a better future! Now there were two options: North or South? We went to southern Germany, Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. For the simple reason that there were already relatives there. Aunt Rosa and Aunt Halina and many other helpful people were good advisors in the German bureaucratic struggle. Initially, my parents received an ID card for "displaced persons and refugees" and were housed in a small hotel. There was also support from the DRK and Caritas.

I really had a great childhood. There were a lot of cool kids in my class; one was from Croatia, others came from Turkey, Ireland, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, and I was from Poland. For us kids, that was normal! "Where is Poland, anyway?" "Really - you know Polish? Say something!", and the other way around as well!

In 1998 we moved to Saxony, to a rural area. My eyes were curious. What are those loud cars? - Trabbis. Never seen before! Everything was new, but also somehow old. I missed my pretzels, but there were "Eierschecke" and "sour eggs" - also fine! In 1998, I already had to experience racism as a child. These are small sentences that can do a lot to a child's soul. As a nine-year-old, you suddenly don't understand the world anymore! Unfortunately, I "lost" my mother tongue because of shame and fear. At that time, it was more important for me to have friends and to be accepted. Looking back, it makes me very sad. What I have left are a few fragments of this language. My dearest memories! No one should be insulted because of their origin, especially not a child. Children are curious, open to new things, unprejudiced. Adults lack education and knowledge of history. Parents should act as role models and show children the world instead of spreading fear.

Today I am a registered nurse. I started training at 17; I finished at 20. In 2013, I completed an additional qualification as a stroke nurse. Now I have already been on shift duty on an internal ward for eleven years, with participation in an established dementia program. Based on the foundation of person-centered care, we address their needs at all times. Dementia patients, those at risk of delirium, their relatives, and we too benefit from this approach.
Since March, our hospital has been well prepared; we were armed. The lockdown saved us a lot of suffering. Since November, the situation has become much worse, we are at the limit of our capacity, both logistically and in terms of personnel. Our "normal ward" has now become an extended Covid ward. The condition of these patients is anything but stable. I appeal to the society, please wear your masks. Each individual bears full responsibility for this precarious situation.

Only together can we get through this pandemic. In our job, we treat everyone equally. It is very important to me that this beautiful city stands together and understands how important each and every one of us is, regardless of religion, gender or background. You can only develop personally and socially with an open mind. This is what I wish for Dresden, Saxony, and for the world . The world has become sick. We have to stop looking for a scapegoat and start working on ourselves and find a solution instead of complaining about everything and everyone.

Stay home for Christmas - "together - alone." Explain to your loved ones that we have been in a fucking pandemic for quite some time, and it can be deadly. Please don't meet out of a pure "sense of duty" or "but we meet every year". No folks, this year is different, period. I hope for sanity and warm hearts that can look far ahead!

I don't post much else. No time. That's probably the problem. Nurses and doctors just don't have time to hang out on Insta & Co. We're on the clock. Nonstop. We too have families who "miss their laid-back mommy". After a shift, I'm exhausted. Physically and mentally. Broken from worrying if this patient I just took care of will still be around next week. Today is my day off. I should eat, drink, catch up on sleep - but I feel a responsibility to write these words. The media presence of the deniers is so shameful! Time for the right ones to have their say! Hopefully it is not too late.

And to all the colleagues out there who are just keeping the system running: Get through your shift well! Allow yourselves time to take a sip of water and breathe!

Ich bin eher kein besonders Ã¤ngstlicher Mensch. Ãber die Jahre hat man berufsbedingt mit so vielen infektiÃ¶sen Erkrankungen zu tun gehabt, dass man eine gewisse Routine entwickelt im Umgang. "I am a specialist nurse for intensive care and have been working in intensive care units since 1998. Until 2006, I worked in Wiesbaden and Mainz before I came back to my old home Dresden due to love. I got the idea of becoming a nurse during my civilian service, which I did in home care for the elderly. I was always interested in the technical side of intensive care. The possibilities for providing intensive care to patients today are enormous.

After more than twenty years, you develop a routine. In a way, you've already seen everything. That also helps emotionally. I separate myself very strongly from my work. When I leave the clinic, I don't usually think about it anymore, I don't think you can do the job over such a long period of time without some kind of management.

I have been working in an internal intensive care unit since 2006. A large number of our patients are well over sixty years old. One always wonders about the sense of providing the maximum of intensive medical therapy to patients over eighty years old, where it is clear that if they survive, they can never have the same quality of life as before. But who wants to decide that, that would be triage. Right now we are still treating Corona-free or post-Covid patients on our ward, but that may change when the Covid-ITS wards are full.

What always dismays me on social media is that there are people who deny the existence of Covid or compare it to the flu. These patients are all so severely systemically ill and have developed so many issues from the Covid infection that even if they survive, they are likely to have very severe physical limitations for a long time or forever. I tend not to be a particularly anxious person. Over the years, I have had to deal with so many infectious diseases due to my job that I have developed a certain routine in dealing with them. I still don't want to get Covid, because you don't know beforehand what course it will take.

On our ward, we are a team that has grown together; some of us have been working together for over thirty years, so it feels a bit like family when you come to work. That helps during stressful times. I hope it stays that way. Of course, the employer would like to have staff to be flexible across all ICUs, but they sometimes overlook the benefits of having a team that has developed over time.

I still enjoy working in my job, even though the shift system takes up your life. I personally compensate by working part-time. We have two dogs and more recently a cat, which creates a nice balance. Hopefully we can travel again next year, that's important for us. Personally, I am basically happy!
For the future, I hope that the division of society doesn't increase even more, especially in Saxony.

"I am a specialist nurse for intensive care and have been working in intensive care units since 1998. Until 2006, I worked in Wiesbaden and Mainz before I came back to my old home Dresden due to love. I got the idea of becoming a nurse during my civilian service, which I did in home care for the elderly. I was always interested in the technical side of intensive care. The possibilities for providing intensive care to patients today are enormous.

After more than twenty years, you develop a routine. In a way, you've already seen everything. That also helps emotionally. I separate myself very strongly from my work. When I leave the clinic, I don't usually think about it anymore, I don't think you can do the job over such a long period of time without some kind of management.

I have been working in an internal intensive care unit since 2006. A large number of our patients are well over sixty years old. One always wonders about the sense of providing the maximum of intensive medical therapy to patients over eighty years old, where it is clear that if they survive, they can never have the same quality of life as before. But who wants to decide that, that would be triage. Right now we are still treating Corona-free or post-Covid patients on our ward, but that may change when the Covid-ITS wards are full.

What always dismays me on social media is that there are people who deny the existence of Covid or compare it to the flu. These patients are all so severely systemically ill and have developed so many issues from the Covid infection that even if they survive, they are likely to have very severe physical limitations for a long time or forever. I tend not to be a particularly anxious person. Over the years, I have had to deal with so many infectious diseases due to my job that I have developed a certain routine in dealing with them. I still don't want to get Covid, because you don't know beforehand what course it will take.

On our ward, we are a team that has grown together; some of us have been working together for over thirty years, so it feels a bit like family when you come to work. That helps during stressful times. I hope it stays that way. Of course, the employer would like to have staff to be flexible across all ICUs, but they sometimes overlook the benefits of having a team that has developed over time.

I still enjoy working in my job, even though the shift system takes up your life. I personally compensate by working part-time. We have two dogs and more recently a cat, which creates a nice balance. Hopefully we can travel again next year, that's important for us. Personally, I am basically happy!
For the future, I hope that the division of society doesn't increase even more, especially in Saxony.

"I originally come from WeiÃwasser in the Oberlausitz region. I completed my training at the Carl-Thiem-Klinikum Cottbus between 2011 and 2014. I worked there as a staff nurse until 2017. This means I was deployed on every ward and in every specialty. This allowed me to gain a lot of experience. In 2017, I moved to Dresden, where I first worked at the Diakonissenkrankenhaus Dresden on an accident surgery ward. I have been since 2018 at the University Hospital Dresden as a staff nurse. Because of the pandemic, I have been working in the Covid emergency room since the beginning in March.

Right now, I am working beyond my limits almost every day to get the best results for patients. It is chaos at work, because there are more and more cases. Most of the time, it is impossible to take a break during working hours. The patients I take care of are usually very affected and unstable. In order to get enough oxygen, almost all patients need a high-flow, which blows high volumes of oxygen into the patient through a nasal cannula. We need to constantly monitor the blood gases in order to be able to react quickly. If this measure is not sufficient because patients are getting worse, there is the option of non-invasive ventilation. Here, the patients are fitted with a mask on their face, which presses the oxygen into them. The patients are fully conscious and afraid, because it is an uncomfortable feeling to breathe with the device. On average, I look after between three and six patients in a shift. All of them are isolated and I have to work for several hours in my protective clothing. That's particularly exhausting, because at some point you start sweating and it's hard to understand the patients, because some of them hardly have the strength to speak louder. The work often overwhelms me; I would like to take more time for each individual so that they are less afraid and feel safe. At the end of my shift, I am usually dehydrated because I hardly have time to drink or eat. As a result, I am very tired and worn out.

To cope with this, I have developed a few rituals for myself. When a person takes his or her last breath, I try to be there or make sure that his or her relatives are there. The main thing is that the person does not have to be alone in the last minutes and hears a friendly voice and sees a friendly face. Once the person is deceased, I open all the windows to release his soul. I usually say a few kind words to the deceased, such as "Now you've finally made it and can be at peace." In severe cases, I talk about it with my colleagues and review it again. The university hospital now provides psychologists for the staff to talk about bad cases.

The second wave was foreseeable and has hit the health system hard. The numbers will go up even more after Christmas. I don't know how long my colleagues, both doctors and nurses, will be able to handle this situation. I wish that everyone from the entire population would follow the rules and not see the lockdown as a "punishment" or anything else. It can affect anyone. Adhere to the regulations and do not be selfish -- think of everyone else. Many lives can be saved. Above all, I hope that all our colleagues have the stamina to survive this pandemic together. Despite the tense situation, we should never lose our smiles and our optimism. Because that is precisely what helps those affected to summon up the strength to fight."

"I have worked at JohannstÃ¤dter Kulturtreff as a cultural administrator for a year or so. Originally I am from Berlin, but I have already worked in the Saxon cultural landscape for 5 years. As a trained art historian, I worked for three years in the Museum Bautzen as a museum educator and then I was allowed to learn more about the gingerbread craft in Pulsnitz as a research assistant in the City and Gingerbread Museum.

Now I am responsible for press and public relations at the JohannstÃ¤dter Kulturtreff, and I also organize and plan smaller and larger events at the Kulturtreff. However, in the current situation, a lot of things fall by the wayside. At the moment I am working intensively on our crowdfunding campaign. Have a look at: https://www.startnext.com/virenschutzprogramm/.

In the first Lockdown, we thought about how we can stay in contact with our visitors. That' s when we came up with the idea of the "JOHANNSTÃDTER virenschutzPROGRAMM" (JOHANNSTÃDTER virus protection program). With this magazine, we have the opportunity to continue to be there for people despite the crisis and to provide them with suggestions with alternative activities free of charge! The magazine is very close to my heart and we are happy about every little support.

In the magazine everything that the JohannstÃ¤dter Kultutrtreff stands for comes together: We do not simply decide what we offer to the people in our building, but our visitors themselves decide how they want to shape the center. We try to unite the different activities and interests as well as cultures, so that everyone can find an area where they feel at home. During my research and while writing the articles, I was able to take a look at many courses and saw how enthusiastically they were received. For young and old, there really is something for everyone. It was especially nice for me when I sat down with the women from CafÃ© Halva. This is a program offered in cooperation with the AuslÃ¤nderrat Dresden e.V. (Dresden Foreigners' Council), in which women from very different countries of origin cook together every Thursday in our KulturcafÃ©, offering their food in the BegegnungscafÃ© and engaging in conversation with the guests. I sat down with three women outside in the summer and they told me their recipes. But it didn't stop at just exchanging recipes, I got to know the women better at that point. They told me how they came to Germany and since then I have felt a completely different connection to the women. Everyone should feel heard and that they have been accepted. "In Dresden bin ich seit inzwischen fast vierzehn Jahren, ursprÃ¼nglich bin ich Hannoveranerin und nach dem Studium und einem kurzen Abstecher nach Hamburg 2007 hergezogen. Zwar kann ich zu meinem groÃen Bedauern bis heute kein SÃ¤chsisch, Buchteln und Letscho find ich auch eher mitti, aber hier habe ich meine Liebe zur BÃ¼hne und zum Poetry Slam entdeckt und die immer schon vorhandene zum Schreiben endlich auch zum Beruf gemacht - meine zwei BÃ¼cher sind hier geboren, ich habe mehrere Veranstaltungsreihen - Geschichten Ã¼bern Gartenzaun in der Groovestation und Lesen fÃ¼r Bier in der Scheune, plus noch so dies und jenes.

Nach vielen Jahren als freie Redakteurin fÃ¼r diverse Stadtmagazine bin ich inzwischen feste freie Redakteurin bei einer Dresdner Tageszeitung. Davon abgesehen mache ich viele redaktionelle und Texterjobs, gebe Workshops fÃ¼r Kreatives Schreiben und Poetry Slams an Schulen und Jugendeinrichtungen, moderiere und booke diverse Veranstaltungen, vor allem im Literatur- und Kulturbereich. Im Hauptjob bin ich in Teilzeit persÃ¶nliche Assistentin fÃ¼r eine junge Frau mit Behinderung - eine sehr schÃ¶ne und unglaublich bereichernde TÃ¤tigkeit. Ich liebe schon immer die Vielfalt und Abwechslung, auch wenn es viel Arbeit ist, fÃ¼hlt es sich oft nicht so an. Was fÃ¼r ein wahnsinniges Privileg das ist, merke ich vor allem jetzt unter Corona. Schon immer habe ich viel zu Hause gearbeitet. Workshops digital zu leiten ist eine Herausforderung, weil der Kontakt einfach fehlt und vieles dann eben anders funktioniert. Auch digitale Veranstaltungen zu moderieren ist eine dieser spannenden Neuerungen. Trotzdem ist das ja nicht fÃ¼r die Katz, vieles davon wird sicher auch in Zukunft helfen, neue Methoden zum Einsatz kommen.
Zu Beginn des ersten Lockdowns dachte ich noch, schÃ¶n, habe ich endlich mal wieder Zeit, fÃ¼r die BÃ¼hne zu schreiben, da war lange nicht die Luft dafÃ¼r. Das funktioniert aber kaum, weil meine Slamtexte vor allem aus Alltagsbeobachtungen und Erlebnissen entstehen, und da passiert ja gerade einfach nicht viel, was Inspiration bringt. Weil ich sehr breit aufgestellt bin, geht es mir trotz Pandemie ganz gut - viele meiner Kolleg*innen, die hauptsÃ¤chlich ihren Lebensunterhalt auf der BÃ¼hne und mit Auftritten verdienen, haben wie die ganze Kulturbranche massive Existenzsorgen. Ich finde es extrem beunruhigend und auch schlicht unfair, wie damit umgegangen wird.

Mein VerhÃ¤ltnis zu Dresden ist an sich ein gutes, ich hab mich damals auf den zweiten Blick in die Stadt verliebt, auch heute noch lebe ich gern hier, wenngleich ich es zunehmend anstrengender finde. Ich empfinde es schon so, dass hier - generell in Sachsen - oft mit der nicht nachvollziehbaren Bockigkeit eines Kleinkindes, dem an der Supermarktkasse die Schokolade verweigert wird, auf einfach alles reagiert wird, das entschieden wird. NatÃ¼rlich ist das eine Minderheit, die ist aber - mÃ¶glicherweise in Ermangelung anderer BeschÃ¤ftigungen - besonders prÃ¤sent und laut. Auch ich finde nicht alle MaÃnahmen und Entscheidungen im Zusammenhang mit Corona immer als angemessen, gerechtfertigt oder fair. Und mit einer chronischen Atemwegserkrankung ist es auch fÃ¼r mich kein SpaÃ, nun fast Ã¼berall Maske tragen zu mÃ¼ssen - all das ist aber weit entfernt von einer so gern zitierten Diktatur. Klar wird die individuelle Freiheit fÃ¼r einen begrenzten Zeitraum eingeschrÃ¤nkt und schÃ¶n ist das fÃ¼r niemandem. Aber wir haben immerhin viele Freiheiten, die man einschrÃ¤nken kann. DafÃ¼r kÃ¶nnen wir nur dankbar sein. Und solange man den ganzen Tag in den Kommentarspalten bei Facebook abhÃ¤ngen, Whataboutism betreiben, wirre Theorien verbreiten, hetzen und den Graupapagei mimen kann, kann es ja so schlimm wohl auch noch nicht sein.

Weihnachten werde ich zum ersten Mal in meinem Leben nicht mit meiner Familie in Niedersachsen verbringen - weil es einfach gerade nicht sinnvoll ist. Die Entscheidung dazu war eine ganz schwere, auch weil mein Papa seit zwei Jahren nicht mehr mit uns feiern kann. Wir sind uns trotzdem alle einig darÃ¼ber. Und es hat tatsÃ¤chlich auch so viele positive Aspekte - ich fand den Dezember trotz viel Arbeit nie besinnlicher, Schenken macht dieses Jahr so viel mehr SpaÃ, mit Familie und Freund*innen werden Karten und PÃ¤ckchen quer durchs Land geschickt. Ich bin Ã¼berzeugt, dass jede*r durchaus auch was Positives in dieser seltsamen Zeit finden kÃ¶nnte - aber stattdessen sehen viele nur, dass ihnen was weggenommen wird - auch wenn sie das am Ende vielleicht gar nicht brauchen oder vermissen. Es geht uns allen hier vergleichsweise gut. Es fallen keine Bomben. Niemand wird verhaftet, weil er die falsche Meinung Ã¤uÃert. Niemand muss verhungern. Weihnachten fÃ¤llt nicht aus. Es ist einfach nur anders. Und VerÃ¤nderungen sind normal - auch, dass man sich die nicht immer aussuchen kann, wie sie einem gefallen. Ich wÃ¼nsche mir, dass das neue Jahr ein bisschen positiver verlÃ¤uft als das aktuelle und trotzdem auch die schÃ¶nen Momente 2020 nicht komplett unter den Tisch fallen. Es gibt ja nicht nur schwarz und weiÃ und natÃ¼rlich war auch nicht alles ScheiÃe. Ich freu mich drauf, meine Familie bald wieder sehen zu kÃ¶nnen. AuÃerdem wÃ¼rde ich mich freuen, wenn ich bald wieder tolle GÃ¤ste auf der Gartenzaun-BÃ¼hne in der Groovestation begrÃ¼Ãen kann, und wir zusammen mit dem Publikum einen schÃ¶nen Abend haben kÃ¶nnen. Die BÃ¼hne fehlt uns allen sehr, die Backstagemomente, das Zusammensitzen und Quatschen nach der Show. Ein paar wenige Auftritte gab es ja in diesem Jahr, die alle anders, sehr besonders und vor allem von der Freude Ã¼berschwemmt waren, mal wieder vor Publikum spielen zu kÃ¶nnen und Freund*innen und Kolleg*innen zu sehen, wenn auch nicht drÃ¼cken zu kÃ¶nnen. Ein bisschen mehr Miteinander statt Gegeneinander wÃ¤re schÃ¶n, Ã¼berall und generell. Die ganzen Schwurbel-Ottos und ihre kruden Theorien gepaart mit einem grenzenlosen Egoismus sind schon sehr zermÃ¼rbend und ermÃ¼dend. ZunÃ¤chst aber freue ich mich auf entspannte Weihnachten mit der fabelhaften Familie meines Freundes in Radebeul, ein bisschen Zweisamkeit, zur Ruhe kommen, netflixen, zu viel Essen und dann mit neuer Energie die Herausforderungen des neuen Jahres angehen."

"I've been in Dresden for almost fourteen years now. Originally I'm from Hanover and moved here in 2007 after my studies and a short detour to Hamburg. To my great regret, I still can't speak Saxon, and I also find Buchteln and Letscho rather mediocre, but this is where I discovered my love of the stage and poetry slam, and where I finally turned my ever-present love of writing into a career - my two books were born here, I have several event series - Geschichten Ã¼bern Gartenzaun (Stories over the Garden Fence) at the Groovestation and Lesen fÃ¼r Bier (Reading for Beer) at the Scheune, plus this and that.

After many years as a freelance editor for various city magazines, I am now a permanent freelance editor for a Dresden daily newspaper. Apart from that, I do a lot of editorial and copywriting jobs, give workshops for creative writing and poetry slams at schools and youth institutions, moderate and book various events, mainly in the literary and cultural field. In my main job, I am a part-time personal assistant for a young woman with disabilities - a very nice and incredibly rewarding job. I've always loved the variety and diversity, even though it's a lot of work, it often doesn't feel like it. I realize what an insane privilege it is, especially now under Corona. I've always done a lot of work at home. Leading workshops digitally is a challenge because the contact is simply missing and a lot of things work differently then. Moderating digital events is also one of these exciting innovations. Nevertheless, it's not all for nothing; a lot of it will certainly help in the future, and I will be using new methods.

At the beginning of the first lockdown, I still thought," nice, I finally have time to write for the stage again." I hadn't had the time to do that for a long time. But it's hardly possible, because my slam texts are mainly based on everyday observations and experiences, and there's just not much happening right now to inspire me. Because I'm very broadly oriented, I'm doing quite well despite the pandemic - many of my colleagues, who mainly earn their living on stage and with performances, have massive existential worries, just like the entire cultural industry. I find it extremely worrying and also simply unfair how it is being dealt with.

My relationship with Dresden is actually a good one. I fell in love with the city at second sight, and I still like living here today, even though I find it increasingly exhausting. I do feel that here - generally in Saxony - people often react to simply everything that is decided with the incomprehensible petulance of a toddler who is refused chocolate at the supermarket checkout. Of course, this is a minority, but it is particularly present and loud - possibly for lack of other occupations. I, too, do not always find all Corona-related measures and decisions to be appropriate, justified, or fair. And with a chronic respiratory disease, it is no fun for me either to now have to wear masks almost everywhere - but all this is far from a dictatorship so often cited. Of course, individual freedom is restricted for a limited period of time, and that's not nice for anyone. But at least we have many freedoms that can be restricted. We can only be grateful for that. And as long as you can hang out in the Facebook comment columns all day, do whataboutism, spread crazy theories, hound people and act like a gray parrot, it can't be that bad.

For the first time in my life I will not spend Christmas with my family in Niedersachsen - because it just doesn't make sense. The decision to do this was a very difficult one, partly because my dad hasn't been able to celebrate with us for two years. Nevertheless, we all agreed on it. And it really does have so many positive aspects - despite all the work, I've never found December more contemplative, gift-giving is so much more fun this year, cards and parcels are sent across the country with family and friends. I am convinced that everyone could find something positive in this strange time - but instead many only see that something is taken away from them - even though they may not need or miss it in the end. We are all doing comparatively well here. There are no bombs falling. No one is arrested for expressing the wrong opinion. No one has to starve. Christmas is not cancelled. It's just different. And changes are normal - even the fact that you can't always choose the changes you like.I hope that the new year will be a bit more positive than the current one, and that the good moments of 2020 won't completely fall by the wayside. There is not only black and white and of course not everything was shit. I'm looking forward to seeing my family again soon. I would also be happy if I can once again welcome great guests on the Gartenzaun stage in the Groovestation, and we can spend a nice evening together with the audience. We all miss the stage a lot, the backstage moments, sitting together and chatting after the show. There were a few gigs this year, which were all different, very special and above all flooded with the joy of being able to play in front of an audience again and to see friends and colleagues, even if we can't hug them. A little more togetherness instead of antagonism would be nice, everywhere and in general. The whole bunch of "Schwurbel-Ottos" and their crude theories paired with a boundless egoism are very grueling and tiring. But first I'm looking forward to a relaxed Christmas with my boyfriend's fabulous family in Radebeul, a bit of togetherness, quiet time, netflixing, too much food and then tackling the challenges of the new year with renewed energy."

Ein bisschen mehr Miteinander statt Gegeneinander wÃ¤re schÃ¶n, Ã¼berall und generell. Die ganzen Schwurbel-Ottos und ihre kruden Theorien gepaart mit einem grenzenlosen Egoismus sind schon sehr zermÃ¼rbend und ermÃ¼dend. ZunÃ¤chst aber freue ich mich auf entspannte Weihnachten mit der fabelhaften Familie meines Freundes in Radebeul, ein bisschen Zweisamkeit, zur Ruhe kommen, netflixen, zu viel Essen und dann mit neuer Energie die Herausforderungen des neuen Jahres angehen."

"I've been in Dresden for almost fourteen years now. Originally I'm from Hanover and moved here in 2007 after my studies and a short detour to Hamburg. To my great regret, I still can't speak Saxon, and I also find Buchteln and Letscho rather mediocre, but this is where I discovered my love of the stage and poetry slam, and where I finally turned my ever-present love of writing into a career - my two books were born here, I have several event series - Geschichten Ã¼bern Gartenzaun (Stories over the Garden Fence) at the Groovestation and Lesen fÃ¼r Bier (Reading for Beer) at the Scheune, plus this and that.

After many years as a freelance editor for various city magazines, I am now a permanent freelance editor for a Dresden daily newspaper. Apart from that, I do a lot of editorial and copywriting jobs, give workshops for creative writing and poetry slams at schools and youth institutions, moderate and book various events, mainly in the literary and cultural field. In my main job, I am a part-time personal assistant for a young woman with disabilities - a very nice and incredibly rewarding job. I've always loved the variety and diversity, even though it's a lot of work, it often doesn't feel like it. I realize what an insane privilege it is, especially now under Corona. I've always done a lot of work at home. Leading workshops digitally is a challenge because the contact is simply missing and a lot of things work differently then. Moderating digital events is also one of these exciting innovations. Nevertheless, it's not all for nothing; a lot of it will certainly help in the future, and I will be using new methods.

At the beginning of the first lockdown, I still thought," nice, I finally have time to write for the stage again." I hadn't had the time to do that for a long time. But it's hardly possible, because my slam texts are mainly based on everyday observations and experiences, and there's just not much happening right now to inspire me. Because I'm very broadly oriented, I'm doing quite well despite the pandemic - many of my colleagues, who mainly earn their living on stage and with performances, have massive existential worries, just like the entire cultural industry. I find it extremely worrying and also simply unfair how it is being dealt with.

My relationship with Dresden is actually a good one. I fell in love with the city at second sight, and I still like living here today, even though I find it increasingly exhausting. I do feel that here - generally in Saxony - people often react to simply everything that is decided with the incomprehensible petulance of a toddler who is refused chocolate at the supermarket checkout. Of course, this is a minority, but it is particularly present and loud - possibly for lack of other occupations. I, too, do not always find all Corona-related measures and decisions to be appropriate, justified, or fair. And with a chronic respiratory disease, it is no fun for me either to now have to wear masks almost everywhere - but all this is far from a dictatorship so often cited. Of course, individual freedom is restricted for a limited period of time, and that's not nice for anyone. But at least we have many freedoms that can be restricted. We can only be grateful for that. And as long as you can hang out in the Facebook comment columns all day, do whataboutism, spread crazy theories, hound people and act like a gray parrot, it can't be that bad.

For the first time in my life I will not spend Christmas with my family in Niedersachsen - because it just doesn't make sense. The decision to do this was a very difficult one, partly because my dad hasn't been able to celebrate with us for two years. Nevertheless, we all agreed on it. And it really does have so many positive aspects - despite all the work, I've never found December more contemplative, gift-giving is so much more fun this year, cards and parcels are sent across the country with family and friends. I am convinced that everyone could find something positive in this strange time - but instead many only see that something is taken away from them - even though they may not need or miss it in the end. We are all doing comparatively well here. There are no bombs falling. No one is arrested for expressing the wrong opinion. No one has to starve. Christmas is not cancelled. It's just different. And changes are normal - even the fact that you can't always choose the changes you like.I hope that the new year will be a bit more positive than the current one, and that the good moments of 2020 won't completely fall by the wayside. There is not only black and white and of course not everything was shit. I'm looking forward to seeing my family again soon. I would also be happy if I can once again welcome great guests on the Gartenzaun stage in the Groovestation, and we can spend a nice evening together with the audience. We all miss the stage a lot, the backstage moments, sitting together and chatting after the show. There were a few gigs this year, which were all different, very special and above all flooded with the joy of being able to play in front of an audience again and to see friends and colleagues, even if we can't hug them. A little more togetherness instead of antagonism would be nice, everywhere and in general. The whole bunch of "Schwurbel-Ottos" and their crude theories paired with a boundless egoism are very grueling and tiring. But first I'm looking forward to a relaxed Christmas with my boyfriend's fabulous family in Radebeul, a bit of togetherness, quiet time, netflixing, too much food and then tackling the challenges of the new year with renewed energy."

"In 1992, my husband and I packed our little suitcase and moved from North Rhine-Westphalia to Dresden. We were just in our mid-twenties and full of enthusiasm for the project for which we wanted to work here. The first few days and weeks were difficult; we had left an intact environment and were embarking on an adventure. In my memory, everything was gray. We still remember the Frauenkirche as a ruin. I'm grateful for every photo we took back then, because you forget too quickly and when you look at Dresden today, you can hardly believe it. The first period was difficult because we didn't have any friends here yet, and unfortunately many people had great prejudices against us as West Germans. For that reason, we decided to stay only for a while and then move back home.
However, our lives took a different turn. We had a wonderful daughter and then felt more and more at home and through the kindergarten and school then also a bit more a part of the community. We liked many things, such as the imperfection. So much change was still possible here, and that impressed us.
Unfortunately, something else always struck us especially when we were once again with the family at home. There was so much openness and friendliness, you were noticed. I miss it to this day; so many people here lower their gaze when they see you.

When we had the refugee crisis in 2015, I was shocked by the attitude of many people. It caused some upheaval in my circle of friends, because in my eyes it is simply inhumane. Unfortunately, I still encounter everyday racism here today that leaves me speechless. "We have nothing against foreigners...but!" At that time, I wanted to get involved with refugee children, but then I stopped because I was met with so much incomprehension and pure hatred.

Then came Pegida, who are still ruining the reputation of this beautiful city. In my circle of friends there were many voices that found what was said there to be quite right. I was once at a counter-demo, at the time when up to 20000 supporters gathered on Theaterplatz. The 50 other protesters and I were led away by the police along the Terrassenufer, where the gathering then dispersed. I had never been to a demo before and was not politically active. But in this case I couldn't help it, I had to oppose what was going on there on Theaterplatz. It is still a mystery to me why the majority of the population remained so quiet. An acquaintance told me that the guiding principle of many people was: "See a lot, hear a lot, say nothing."

First we briefly had the NPD and then the AfD with a quarter of the population's vote in the Saxon state parliament. I began to feel uncomfortable and the thought of leaving Saxony again came up for the first time in more than twenty years.

And now Corona. I get really scared when I read and hear what people in my vicinity say. I am bombarded by deniers, conspiracy theorists, and busybodies, and it is hard for me not to doubt their state of mind. The proportion of contrarians in my circle of acquaintances is enormously high. That worries me!

My daughter always tells me that many things will become better with her generation. I really hope so! Because actually I don't want to leave Dresden...

Manchmal erhÃ¶ht ein Master die Chance auf eine wissenschaftliche Karriere. Aber auch das hat leider nicht geklappt. Der damaligen Liebe wegen war ich aber auch an Dresden gebunden. Also habe ich nach dem Studium im Onlineweinhandel und spÃ¤ter bei Tranquillo im Onlineshop gearbeitet. Dabei konnte ich etwas Marketingluft schnuppern, was ich echt spannend fand. Daher habe ich nebenberuflich eine Weiterbildung zum Online Marketing Manager gemacht und anschlieÃend in einer Marketingagentur gearbeitet. Seit diesem Februar bin ich bei einem IT- und Software-Dienstleister im Bereich Marketing angestellt. Oft denke ich, dass ich die Zeit im Weinhandel und bei der Marketingagentur streichen wÃ¼rde, aber im Grunde habe ich da viel Ã¼ber mich gelernt. Was erwarte ich von meinem Arbeitgeber? Was bin ich bereit zu opfern bzw. zu geben? Wo sage ich einfach nein? Es waren negative Erfahrungen, aus denen ich aber viel Positives gewinnen konnte. Denn ich weiÃ jetzt, wo ich beruflich hinmÃ¶chte.

Ich wollte damals unbedingt nach Dresden, weil ich die GegensÃ¤tzlichkeit hier so mochte. Auf der einen Seite das historische Dresden mit seinen alten, barocken Bauten - Tourimagnet. Auf der anderen Seite die Neustadt - alternativ, multikulturell und frei! Nicht ganz so ,,schÃ¶n'' an jeder Ecke, aber mit interessanten Menschen und einem bunten LebensgefÃ¼hl. Seit ich hier wohne, hat sich jedoch einiges geÃ¤ndert. Immer mehr moderne BauklÃ¶tze werden aufgestellt. Kleine grÃ¼ne Ecken weichen hÃ¤sslichen Betonriesen. Die Mieten sind exorbitant gestiegen. Noch viel schlimmer ist aber der politische Wandel, der sich hier vollzogen hat. Ich meine, diesen braunen Mist gab's schon immer, aber irgendwie wird er immer salonfÃ¤higer und Ã¶ffentlicher zur Schau gestellt. Ich finde es beschÃ¤mend und traurig, wenn von Dresden oder aber Sachsen allgemein berichtet wird. Selten ist es positiv. Ich war wirklich mal ,,stolz'', hier zu wohnen. Aber nun wohne ich in einer Stadt, in der Pegida und AfD, also Nazis, fast gÃ¤nzlich ungehindert aufmarschieren und hier so viel UnterstÃ¼tzung finden.

Um ehrlich zu sein, habe ich mich politisch nie stark engagiert. In Dresden ging ich hin und wieder auf Demos (gegen Rechts und Rassismus und fÃ¼r mehr Toleranz) oder blockieren, aber in der Ã¼brigen Zeit bin ich politisch eher inaktiv. Ich mÃ¼sste selbst viel mehr den Arsch hochkriegen, ganz klar. Meiner Meinung nach sollte man in der Bildung, also der Schule, mehr den Fokus darauf legen. Nicht nur in Geschichte, sondern auch in Sozialkunde, Ethik, Religion oder AGs mÃ¼ssen spezielle Projekte gegen Rechts oder Rassismus durchgefÃ¼hrt werden. Kinder bzw. SchÃ¼ler mÃ¼ssen sich intensiv mit diesen Themen auseinandersetzen, um Ideologien zu erkennen und diese kritisch zu bewerten. AuÃerdem sollte man in den Reihen der Regierung, der Polizei und so weiter genauer durchleuchten, welche rechten Strukturen da herrschen. Ich habe allgemein das GefÃ¼hl, Sachsen und auch Dresden sind auf dem rechten Auge blind.

Was mich gerade sehr beschÃ¤ftigt, ist die Coronapandemie. Ich finde es krass, wie sich das Ganze entwickelt hat. Dass gerade Sachsen so hart betroffen ist, stimmt mich nachdenklich, vor allem auch im Hinblick darauf, dass hier anscheinend so viele Schwurbler unterwegs sind. Bereits im FrÃ¼hjahr habe ich alles mit Sorge verfolgt, als es von sehr vielen noch nicht ernst genommen wurde. Seit MÃ¤rz befinde ich mich nun im Homeoffice und fÃ¼hle mich sicherer damit. Als im Sommer die Zahlen sanken, ist Covid bei mir gedanklich etwas nach hinten gerutscht, auch wenn ich immer daran geglaubt habe, dass eine zweite Welle kommen wird. Nun, da es so ist, finde ich es einfach nur beÃ¤ngstigend!

Auch hier steht Dresden mal wieder negativ im Fokus, weil wir den ganzen Querdenkern mehr als einmal eine Plattform gegeben haben und viel zu viel zugelassen haben. Mich kotzt auch an, dass viele Kultureinrichtungen und GeschÃ¤fte geschlossen haben. Es nervt, dass Kneipen, Restaurants und Clubs zu sind. Manchmal ist es lÃ¤stig, immer und Ã¼berall die Maske zu tragen. Aber hey, hier geht es ums Allgemeinwohl, und da scheiÃ ich auf persÃ¶nliche Befindlichkeiten. Ich will, dass wir das durchstehen. Ich mÃ¶chte wieder auf Festivals und mit Freunden essen oder tanzen gehen - und das nicht erst in ferner Zukunft. Ich mÃ¶chte, dass meine herzkranke Omi gesund bleibt. Und ich mÃ¶chte vor allem, dass wir hier nicht die Leichen mit Containern wegkarren. Diese EinschrÃ¤nkungen nehme ich gerne hin, nicht nur um mich, sondern auch um andere zu schÃ¼tzen.

Es macht mich wÃ¼tend, dass es immer noch Menschen gibt, denen das alles egal ist und die wilden Theorien glauben schenken. Menschen, die meinen, es handle sich um eine normale Grippe oder Bill Gates und Reptiloiden seien dafÃ¼r verantwortlich und so weiter. Ich weiÃ nicht, was bei denen schief gelaufen ist. Menschen behaupten, sie wÃ¼rden ihrer Rechte und Freiheiten beraubt, und ziehen Vergleiche, die jeder Logik und PietÃ¤t entbehren: Merkel mit Hitler, das ErmÃ¤chtigungsgesetz von 1933 mit den Coronaverordnungen oder die Maske mit einem Maulkorb. Es ist einfach irre! Was manche von sich geben, hat nichts mit faktenbasiertem Wissen zu tun, sondern mit Meinungen, die in Facebook-, Telegram- und WhatsApp-gruppen verbreitet werden. All das passt den Nazis gut in den kragen. Sie stimmen fleiÃig mit ein und nutzen es, um die Menschen in ihrer Ablehnung gegen den Staat und dessen MaÃnahmen zu befeuern. Viele sind so verblendet und merken das nicht.

FÃ¼r Dresdens Zukunft erhoffe ich mir, dass sich mehr Menschen gegen den braunen Dreck auflehnen. Ich mÃ¶chte gerne wieder mit stolz sagen kÃ¶nnen, dass ich hier wohne und mich nicht fÃ¼r die PrÃ¤senz und Akzeptanz von Pegida, AfD oder auch Querdenkern schÃ¤men. "I am from a small little village in the Vogtland and I came to Dresden in 2005 to study. I studied horticulture in Pillnitz. Even before I graduated from high school, I knew I wanted to go to Dresden. I looked in the study guide to see what you can study here. Then I visited some of the facilities at the TU during the Open University Day. Forestry in Tharandt didn't work out at first, but the HTW accepted me.

I have run the MontagscafÃ© at the Staatsschauspiel Dresden since the beginning of 2017. The MontagscafÃ© was founded in August 2015 because there was no space or occasion for encounters, contact between Dresdeners and the arriving refugees. Many people wanted to help, to establish contact. The refugees did not know their way around Dresden, they did not know German, and some of them had been through a lot in the wars in their home countries.

There was an urgent need for a place where these two "groups" could meet, otherwise it would have escalated - or one could say, otherwise we would not have been able to prove our ability to empathize and cooperate as a prerequisite for civilizing development and emancipation. The context of such a transcultural encounter space is crucial. We, as a public cultural institution, guarantee a certain security that here, as openly as possible, transparently, democratically, at an equal level ,and according to secular principles, all people are treated equally.

So far, funding has been divided into two parts. Infrastructure, space, technology and equipment are provided by the theater free of charge every Monday. To pay the two full-time employees* and the artistic program, we have received extensive and reliable support from the program "Integrative Measures" of the Free State of Saxony in the last three years. We have developed a new concept for the next three years in response to the changes in society in Saxony in the context of increasing pluralization and diversification. The political pressure on the distribution of funding has become tougher. Now, the support mainly goes to counseling and emergency assistance and not longer innovative, artistic meeting formats like the MontagscafÃ©.

The MontagscafÃ© has an average of 6,500 guests a year, sixty to seventy percent of whom are migrants or people without German passports. Every Monday we count between five and ten people who are new to Dresden. These are international students, refugees, migrant workers, or people "in transit" in general. On the other hand, with our cultural program, we make sure that issues in local civil society are at the forefront of our activities, so that there are always plenty of people around to help new people arrive, or simply to lend a sympathetic ear.

What we do is the most natural thing in the world: We say hello and welcome to every new person in Dresden. We are, so to speak, the informal welcoming committee of the city. Many, many people I know tell me that if the MontagscafÃ© hadn't existed, they would have left Dresden - because it was or is too bad and "xenophobic" or just not welcoming for them.

One evening an older gentleman came into the Monday CafÃ©, with his arm in a cast - obviously very embarrassed and shy, he had never been there before, neither in the theater nor in the MontagscafÃ©. He had been to the trauma surgeon across the street because of his arm and then read on the sign in the Kleines Haus that we were offering a comic workshop. He had secretly drawn critical comics in the GDR and reproduced them himself but had pretty much buried this part of his biography. With us, he gradually thawed out and drew stories for hours. He had obviously never had any contact with people from Syria or refugees. That evening he befriended an older man from Syria and then came regularly, even accompanied by his wife. The two of them could not really communicate, that is, linguistically, but they just understood each other wordlessly. I think this is a representative story for me, which says a lot.

One fundraiser is never enough to compensate for the loss of a major grant. But with this, we can bridge the waiting period. The fundraising campaign runs until the end of January and can be found here: https://www.betterplace.org/de/projects/86836. We made a special film about it with lots of guests. It says it all. https://fb.watch/2u9hcW37iK/

I hope that Dresden will have the courage to embrace a new realism. By this, I mean above all the realization that the new, the unfamiliar and the different offers great opportunities and resources for an exciting, joyful and sustainable coexistence. "You have to be able to see utopia" - is one of the most important guiding principles for the MontagscafÃ©, taken from Harald Welzer's book "Everything could be different." We live utopia - you could say. We make it tangible in a framework that doesn't immediately change your whole life, but first in a small, delicate, poetic way - and then you can go home and see where it leads you. Maybe you want to learn Arabic? Or cook? Or maybe just approach strangers for a change?"

Wir haben fÃ¼r die kommenden drei Jahre ein neues Konzept erarbeitet und damit auf die VerÃ¤nderung der sÃ¤chsischen Gesellschaft im Kontext von zunehmender Pluralisierung und Diversifikation reagiert. Jetzt werden vor allem Beratungs- und Notfallhilfen unterstÃ¼tzt, aber keine innovativen, kÃ¼nstlerischen Begegnungsformate wie das MontagscafÃ© mehr.

Jeden Montag zÃ¤hlen wir zwischen fÃ¼nf und zehn Menschen, die ganz neu in Dresden ankommen. Auf der anderen Seite sorgen wir mit unserem Kulturprogramm dafÃ¼r, dass Themen der lokalen Zivilgesellschaft bei uns im Mittelpunkt stehen und somit immer viele Leute da sind, die neuen Menschen bei Ankommen helfen, oder einfach nur ein offenes Ohr haben. 

Was wir machen ist ja das SelbstverstÃ¤ndlichste der Welt: Wir sagen Hallo und Herzlich Willkommen zu jeder neuen Person in Dresden. Wir sind sozusagen das informelle BegrÃ¼Ãungs-Kommitee der Stadt. Bei uns taute er allmÃ¤hlich auf und zeichnete stundenlang Geschichten. Er hatte offensichtlich noch nie Kontakt mit Menschen aus Syrien oder GeflÃ¼chteten. Der sagt eigentlich alles. https://fb.watch/2u9hcW37iK/

Ich wÃ¼nsche mir fÃ¼r Dresden Mut zu einem neuen Realismus. Damit meine ich vor allem die Erkenntnis, dass das Neue, Ungewohnte und Andere eine groÃe Chance und Ressource fÃ¼r ein aufregendes, freudvolles und zukunftsfÃ¤higes Miteinander bietet. "Utopie muss man sehen kÃ¶nnen" - ist einer der wichtigsten LeitsÃ¤tze fÃ¼r das MontagscafÃ©, Ã¼bernommen von Harald Welzer aus seinem Buch "Alles kÃ¶nnte anders sein". I have run the MontagscafÃ© at the Staatsschauspiel Dresden since the beginning of 2017. The MontagscafÃ© was founded in August 2015 because there was no space or occasion for encounters, contact between Dresdeners and the arriving refugees. Many people wanted to help, to establish contact. The refugees did not know their way around Dresden, they did not know German, and some of them had been through a lot in the wars in their home countries.

There was an urgent need for a place where these two "groups" could meet, otherwise it would have escalated - or one could say, otherwise we would not have been able to prove our ability to empathize and cooperate as a prerequisite for civilizing development and emancipation. The context of such a transcultural encounter space is crucial. We, as a public cultural institution, guarantee a certain security that here, as openly as possible, transparently, democratically, at an equal level ,and according to secular principles, all people are treated equally.

So far, funding has been divided into two parts. Infrastructure, space, technology and equipment are provided by the theater free of charge every Monday. To pay the two full-time employees* and the artistic program, we have received extensive and reliable support from the program "Integrative Measures" of the Free State of Saxony in the last three years. We have developed a new concept for the next three years in response to the changes in society in Saxony in the context of increasing pluralization and diversification. The political pressure on the distribution of funding has become tougher. Now, the support mainly goes to counseling and emergency assistance and not longer innovative, artistic meeting formats like the MontagscafÃ©.

The MontagscafÃ© has an average of 6,500 guests a year, sixty to seventy percent of whom are migrants or people without German passports. Every Monday we count between five and ten people who are new to Dresden. These are international students, refugees, migrant workers, or people "in transit" in general. On the other hand, with our cultural program, we make sure that issues in local civil society are at the forefront of our activities, so that there are always plenty of people around to help new people arrive, or simply to lend a sympathetic ear.

What we do is the most natural thing in the world: We say hello and welcome to every new person in Dresden. We are, so to speak, the informal welcoming committee of the city. Many, many people I know tell me that if the MontagscafÃ© hadn't existed, they would have left Dresden - because it was or is too bad and "xenophobic" or just not welcoming for them.

One evening an older gentleman came into the Monday CafÃ©, with his arm in a cast - obviously very embarrassed and shy, he had never been there before, neither in the theater nor in the MontagscafÃ©. He had been to the trauma surgeon across the street because of his arm and then read on the sign in the Kleines Haus that we were offering a comic workshop. He had secretly drawn critical comics in the GDR and reproduced them himself but had pretty much buried this part of his biography. With us, he gradually thawed out and drew stories for hours. He had obviously never had any contact with people from Syria or refugees. That evening he befriended an older man from Syria and then came regularly, even accompanied by his wife. The two of them could not really communicate, that is, linguistically, but they just understood each other wordlessly. I think this is a representative story for me, which says a lot.

One fundraiser is never enough to compensate for the loss of a major grant. But with this, we can bridge the waiting period. The fundraising campaign runs until the end of January and can be found here: https://www.betterplace.org/de/projects/86836. We made a special film about it with lots of guests. It says it all. https://fb.watch/2u9hcW37iK/

I hope that Dresden will have the courage to embrace a new realism. By this, I mean above all the realization that the new, the unfamiliar and the different offers great opportunities and resources for an exciting, joyful and sustainable coexistence. "You have to be able to see utopia" - is one of the most important guiding principles for the MontagscafÃ©, taken from Harald Welzer's book "Everything could be different." We live utopia - you could say. We make it tangible in a framework that doesn't immediately change your whole life, but first in a small, delicate, poetic way - and then you can go home and see where it leads you. Maybe you want to learn Arabic? Or cook? Or maybe just approach strangers for a change?"

Derzeit bin ich seit fast zwei Jahren krank und sitze im Rollstuhl. Vor zehn Jahren wurde mir der rechte Fuss amputiert, nachdem sich eine offene Wunde infiziert hatte. Da ich auch eine WundheilungsstÃ¶rung habe, wurde ich fast jÃ¤hrlich operiert, da sich am Stumpf immer wieder Wunden auftun. Um das zu verhindern, sitze ich jetzt im Rollstuhl. Aufgrund zahlreicher Vorerkrankungen bin ich gewissermaÃen der Inbegriff der Risikogruppe. 

Die EinschrÃ¤nkungen des tÃ¤glichen Lebens sind im Rollstuhl schon gravierend; mein Leben hat sich stark geÃ¤ndert. In diesem Jahr hat der Lockdown natÃ¼rlich auch vor mir nicht Halt gemacht. Um mobil zu bleiben, bin ich vor Corona einmal die Woche nach Leipzig, Dresden oder Berlin gefahren und hÃ¤ufig zu Freunden in Frankfurt. Das fehlt mir jetzt sehr. 
Ich lag von Oktober bis November insgesamt knapp acht Wochen im Krankenhaus. Zuerst war ich wegen einer OP im Elbe-Elster-Klinikum, unmittelbar danach im Uniklinikum Dresden. Dort wurde ich wÃ¤hrend meines Aufenthaltes mit Corona infiziert. 

Als klar war, dass mein Bettnachbar im Krankenzimmer coronapositv war, wurden wir alle getestet. Nach vierundzwanzig Stunden kam dann eine Ãrztin im Schutzanzug zu uns. Damit war die Diagnose schon klar. Im Zimmer waren wir - bis auf einen - alle positiv. In diesem Moment war das ein riesiger Schlag fÃ¼r mich. Ich dachte, das ist mein Todesurteil. Man weiÃ ja nicht, wie der Krankheitsverlauf ist. Am allerschlimmsten waren aber die vierundzwanzig Stunden nach dem Abstrich im Rachen bis zum Erhalt des Ergebnisses. Das Personal auf Station lieÃ sich kaum noch sehen, was ja verstÃ¤ndlich ist. Dazu kam die furchtbare Ungewissheit ,gepaart mit Hoffnung und Angst. Nach der Diagnose reduzierte sich dann alles auf Angst. 

Ich wurde dann unverzÃ¼glich auf die Isolierstation verlegt. Dort habe ich zwei Wochen verbracht, bis mein erster Test negativ war und ich wieder auf die Station zurÃ¼ck verlegt wurde. Ich hatte etwas Hustenreiz. Ansonsten ging es mir physisch gut, nur psychisch machte es grÃ¶Ãere Probleme. Erst nach ungefÃ¤hr einer Woche mit milden Symptomen schÃ¶pfte ich Hoffnung, dass ich Ã¼berleben kÃ¶nnte. Man bekommt ja mit, was sonst so passiert. Von meinem Fenster aus konnte ich die Bestattungsunternehmen sehen, die tÃ¤glich reinfuhren und der andere Patient in meinem Zimmer bekam Sauerstoff. 

Meine Mitpatienten hatten GlÃ¼ck. Einer wurde gleich an meinem ersten Tag als geheilt entlassen. Die anderen beiden bekamen Sauerstoff. Einer wurde dann auch verlegt. Allerdings erfÃ¤hrt man nicht, wohin oder warum. Gedanken macht man sich aber schon. Die Intensivstation leuchtet natÃ¼rlich als letzter Weg am Horizont . Es ist natÃ¼rlich auch einschÃ¼chternd, wenn das gesamte Personal Schutzkleidung mit Maske und Helm trÃ¤gt, man also niemanden wirklich sieht, auÃer die Augen. 

Direkt unter meinem Zimmer auf der Isolierstation stand die ungeheuer lange Schlange von Menschen, die sich testen lassen wollten. Das zeigte recht deutlich das AusmaÃ der Infektion. Die Station war bis an die Grenzen belegt. Das Krankenhauspersonal ist im Moment wirklich an der Grenze. Pausen sind Seltenheit, weil das An- und Ausziehen der Schutzkleidung natÃ¼rlich auch Zeit braucht. Dennoch waren alle Mitarbeiter auf der Isolierstation sehr nett. Vom Arzt bis zum Physiotherapeuten und dem Reinigungspersonal. Jeder versuchte stÃ¤ndig, Otpimismus zu verbreiten, zu trÃ¶sten und zu erklÃ¤ren, was an Tests durchgfÃ¼hrt wird und wie es weitergehen wird. Das verdient wahre Hochachtung - mehr als Klatschen.

Einerseits bin ich durch meine Ã¼berstandene Krankheit jetzt natÃ¼rlich schon freier, da ich mit den AntikÃ¶rpern ja bereits immunisiert bin. Allerdings machen mir die Mutationen des Virus schon Sorgen. Ob die ImmunitÃ¤t dagegen hift, ist vÃ¶llig unklar. SelbstverstÃ¤ndlich trage ich auch weiterhin Maske. Ich habe in meinem weiteren Bekanntenkreis bereits einen, der an oder mit Corona verstorben ist - und das mit gerade Ende dreiÃig. Vieles wÃ¤re einfacher, wenn es nicht so viele Idioten geben wÃ¼rde."

"I am 53 years old. I was born in what was then the district of Riesa and still live here. After my military service, I studied mathematics and business administration in Dresden, Marburg and Frankfurt. Now I work in the security services sector.

At present, I have been ill for almost two years and am in a wheelchair. Ten years ago, my right foot was amputated after an open wound became infected. Since I also have a wound healing disorder, I have had surgery almost every year because wounds keep opening up on the stump. To prevent this, I am now in a wheelchair. Due to numerous pre-existing conditions, I am in a sense the epitome of the at-risk group.

The limitations of daily life are already serious in a wheelchair; my life has changed a lot. This year, of course, the lockdown has not stopped at me. To stay mobile, I went to Leipzig, Dresden or Berlin once a week and often to friends in Frankfurt before corona. I miss that very much now.
Between October and November, I was in the hospital for a total of almost eight weeks. First I was in the Elbe-Elster-Klinikum for an operation, immediately afterwards in the University Hospital Dresden. There I was infected with Corona during my stay.

When it was clear that my roommate in the hospital room had covid, we were all tested. After twenty-four hours, a doctor in a protective suit came to see us, making the diagnosis clear. In the room, all of us - except for one - were positive. At that moment, it was a huge blow for me. I thought, this is my death sentence. You don't know how the disease will progress. But worst of all were the twenty-four hours after the throat swab until I received the results. The staff on the ward were hardly around, which is understandable. In addition, there was the terrible uncertainty, coupled with hope and fear. After the diagnosis, everything was reduced to fear.

I was then immediately transferred to the isolation ward. I spent two weeks there until my first test was negative ,and I was transferred back to the ward. I did have some coughing. Otherwise I was physically fine; it only caused major psychological problems for me. Only after about a week of mild symptoms did I start to have hope that I might survive. After all, you get to see what else is going on. From my window I could see the morticians coming in every day, and the other patient in my room was getting oxygen.

My fellow patients were lucky. One was discharged as cured on my very first day. The other two got oxygen. One was then transferred as well. However, you don't find out where or why. But you do worry about it. Of course, the intensive care unit is the last resort. It's also intimidating, of course, when all the staff are wearing protective clothing with masks and helmets, so you can't really see anyone except for their eyes.

Directly below my room in the isolation ward was the tremendously long line of people waiting to be tested. That showed quite clearly the extent of the infection. The ward was filled to capacity. The hospital staff is really at the limit right now. Breaks are rare because putting on and taking off the protective clothing naturally takes time. Nevertheless, all the staff in the isolation ward were very nice. From the doctor to the physical therapist and the cleaning staff. Everyone was constantly trying to spread optimism, comfort, and to explain what tests are being done and how things will proceed. This deserves true respect - more than clapping.

On the one hand, I am of course freer now because I have survived the disease and am already immunized with the antibodies. However, I am worried about the mutations of the virus. Whether the immunity helps against new versions is completely unclear. Of course, I continue to wear a mask. I already have one person in my circle of acquaintances who died of/with Corona - and he was in his late thirties. Many things would be easier if there weren't so many idiots."

--
Why do we do interviews with Pegida at all?

Everyone knows roughly what these people have to say. "Islamization is in full swing, crime is on the rise, people are coming to us for social benefits, I hardly dare go out on the street in the evening, I hope the AfD will get even stronger." Do we need to write it all down again?

First of all, our project is called "people in Dresden," not "nice people in Dresden." When we approach people on the street, we don't know what they're like. Astonishingly, we end up with a very large proportion of nice conversations with nice people. Of course, that's partly because the not-so-nice ones don't talk to us that often. When we do interviews at Pegida, of course, it's different. Further, it's not the same every time. In the beginning, so maybe 2015, 2016, it was difficult to make contact. The atmosphere was quite hostile, bad words were hurled at us, and in general it's just insanely draining to listen to it all in all its contradictoriness.

Nevertheless, we think it's important to document that as well. Not because we want to "give a stage" to certain opinions or because we find it useful to talk to right-wingers. We don't talk at all, but listen. Our approach is not to exchange opinions and argue in conversation. We also do not believe that our site is a practical place to spread Pegida ideas. In my opinion, you would assume this mainly if you don't know much else about People in Dresden/people in Dresden - or are just trapped in your thought patterns. By the way, we are relatively reflective and think about things before we do them.

Couldn't it also be that this is a place (not the only place) where the inhuman views of the day are documented? And what happens when we post an interview here and out of 100 comments, 98 completely disagree?

I remember one interview where I stood by speechless and couldn't believe that people could say misanthropic things in a formal ready-to-print manner like that. After the post was reported, Facebook unfortunately removed it and then later removed the text in which we replaced the worst words with *** (and banned me for three days). I still find that sad because such a part of this project has disappeared. Sure, there are a lot of really cool people in Dresden and we're glad that we were able to show so many of them, but without these interviews, which as I said make up an amazingly small part of all interviews, the site just wouldn't be complete.

That's why we show some of them here again. Please don't report us on Facebook.

"I am retired, single, and live relatively well, and I am here today because Pegida is. Since the start, since Pegida has existed, I have come here regularly and fight so that Germany can be better again at some point.

What I think is good and what is actually the basic principle why Pegida was founded at all is: The Islamization of Europe, which is already inexorably in progress, especially in Germany, because we have taken in so many. And you can see what has happened through statistics, for example criminality. No one likes to go out anymore on the street in the evening, because people are afraid. That is a fact. There are problematic areas here in Dresden â the former high-rise housing blocks. Itâs a catastrophe. The criminality is a result of the immigration. Today, there were numbers read by a member of parliament, who just spoke. Itâs really bad.

Islam equals terrorism, since everywhere where there is terrorism, Islam is behind it. Islam is not a belief; itâs always only been about ruling the world. They have been trying that for centuries.

I hope that the AfD is clearly ahead in the elections. It will change a lot. The repatriation of people who donât have any residential right, since there are a hundred thousand who only have the right to stay, and they have to be sent away first of all. I canât say if that can be dealt with on the state level.

There are now elections in three states, which used to be in the East. The people are still somewhat smarter in those places. In the old West Germany, there has been a high percentage of foreigners for a longer time. They have gotten somewhat used to it. They have always done somewhat better; they could build up their prosperity and have been able to maintain it, in large part. I canât say anything general, but it has also gotten worse in the old West Germany. There are so many âNo Go Areas,â from example Marxloh. Berlin is now also totally awful. The percentage of foreigners is so large that the Germans feel themselves pushed back and if you go through the city paying attention, there are almost only foreign businesses. There are quarters where there are only foreigners. I avoid Berlin now. I donât like to go there anymore.

In East Germany, we already had a dictatorship. And at the time of the reunification, we had democracy. We had hopes, and it actually went forward for a long time. But then starting in 2000, it went downhill, and since 2010, itâs taken big steps toward the cellar. Now, we are almost in the cellar. I am of the opinion that our whole government only takes care of itself and does nothing for the people. That canât go well over the long term. At some point, the people will rise up again, and probably first here in the east."

Wir sprechen meistens die Leute auf der StraÃe an und erklÃ¤ren kurz, wer wir sind und was wir vorhaben. Die allermeisten Reaktionen sind nett und wir gehen auch gar nicht davon aus, dass jeder Lust hat, mit wildfremden Menschen zu sprechen, aber manchmal wissen wir nicht, ob wir lachen oder weinen sollen. Folgende Menschen durften wir schon kennenlernen:

Die grimmigen Einheimischen: Gucken woanders hin oder einen an, als wÃ¶llte man ihnen die Bratwurst klauen. Oft sagen sie gar nichts, manchmal versteht man es nicht so richtig, groÃe Worte gebrauchen sie eigentlich nie. Das wÃ¤ren wahrscheinlich die Leute, die die Bandbreite unserer Seite erhÃ¶hen wÃ¼rden.

Die unentschiedenen Einheimischen: Wahrscheinlich haben sie Mitleid mit uns. Andererseits wollen sie ihre Ruhe. Standardantwort: âEigentlich ungern.â An solchen Antworten halten wir uns fest, wenn es dunkel und kalt ist.
Die AuslÃ¤nder, die wirklich gern ein Interview machen mÃ¶chten, aber nicht jetzt: Schaut auf die Uhr, stellt fest, dass er Ã¼berhaupt keine Zeit hat, aber nein sagen mÃ¶chte er auch nicht. Since no one wants to give us interviews at the moment, we will post a photo from Santa Fe, the home of our interviewer. Also, here's a typology of refusing an interview. We usually approach people on the street and briefly explain who we are and what we are up to. The vast majority of reactions are nice, and we don't assume that everyone wants to talk to complete strangers, but sometimes we don't know whether to laugh or cry. We have had the pleasure of meeting the following people:

The grim locals: Looking somewhere else or at you as if you wanted to steal their bratwurst. Often they don't say anything, sometimes you don't really understand, they never use big words. These would probably be the people who would increase the bandwidth of our site.

The undecided locals: They probably feel sorry for us. On the other hand, they want their peace. Standard answer, "Actually, I would prefer not to." We cherish such answers when it's dark and cold.

The foreigner who would really like to do an interview, but not now. He checks his watch, realizes he has no time at all but doesn't want to say no either. He asks for an appointment for next week, pockets our business card and says he'll write to us. Do they know how much business cards cost?

The people who don't have time, but somehow do. Not having time is the standard excuse. But some people, after telling us they have no time, then manage to stand next to us for fifteen minutes and watch us approach people. Kind of creepy.

The nasty ones: "Fake news!", "I don't talk to everyone!", "I don't like foreigners, that's why I always carry this! [pulls out a blackjack]" Since we aren't getting paid for it, it's a bit too much for us.

The people who don't actually want to give an interview, but do, and only say something afterwards. Very annoying, because you waste a lot of time. We're usually out once a week doing as many interviews as we can. Talking to someone for twenty minutes, taking a picture, and getting a message half an hour later saying they didn't mean it is really irritating.

The people who find their companion much more interesting than themselves and always refer to the person next to them. The chance of an interview is less than ten percent.

The one with the very specific reason: "Sorry, my dog is too ugly." That answer has amused us for years. Thanks for that!

Yesterday my colleague Robert shared a typology of rejection that we have developed in the last six years of doing interviews. When I am old and gray, I am sure I will remember those moments well â standing on Prager StraÃe, hopping up and down in the cold, feeling my legs freeze, and hearing no after no. Itâs toughened me up for sure. At this point, I am willing to approach almost anyone, in whatever state of sobriety or sanity, as long as they look like they have something to say. At least as long as I have Robert behind me.

What I hope I will remember more vividly, however, are the many, many good people we have interviewed in organizations and associations all over Dresden. Most of these groups came into being or sprang into action with the arrival of refugees in 2015, like the MontagscafÃ©, SPIKE, the ABC-Tische, CafÃ© Halva, the Bildungspatenschaften des AuslÃ¤nderrats, CafÃ© International, Start with a Friend, Prohlis ist Bunt, and Banda Internationale. But we have also visited the offices of Drobs, the homeless newspaper, spontaneously encountered street workers near the main train station, and talked to the kids and music teachers in the wonderful Musaik program in Prohlis.

Doing these interviews fills me not only with appreciation and respect for their paid employees, volunteers, and âvisitors,â but also with a kind of calm. As long as there are these people in Dresden in such great numbers, things canât be too terrible. I am an idealist at heart, and talking to the volunteers, in particular, confirms what I want to believe about the world: Helping someone else makes your own life meaningful. Forming relationships and bonds that extend beyond your family or your social group is energizing. We can create communities with the people around us to make our city better. Life is not a zero-sum game in which the Germans can only win if everyone else loses.

The Covid 19 pandemic has shut down the activities of most of the above-named organizations, but I am looking forward to meeting these people again as soon as it is possible.
